reviews.review: Lovely place for a stroll. This is such a lovely walk, with interesting shops, cute little places to eat and stop for a wine (and some of that yummy local runny cheese and fresh bread!). The tessellated tiles are just beautiful, however I've head the local municipality want to rip them up as they are too high maintenance). This town is made for strolling and you will definitely enjoy a walk down to the harbour.
shopping. very good for shopping and finding little boutiques - they also have the standard shops but still has a charm of it's own
GREAT. Nice place, take all the time you can, don't hurry and just enjoy the views around you. Than indulge yourself with some fine portugese food.

Entrence to Lisbon. Large plaza with a wide range of shops and restaurants to choose from. There is a boat that takes you to the other side of the river and the nearby Rua Agusta is also filled with places to eat and shop.

Palace Square. The Praca do Comercio is a sunny happy square bordering the waterfront of the Tagus and surrounded by three elegant arcaded ochre and white buildings that used to be the palace designed by Pombal. Although no longer the gateway to Lisbon, it is now a buzzing trendy location for tourists and locals where street musicians and seagulls abound. The magestic triumphal arch leads into the city. In the center of the square is a huge statue of King Jose I. Inside the arcaded passage is a very helpful tourist information office.

great shopping street. If you don't mind a good little shopping in a great architecture surroundings then go here! very nice street to shop, eat and walk around. Road tiles mosaics made from different stones are marvellous.
The main street of Lisbon for tourists. The main street of Lisbon for tourists, full of shops with souvenirs, restaurants and other products like shoes , clothes,etc.

Grand Plaza. Large plaza with majority of government buildings flanking it. Tried most of the cafes -- good place to drink wine/beer while you wait to take the river cruise directly across the street. One has great pizza. The plaza gives you a good sense of the grandeur of Portuguese history and culture. it is also a good place to walk to Chiado and Barrio Alta.

Praca de Comercio - the most attractive place in city. Praca de Comercio - the most attractive place in city! Shopping, food, street performers, access to the river... Nice and wide! Lots or fresh air!

Architectural wonder. Beautiful architecture all over...an amazing experience. So much to see ...so little time. Restaurants, cafes, shops etc. The food in Portugal is amazing....you can't find a bad thing to say about it. Especially if you are a food expert and love wine. It's amazing .

Heart of touristic Lisbon. You can't come to Lisbon without first walking towards the Praca do Comercio..the buildings, the square, the view...superb.
There are bars and restaurants and wide open spaces and oh yes....shops!

Sternly sterile. Don't expect glamour as in St Marks Venice or Trafalgar Square in London. Yes it's large but quite uninteresting. From there go through the arch and join the crowds in Rua Augusta. It's a flat walk up to Rossio with side streets just as interesting.
Large central square.. Large well proportioned square with cafes and restaurants. As it is near the tourist centre prices tend to be higher than elsewhere.
Beautiful Plaza. Beautiful, open, big plaza. It is so bright you need to have your sun glasses on. Behind the gate the walking street full of restaurants and shops.
Beautiful. Very nice place to get the feeling of Portuguese atmosphere, smell the sea, watch the tourists walking around, amazing buildings, lots of restaurants. Would spend hours there.

Holiday in Portugal. We had to go here to book the tickets for the bus tour.
A large open square with shops & restaurants around its sides with the front open to the river.
Pleasant area for walking.

Wonderful main square. In the old days this used to be the square to welcome all the ships from the famous Navigators and Explorers. the square offers wonderful restaurants ( little overpriced though), the Arch of Rua Augusta that you can climb, the street "Rua Augusta" which is a small shopping street and above all: my favorite museum "Lisbon story center", that I can highly recommend.

Beautiful square, especially at sunset!. Expect lots of tourists and lots of offers for tourists! Be it food offers, shops, traditional art, chances are you will find it here, although maybe not for the best price. The square is right to the shore and you are almost certain to find an ad-hoc fiesta next to the river. Street musicians, people who feel like dancing and nice places offering a wine or cocktails to enjoy along with a sunset over the river, they're all two steps away. The arch is impressive and the square it's said to be the place where the medieval ships would come to and bring spices and other exotic goods from overseas.

Beautiful pedestrian way with a view of the square and shore in the distance.. A must see street, but quite touristy! Perfectly safe, but be wise about your belongings, as in any crowded area. Architecture is gorgeous, and the square at the end is your bonus for walking the distance!
Thriving Area in Lisbon. This is a vibrant pedestrian street with many shops and outdoor cafes and restaurants. The celebrated arch makes a great visual when walking towards the Praca do Comercio.
Beautiful Waterfront Square. Beautiful and large waterfront square on the Waterfront. Places to eat and drink. Its at the beginning of the very touristy but fun Rue de Augusta

This is a great Square near nice shopping.. Nice "Plaza" with live street musicians and good shopping. Very good lunch spots and for drinks. Worth visiting. It has a look and feel of a truly European piazza. We found a particularly nice leather good shop for pocketbooks and back packs.

Repeat Repeat. Ok it is a massive plaza/that runs the length of the City centre from Praca Don Pedro right down to the seafront. However from a content standpoint it is sadly much like any other tourist centre. Lots of shops/big brands and every 15 metres a small Asian tourist shop selling exactly the same tat as the one 15 metres either side of it, which really spoil the whole place. The whole of Lisbon is sadly blighted by these. No innovation no differential it is a pity the Council let it happen. The centre of the walkway is full of restaurants which offer a variety of cuisine, lots of local and very typical dishes which is good. Fish a plenty alongside cheeses and meat dishes.In the evening it can be like an assault course dodging all the menu guys but at least it feels safe and is well lit.
good street to get your bearings. This is the main square which has the turist office and the main street through townLisbon Story and Beer musium also off this square
A must see and live. The heart of the action in Lisbon, very touristic, but that's the point here.....nice places to est, drink and see people go by....
Impressive quare. Huge square with many bars and restaurants surrounding it. On the day we arrived there was a fascinating craft market and some excellent buskers.
lovely plaza. lots of stuff to do here, beautiful views of the water and shopping streets. Really lovely wine tasting in the square. Nice statue and arc.

Beautiful to look at but expensive food. The archway leading to Commercial Square is beautiful, and as you step through for the first time it is breathtaking. Within thd square you have 'The Sexiest WC in Lisbon', at 1€ it's not the cheapest convenience but a sight to see!! Lots of restaurants but they seemed expensive and impersonal - we paid 23€ for 2 sandwiches and 2 cans of iced tea on the first day, and they were average.

Lisbon doorway from the river. A large square with about 35.000 sq metres, its the perfect gateway between Lisbon downtown and Tagus river.The former location of a Royal Palace, it was completely destroyed by 1755 Lisbon earthquake, after which it was rebuild as part of the Lisbon downtown rebuilding plan of Marquis of Pombal, Minister of the Kingdom during the reign of Dom José I.Walking down Augusta Street, you enter Praça do Comercio through Augusta Street Arch and end up in the Tagus River port, from where caravels would arrive to unload and trade their goods. From that standpoint, this square also worked as the Kingdom customs.An historical curiosity, it was in this square that the last King of Portugal, Dom Carlos I, was assassinated in February 1st, 1908.

Visited for a day.. Very nice city with lots of tourists and surprisingly no hustlers begging for money like in other cities we have been. Lisbon is fond of using small flat stones in their sidewalks and sidestreets which is nice especially with designs on it but be careful of dips and bumps as it is not as level as one might assume. Don't bring your skateboard as you will definitely make a lot of noise.

The Praca is a perfect place. To visit the place is best in late afternoon
At sunset.
River view is a beauty.
Many tourists are standing

Outstanding!. This plaza was built to commemorate the merchants who supported the city by paying an additional tax after the big earthquake to rebuild the city. On one end of Rua Augusta is Parco Comercio and on the other side is Parco Rossio. There is a beautiful arch and magnificent statue and it's right across the street from the river. At night in the summer they have an amazing light show in this square. Really fabulous but it only plays in the summer on certain nights. Check ahead and plan accordingly. It's a light show you cannot miss!

Great way to spend an afternoon in Lisbon. A lovely place to stroll around, window shop and get a feel of lisbon. If you walk towards the square there is an Italian restaurant called Nosolo Italia which serves the most delicious food. Lots of options for vegetarians as well! Don't forget to try their sangrias!
Terreiro do Paco Oct 2016. A great place to visit for the family especially if the weather is good. Plenty to see and soak up the local culture in this sector.

Don’t missed it. This is a really a very impressive square with the triumphal arch and as an added bonus the ocean is right behind it. Nice place to take some good photography, to learn some history and go for a long walk. Not to be missed!

ONE OF THE BEST LANDMARKS OF LISBON!. Every road leads to.... Praca do Comercio! located close to the beach and Tajo river, this huge (and with open space) square also connects (through Rua Augusta etc) downtown with upper town. there are many bar restaurants around it in order to enjoy your stay here!
Great View. Lots of shops and places to eat in this area - This path opens out to a large square. Good for a photo opportunity.

recent visit. This appears to be the main square in Lisbon.It is very tourist orientated. This is very near to where the cruise ships dock.There are all the usual shops and restaurants around this square. It is well worth a visit.

Not to be miised. The Praca do Comercio at the end of the Rua Augusta (a very grand pedestrian only street) must be the most photographed part of Lisbon. The grand yellow buildings surrounding the riverfront square, with the Arch Rua Augusta at the centre, are very photogenic and the square itself is a place where both locals and tourists tend to congregate. It is also a central point because it is surrounded by Alfama, Baixa, Chida and Bairro Alto. As a result you will find yourself there at some point during your stay in Lisbon.

The centre of everything in Lisbon. You won't need to go looking for this attraction, it's central to everything and right on the River. Huge wide open space surrounded by beautiful buildings, loads of places to eat and drink (the ones in the square are a bit pricey and touristy- try those just outside)

The heart of Lisbon. This vast square with views of the Targus, competes with many around the world. Lined on one side with restaurants and the avenues of Baixia all lead from here. The tram15e for Belem can be caught from here.

Walk or shop, always something new. This plaza and pedestrian mall is full of surprises, restaurants, shops and old architecture. We went several times for dinner or dessert at different places. Good photo opportunities day or night

Nice shops and restaurants but.... Too many hawkers of useless hype goodies for kids, too many pushy waiters almost shoving you on a chair in their restaurant.
That being said the praca offers you a great walk and view on the Taag estuary.

Do not miss a visit. Praça do Comércio, in the beginning it was an open market, with the arrival of most goods by ship. It suffered during some decades and it was used as a Carpark. Finally is has been recovered and changed into the actual as configuration. Trendy restaurants, bars. The view to the river, fantastic. Cais das Colunas.

People watching. Pleasant, very clean square at the southern end of Baixa, surrounded by coffee shops and restaurants, which we didn't try as, from past holiday experience, they are usually tourist traps with little local authenticity.After taking in the architecture, it is worth walking down to the river's edge to dip your toes in the water to cool down, and perhaps sit and listen to the buskers for a few minutes.

Great Surprise. My ancient travel book said the square was a disappointment at close quarters because most of it was devoted to a car park - not any more. Its now a sparkling clear area dominated by the marvelous equestrian statue and is a great place to sit and have coffee etc at the various cafes and admird the architecture.
A Lisbon must....Compulsory!!!!. Great walk with the family. Nice stores and architecture. Just keep walking until the end of the road to find the most beautiful square in Lisbon.
Very square. This is of interest by its surrounding cafes bars etc.It also hosts some ad hoc markets.Remarkably litter free.but on a winters day a bleak expanse of ..well paving.
Beautiful view. Once you step on the Praca, you can feel the fresh breeze from the Tagus River. A place where one can enjoy just watching people go by or sitting near the river.

A little touristy but worth seeing. It's big, in the center of the downtown along the waterfront and worth wandering through. Lots of restaurants along one side and tourist shops but does have a great information center. The arch leads to Rua Augusta and the heart of the city.

Don't miss it! . Come to take in the view and the architecture. There's not really that much to do here unless you plan to enjoy an hour or two in one of the many overpriced cafes that line the sides of the square. But there is plenty to see! Local people doing what local people do. Tourists doing what tourists do. The big wide open square with an incredible statue in the center and beautiful old buildings with remarkable galleries lining the sides. The square sits in front of the river and the views are quite good. People watching is the star attraction here. But the place also gives you a feeling for the rest of Lisbon. It sets the stage for everything else you'll see here. Don't miss it.

Midweek trip. This is the place to stop over once you are on the hop on hop buss....nice teracces,the coffee and let's not forget the portugese wine...delicious. Eat at one of the many side walk restaurants, good sardines, bacaloa (dried cod in special suaces)...

View of the arches. This place was lovely to see very cosmopolitan. The cafes are all in a row and you can see the view through the arch to the waterfront. Nice day and night. Very busy. Nice place to have a meal and watch the world go by.

Pretty, but prepare to be pestered. Its a nice square, great opportunity for some photos and selfies and the statue is nice. Some restaurants etc if you want that. However, it's let down by the fact that I was only there for about ten minutes ans got asked by three different people if I wanted to buy marijuana (one of them asked me twice and even told me it's legal in Portugal - I can assure you it's not). Also a woman selling "genuine sunglasses" tried to coerce me as well. It's annoying that the police are there, but just appear to turn a blind eye and walk past.
Grand and beautiful plaza!. Overlooking the Atlantic Ocean, the statue evoke the spirit of maritime exploration and commerce of the Portuguese.Grandeur.
Nice place. The place is nice, filled with lot of people, sea from one side, almost romantic in the evening. But the drug dealers here are very annoying.

it's a square!. We walked through the Prace do Comercio a couple of times during our recent stay in Lisbon. There are a few restauants and cafes (which we didn't visit), plus a statue of Jose I, some nice architecture and a grand arch we walked under that leads to the Baixa.
Friendly. A friendly place with friendly people. This is the tourist hotspot so there are many bars. The bars are amazing with live music.

Beautiful square by the river. A very nice square by the river, some nice attractions near by. One of the problems in Lisbon right now is some transports, i was there for an hour waiting for the bus to Belem but it never arrived!
Breathtaking buildings. Beautiful buildings surround you as you walk from ocean to city park, gorgeous architecture. Prepare for the crush of tourists, very busy!

Beautiful commercial square. The square is architecturally beautiful and definitely worth seeing. It is filled with coffee shops and restaurants and is lovely place to have a wander round. There are views back up towards the Sao Jorge Castle in the city and also views out to sea. Great spot for an ice cream and some people watching.

People Watching at its Best. One of about 7 bar/restaurants around Commercial Square this is a fine place to take a break and refresh mind and body – especially on a hot day. There is a good range of food and drink at competitive prices and staff who are helpful and able to speak English - so often a plus point.

GREAT STREET TO WALK. The square is impressive in design and is right near the water and other sights. You can make your shopping, have coffe, lunch or dinner. In most restaurants the prices are touristic.

Great square to walk around in. This is a great square to walk around in and get a coffee at. The square is impressive in design and is right near the water and other sights. We actually walked to San Gorge castle from the square, a bit of a hike but a nice walk.

A beautiful space.. This is an ideal area to relax whilst admiring the beauty of the area.
Its proximity to the river gives access to boats and ferries.
There are plenty of restaurants and cafes surrounding the square.

Admire the views but avoid the restaurants. It is a magnificent square where you can relive the grandeur of the time when Portugal was a wealthy nation. Nowadays the walking area's to the square are full of beggars, bad restaurants and occasional drug dealers. Too bad the local authorities don't take adequate actions ...

What a sight - a must visit. Vosited The Praça do Comércio which is located in the city of Lisbon, Portugal.
Overlooking the Tagus river, the square is still commonly known as Terreiro do Paço because it was the location of the Paços da Ribeira (Royal Ribeira Palace)
Big square with lots of cafe and reatautabg.
A must visit when in lisbon.
.

Shopping & Food with lovely picture ops. Great shopping. Tapas, paella, pasta, pizza & many pastry shops & cafes. Nice cobblestone walking Street with not having to worry about vehicular traffic! Can spend a great afternoon here.

Portuguese grandeur.. Such a lovely space - it needs to be experienced first hand to appreciate its scale and beauty. Once the site of the Royal Palace, now mainly government offices, but with a beautiful pousada recently added as well.
Great view and local feeling. Sitting, singing, watching the water, resting, u name it! Very close to city center, this is an important point to visit while in Lisbon!
Sightseeing. It was a beautiful weather to walk around this place. A music group performed on the waterfront and we enjoyed it so much.

Good place to relax and enjoy a drink. Its a typical tourist spot with great architecture. Can imagine the past that this would be a kind of harbor to welcome ship travelers to Lisbon. Warning - can get too hot in the summers, best to enjoy a drink in one of the many cafes closeby and enjoy the views.

Awesome . This square at the heart of the city once was the gateway to those sailing into Lisbon.The square boasts magnificent structural buildings, museums, shops and restaurants. It's a great place to wonder around during the day and evening and to soak up the great atmosphere and listening to singers at the seafront with crowds eager to listen to good music.The square is also the starting point for excursion pick to spots, trams, buses and tuk tuks.
Excellent. Very busy, street artists ,great atmosphere buzzing. We had lunch in a street cafe and did some shopping .

Another wonderful Place. Great place to walk around, people watch, and just enjoy Lisbon life (although I think it was mainly tourists while I was there - they are from all over so even that was nice)

It is a must. It was funny to see the diference from 20 years ago. Then it was a parking and now center of the live at town. I visited it at 18 and was lovely . The river Tejo and people playing music there.
Everyone ends up here.. A wonderful wide open plaza, right on the banks of the river. A hub of activity, great photo ops and fun place to be.
Lovely space but busy and a target. The beating heart of Lisbon this place is but it attracts crowds and the trams that go through are major spots for pickpockets - be careful!

Amazing for sightseeing and shopping!. If you wish to do some shopping, dining or sightseeing, this is the right place for you! It's super close to Chiado and Alfama and offers you access to a lot of other location. Definitely recommended!

Best square in Lisbon. So spacious, gracious, with a lot of shops.Details on the monuments for their King are amazing. If you do not have a tour guide, read about it as it is one of the most interesting stories about Lisbon we heard.

Impressive Lisbon Square. This large public square is located on the site of the former Ribeira Palace which was destroyed by the earthquake of 1755 (most of Lisbon was also destroyed). In the aftermath the square was designed to be reminiscent of the former Palace. Shops abound in the U shaped building that surrounds the square. Its a great place for a walk and you will, of course, walk down by the Tagus river located on the south side.This is an easy walk for anyone who is in the Baixa-Chiado area.
Good Place. I walked quite the Terreiro do Paco , a site with lots of people , but with large space and beautiful things to visit .

great place with nice atmosphere. I enjoyed spending some time at this place, taking in the beautiful view both over the Tagus river and beautiful bridge and on the other side seeing the arch and Rua Augusta. There are several restaurants around the square where you can enjoy a good dinner and the atmosphere.

Beautiful square, nice place for a walk. This is a perfect place to start you Lisbon tour, the square is huge with an amazing arch signaling the beginning of Rua Augusta, one of Lisbon famous streets. On the other side you can enjoy the view of the Tagus river. Surrounding the square you will notice a set of neat symmetrical buildings pretty well maintained, these hold government offices. I visit during daytime and the atmosphere was quite pleasant, perfect place to go for a stroll and enjoy the scenery.

Spacious and Impressive. Very big rectangular square facing the river Tejo. There are some cafes on the perimeter of the square and the monument in the center. If it goes about summer, it is advisable to visit it early in the morning or before the sunset. Otherwise there is very hot, an open sunshine and the shade only in the galleries. In the night lit are only the surrounding galleries and the monument itself, so other space remains dark and it will be hard to get a good photo in the darkness. No benches or trees at the square.
Favorite place in Lisbon. If u r thinking where to go in Lisbon, go to Bairro Alto where Praca do Comercio is. This is my favorite place. It's very calm and romantic there.
Nice atmosphere. The arch is lovely to look at and there's are loads of shops and restaurants near by. It looks really good lit up at night.

Another must for Lisboa visitors, but you will get there anyway at some point. You can take the tramp no 15 from there. It will take you to the Belem district. The ticket could be bought at the subway station located nearby.

Way to Shop.. Busy but extremely nice place to visit. Multiple places to eat & shop until you drop. Nice & safe environment. reasonable prices. Lots of souvenirs to choose from. Definitely recommend this visit. will take at least 3 to 4 hrs.

Great sites to see.. This is one of the most spectacular sites in Lisbon. Now, be very mindful of when visiting this area. Drug dealers are all over this tourist spot. Also try to avoid the people wearing orange vests. They will try to talk nice then hustle a deal. The police will not stop these people. I will let you figure the rest. Still a really nice area and site.
The old commercial entry to the sea front and the city. The old commercial entry to the sea front and the city, plenty of bars and restaurants either side of the archway, cool breeze off the sea.
BEAUTIFUL VIEWS. It's a place you can not miss when you visit Lisbon. Huge square, where you can rest for a while on a bar, and look to the sea...
Beautiful Square. This is one of the most beautiful squares in Europe located right on the water. There are plenty of restaurants and cafes that one can visit.
Wide spaces. Wide open plaza and great photo ops. Go there and do it. Catch the number 15 tram nearby and head to Belem!

Gorgeous square. This is where most of the important events of Lisbon happen - now it is no longer a parking spot but once again is a gorgeous fitting entrance to Lisbon - the arch is superb. Stroll along the waterside

Some of our best photos were from here..... A gorgeous stroll through majestic architecture and gorgeous limestone patterned streets, this visit should not be missed!
A tour guide we worked with took us here and many top sights would have been missed without his help.

Gateway to the city. Walking through the arch from the river side into the bustling city gave us the sense that we had arrived by ship. The avenue is smooth tile and very walkable. We love streets that you don't have to share with vehicles. Got great pictures of city life here. Lots of sidewalk cafe' s, street musicians, and street vendor. The buildings provided shade even in the heat of summer.
Great restaurants and cafes. This is a great area with shops, restaurants, cafes. Evening it really comes alive. The walk takes you down to the waterfront.
Beautiful square. Beautiful square with an amazing architecture and great landscape of the water. Must visit when in Lisbon.The restaurants and bars near have high prices.
Stunning!. A square with the wow factor. Stunning architecture, brilliant photo opportunities. Plenty to see, and excellent food options

Nice square. One of the place I recommend to visit while you visit Lisbon. And from here you can take the trams and just cruising around in the beautiful Alfama. If not, the place is surrounded with shops and bars and really close to the water. The square is also known as Terrier do Paco because one day the royal palace stood here.

Lovely. A beautiful place. Lovely architecture. Great view of the water. Lots of shopping options. It is so large that even with lots of people around you don't feel like it's mobbed. It has a lovely atmosphere.
Beautiful. Absolutely beautiful plaza. Great sculptures and architecture. Great view of the water opposite the arch. Lots of food options.
Very beautiful. This is a centrally located square near the Tagus river and with great views and sights. Full of Lisbon's story!

Gateway to the city. Big beautiful square right on the water front. Walk through the huge arch which really feels like you're walking through a gateway into Lisbon. You can get some good pictures here, especially on a sunny day. Also good connections to several trams/buses around the city (get the 15E tram from here to Mosteiro dos Jeronimos in Belem)

Pretty pictures . Right on the waterfront, this area is beautiful and busy. Great for pictures - check off that you were here in Lisbon. Lots of people around. We passed by in the day and it was busy. And we came back at about midnight and still lots of people hanging out near the water on the overlook.

Great opportunity for photos and a nice stroll.. You can get some great shots here and the architecture is beautiful. There's also a market that takes place selling lots of nice Portuguese gifts, and enough restaurants/cafes to choose from for snacks, deserts and cocktails.Remember your sunglasses as the white stone is very bright on a sunny day! (And this will hopefully deter the street sellers from trying to sell you some, incessantly!)
Perfect place to sit in the sun and enjoy drinks. Sea views, good selection of bars and restaurants and large drinks at reasonable prices all around. Perfect place to stop for a rest

Beautifull and huge. With diferent coffee places all arround the square and the river just in front, its a place to relax, easy access with the metro Terreiro do Paço you can make a walk until Cais do Sodré near the river and enjoy the view.

Lively central with amazing buildings and view to the waters. Flanked with historical buildings either side, really lively and interesting to see all the old shops and buildings leading to the gate on the waters. Nice walk with great views, not to be missed. Just avoid the touristy shops either side with overpriced menus.
Romantic. I can not even describe what i was feeling there. Amazing place, stunning place. You have a feeling that you a part of something huge and important, like a part of history.

Nice square with fascinating history. One of the city quarters you have to visit. The square were and still is a gate to the city. Read about the history of the Lisbon earthquake to understand how it is built...
Visit. Praca di Comercio is a nice place to visit during the day and during the night: magic! I really suggest to do not eat there... to expensive

Lively and central connect to all tour buses, trams. Lively and lovely. Crowded and tourists every where. Offers flavor of Lisbon. Beautiful seashore, near to Rossio and heart of Lisbon for connectivity.
The entire stretch of street offers much to tourists.
Must see!. It very beautiful and spacious, architecture is very interesting and you also have a breathtaking view to the water. Be sure not to miss it.

A must. It's one of the city benchmarks. Beautiful view of the river and the surrounding streets. It's not the cheapest place to eat or drink but you are in the city center. It's a great place to stroll around and take pictures.

Lisbon visit card - must be visited.. This square is the visit card of the city
Around the square are several ministery's headquarters. The Tagus River is just opposite. A place compulsory to visit. Always be aware of pickpockets. Your life is not at risk, the same can't be said about your wallet or other belongings.
city center. Beautiful and historical square in the heart of Lisbon, close to all destinations in the city with an amazing view to the Tagus river!

Stroll. Great place to walk and eat
Many stores to shop good prices and nice items
Good food choices no shortage of food
Great to explore

Nice Square In Central Lisbon. Praca do Comercio is a fairly large square not too far from the riverbank. The architecture around the place is quite impressive and you can see the castle that is on top of the hill. The area is next to the old district of Alfama so there is quite a bit of charm around the place.Nearby there are some fairly decent restaurants and souvenir shops.

Scenic Plaza in Lisbon. This plaza is the scene of a beautiful and ornate statue, as well as a commemorative arch. There are multiple restaurants if you are hungry. It's also down by the water, creating an even more picturesque setting. This is a great place to stop and take photos.

Important spot full of history. The Royal Palace used to be located there before t was entirely detroyed, as the rest of Lisbon by the 1775 earthquaque. This place used to be a departure point for the Portuguese descoveries and a major welcoming point for travellers or dignatiries arriving by boat. The statue in the middle represents king Joseph I who rebuilt Lisbon after the earthquaque
its like the kalverstraat in Amsterdam , but then much better !. its a touristy place and street and visited by many tourists , but it has its charm as well, and the void from the arc is excellent !

A MUST SEE PLACE ONCE IN LISBON, GREAT AND HUGE PLACE IN FRONT OF THE OCEAN.. My wife, our 10 years old kid and myself spent 2 nights in Lisbon in August 2016. We saw Praca do Comercio and must say that it is a place to be seen once in Lisbon ! The place is huge, large, interesting, animated and it is somehow like to be on Red Square in Moscow ! You must see and visit it at least once, not to have regrets ! Enjoy the photos I will add to my review and maybe see you there one day ;-).otterboris
Good accessible shopping, some good eats. You have mid price shopping pretty nice. Some nice eats but looks for them off the street. On the main avenue are more tourist traps.
Nice square. The setting on the waterfront makes this a little unusual and it is very large, but there is not much to do there really. Worth a look though.

Very busy and expensive. The commercial area is packed with those coming to Lisbon on cruise ships, which dock close by. There are lots of restaurants and shops with very high prices. There are some interesting places around the edges but the Commercial Zone was my least favorite parts of Lisbon. I recommend awareness of pickpockets.
Sunny square. Big and sunny square by the Tagus river. Perfect to rest and to have a meal or a drink at the bars available.
nothing special but worth a stroll and people watching. a few places to sit and eat or drink but a couple of beggars there when we went, so a bit off-putting
Big Square . On your way to downtown of Lisbon you can spot this big Square called Praça do Comércio. A nice spot for coffee and sunset.

Great light display. We visited this area several times during our 8 day stay. A great place to shop or just enjoy a spot of people watching while sampling the local ice cream. The light display, which used the Arch and buildings to the sides as screens, was an unexpected bonus enjoyed by all our group with ages ranging from 11 to 65+. So much to see and do in this area with the opportunity to explore at your own pace.
Busy central street. Worth too see as it have a climat of a old town with some nice sights including artist and a lot of shops
Absolute city center of Lisbon !. A walking area with many shops where you finally reach that arch and after that is the river.Great place but many tourists

A wonderful walk-through & shopping spree. We visited this area which was crowded with tourists all around. We had great time there viewing the splendid arch and the super large square. Shopping was also great with great prices. An opportunity not to be missed.
Beautiful. It was lovely just walking down the streets and seeing all the impressive arch. Such wonderful architecture and design.
Nice view of the city and the sea. The square is very large and you can find many streets activities. You are between the sea and the city. Some coffee and restaurants but it is quite expensive.

A lively street . Our hotel was located just one street beside this one. This is a street with lots of shops and a bunch of restaurants. Usually there are street performers doing just about everything from mariachi to juggling
Lively square. Definitely worth the walk about and take some photos of the river and bridge. Live bands playing and nice atmosphere just watch out for the drug pushers.

Fun area to hang out. Although touristy of course, this is a fun place to walk around and shop. Walk down to the riverfront on a sunny day and enjoy the sunshine, street performers and the entire ambiance. Also, think what it must have been like in 1755 when the earthquake and tsunami hit the area and you get a real sense of history of this area. The book, This Gulf of Fire, is a riveting account of this.

Relaxing in the city center. This "plaza" has everything a tourist could want: places to eat, including a beer museum (I recommend it), shops with souvenirs and weekend fairs. Nice place to sit in the afternoon :)
Nice square to relax. Nice place to walk, sit and watch people on a sunny dat! Easy to get with tram, metro or bus. Surroundgeluid by Nice restaurants where you can eat for normaal prices!

Must visit when you are in Lisbon. You won't possibly miss Praca do Comercio; I walked there from Rossio by the main road: Rua Augusta. You can find the tourist info center at Praca do Comercio and all kinds of transport at Praca do Comercio.
Nice photos. It is THE espalanada of the city. A central point to explore downtown. Also, a great location for takis photos.
Nice Plaza. Be prepared to walk around and visit a lot of shops and restaurants. This is the main attraction in town.

A large iconic city square. Praça do Comercio is a large open space in the centre of the Baixa area, built following the 1755 Lisbon Earthquake which pretty much flattened the city. The local name is Terreiro do Paço which is a reference to the royal palace which stood on the same land before the earthquake. Although a must see in Lisbon don't expect it to be a bustling square, though I understand it comes into its own when it hosts specific events. The restaurants/bars around the square are overpriced and best avoided. Plenty of nice places to eat and drink in the streets parallel to Rua Augusta. Places you must visit while at the square are the Tagus riverbank, Arco Triunfal da Rua Augusta (you can actually climb up to the top of it to take in the superb views) and Lisboa Story Centre (a multimedia/audiovisual museum which tells the story of city through the ages). We saw a small artisan's craft market here on the Monday and Tuesday during our stay. You can get the metro, buses, trams and taxis here.

Lisbon's Gem. Praça do Comércio or Terreiro do Paço is right next to the Tagus River in Lisbon. It's a great place for a walk and it's often a meeting point for me and my friends. It's a beautiful place in Lisbon and it's full of history too.
You Will Stumble Through. We walked through this area while headed to other areas. It is nothing special. I think we bought a pastry.
Good for Food and Shoping. Great. A long street with lots of traditional restaurants and shops for clothing, shoes, bags.Very friendly environments. Safe to walk.

Iconic place. Looks nice from the castle above the city. Down there afterwards I think I was a bit disappointed, maybe I was hoping to sit nicely somewhere right by the river but there was nothing such place right there, just some garbage. Still, it is a must see place and I am happy I was there.

A place that a tourist can't miss . Very busy and crowdedWalking in day time is different from walking in the night time Try snack , ice cream , coffee and pastries in the street Not a great place for shopping Don't miss the laser show near the seafront starting after 9pm in the evening

Visit@Praça do Comercio. This is a central square with beautiful monuments all around. It is a station to many means of public transportation,such as the metro,buses,electric 28,etc.. Also,there is the start of the beautiful rue de Augusta...

Tourist's Praça. Central point of the riverside and transport. There are several cafés and bars there serving snacks and drinks as well as coffee. Home to Lisbon Story Centre which is a great way of learning about the city's history.

Check out the Praca at night.. The light show projected on the building facing the square at night was fun!l the restaurantsame and street performanceso in the evening made for a wonderful atmosphere.

Lisbon at it's best. A beautiful and emblematic symbol of Lisbon and it's history. Facing the Tagus River with Arco da Rua Augusta at the opposite side of the square leading into a wide and stretchy street full of restaurants and shops. An emblem of Lisbon. Emblematic square of Lisbon where occasionally occurs spectacles and events, being a very busy tourist spot in the city of Lisbon. This square is very close to Baixa-Chiado, Restauradores and Avenida da Liberdade (no more than 5 minutes walking). The square is in front of the Tejo River, providing a beautiful view of the river, over 25 de Abril" bridge and also over the south of the Tejo river (Almada). The area has several restaurants, all them with terraces that allow for a relaxing break during the visit to Lisbon. The square is always clean and well maintained, however tourists should have special attention because they may be approached by drug dealers that usually target tourists. Near parking does not exist, advising to travel on foot.
Beautiful place. It is a huge square, with a lot os great restaurants, close to both the street of Gold and the one of Silver. You cannot miss it.

An uplifting experience . Right on the southernmost square of Lisbon's Tourist area, an impressive arch, Arco da Rua August straddles the main street leading up to the obelisk in Praça de Restauradores and the Avenida da Liberdade. You can take a lift up to a terrace viewpoint near the top and achieve good orientation views of downtown Lisbon to the north and of Praça do Commercio and the Tagus towards the 25 d'Abril Bridge and the statue of Christo Rei on the other side in Almada. Well worth a visit especially on a clear day.

Praca do Comercio. Before the earthquake (1755), it was the esplanade of the royal palace da Ribeira.Destroyed, it was decided to build a place that would symbolize the new Lisbon.It is lined with classical buildings of the eighteenth centuries and arcades. Lot of cafes, shops and restaurantsThis is one of the most beautiful square in the capital. Nice vew on the Tagus , the bridge 25 de Abril and on the figure of Cristo Rei. Very nice walk from Rossio to here

Old & New World Europe all in one!. Great place to just take in the environment of Lisbon at its best. Have an expresso or a fine meal (or an economic one - your choice) in this majestic square. Don't forget to go up to the top of the main archway (fee involved) for an outstanding view, then take a walk along the newly updated riverfront. Downtown shops of all kinds are adjacent!
Nice strall . If you want to do a stroll you may go to that area. There are lots of shops and restaurants. It more of the same but it nice.
Beautiful square. . Old , historic, beautiful. One cannot miss it. Right at the centre in Lisbon. Good place to hang out.

Good to jump from AC to AC. To be fair, the promenade is very nice and magnificent. The problem is that it is usually crowded as it is one of the well known shopping streets.Good the experience though.

Great place to see sites and sounds of Lisbon. This avenida is an excellent place to visit to enjoy the sites and sounds of Lisbon - grab a glass of port, do some shopping, and eat some local fair.
Iconic square . Best at sunset when crowds gather at the water's edge this is a beautiful square with elegant arched passageways framing it . Stunning !

Expensive to eat but great to see. This is in the heart of where Marques do Pombal rebuilt Lisbon after the earthquake. The shops are amazing, some of them are very cheap. The food/ice creams are expensive. Great to get information at the tourist both and of course on the evenings there is a wonderful projector show.
beautiful. Rua Augusta,i love this street and i have donbe that every day,there are some many person that do something to demostrate you how wonderful is the art.

The largest square in Europe. Surrounded on 3 sides by old, elegant buildings hosting Portugal ministries and on the south side by Tagus river, this is the largest square in Europe.The light is particularly intense and bright here.You can walk as far as the Tagus river and sit down for a sunbath. Two old columns are the only remains of the old royal palace that occupied the square before the 1755 earthquake.Recommended is to visit the Tourist Information Centre located under the archs at the western side of the square.From here, the view goes as far as the opposite coast and the bridge.

Party of 10. This is a very busy place by day and night. There are lots of shops and places to eat as well.
This such a buzzing place by night that will keep you entertained for the evening.
This is also so close to hotel Mundial which is about 15 minutes walk at a slow pace

Great place to stop and people watch. Lovely part of Lisbon with lots going on in the cafes and bars and shops. Lots of people selling selfie sticks though so just ignore. Lots of Music and buskers and great place to just stop and let the world go by.

Especially Bustling on a Weekend!. i love the bohemian feel to the place during the weekend when its bustling with a lot of local artsy and hand-made stalls from the marble sculptures, to stained glasses and leather works to trinkets of all kinds. The restaurants and cafe are especially filled with al fresco dining area ideal for just enjoying a good beer and bacalhau to be finished off with a yummy treat of pasties de nata. service personnel are extremely nice, although thrice we've been cautioned to hold on to our belongings since pick-pockets are rampant in the area. Beautiful space. Price do Comercio is a fantastic open space with beautiful architecture that feels like open-air museum sans arrogance. A great one to pass on your city walk and then head down one of the streets for a snack of codfish cake with cheese

A walk in Tagus River. you must take this walk that oversees Lisbon. Its located at the end of Avenida de Liberdade ,by the mini-shops and restaurants. You take an elevator and walk along the overpass. Its remarkable views of the town and its surroundings are spectacular

Lovely place. . I always love a crowded place that still looks neat and is still pleasing to the eyes. This place is good for photo ops. Great place to watch the world go by. This is a very beautiful square with shops and restaurants around it. There are places to buy ice cream and just enjoy watching life.

Commerce Square -Praca do Comercio. This Huge Square is located in the City of Lisbon near the Tagus river. It is still known as ' The Palace Yard' (Terreiro do Paco) because before the 1755 Lisbon earthquake it was the location of the Royal Ribeira Palace. King Manuel I built the Royal residence by the river outside the city walls. A Port was also in the area and administrative buildings that regulated trade between Portugal and it's colonies in Africa, Asia, Brazil and Europe. In 1755 the deadly earthquake, tsunami and consuming fire destroyed the Ribeira Palace, the buildings near the Tagus river and two thirds of the city of Lisbon, killing in excess of 90,000 people. It was a Calamity that set the fortunes of Lisbon back with the loss of many art treasures and books of the Palace Libraries. The Prime minister Marquis of Pombal under King Jose I press ganged Lisbon' survivors to rebuild the broken city. The Square was named Praca do Comercio to reinvent the new function of the square in relation to the commercial heritage of Lisbon and Portugal. In the centre ofthe square is an imposing Statue of King Jose I. The sculpture was worked by Machado de Castro of Coimbra. Maxhado was a master of many sculptures. The particular sculpture of the Square shows King Jose I on his horse crushing snakes on his path.

Lik. The Portuguese capital has a new venue for enjoying the city, Pátio da Galé, in Terreiro do Paço, featuring areas dedicated to food & beverage, leisure, culture and events.Situated in the west wing of Lisboa's most emblematic square, Pátio da Galé helps to promote the charm of the Portuguese capital as a tourist destination, presenting itself as an ideal place to experience the city.Like every Europeam capital, (Concord Paris, Grand Place Belgium etc) Lisbon has its grand circles. Praço do Comercio is the one in Lisbon. Inside Patio da Gale, thereare two restaurants - the Aura and the Terreiro do Paço. There are also terraces, icecream parlour, exhibitions and cultural events around. It is a big circle and beautiful summer nites there is a big screen TV. It was time of Eurocup, was excellent place to watch the final with France. From time to time there is also stage and live music. The best thing about the place is it is by the Tejo river, you can walk along the bank, or sit by the river. It is a good bank for promenade there are cafes that sell snacks and drink along the way. If you walk like 10-15 minutes you can reach Cas de Sodre train station from where you can take the train to the most popular summer towns of Lisbon: Estoril and Cascais. Along the way, the estuary of river Tejo ends where the train follows the route by the Atlantic. Cascais is the terminal a town worth seeing and visiting for a day to pass at the shores of Atlantic Ocean.

The link between the city and the Tajo !. It's a most see in Lisbon ! the square is perfectly situated in the centre of the most popular districts and the Rio Tejo which offers a very good view especially at Sunrise/Sunset.

It's a big European city square (No imagination needed) - Lots of broken glass post Euro celebrations . It's nice but there are other nicer squares / places in major European cities. Loads of broken glass post Euro 2016 celebrations that needs to be cleaned up.

A Special Place in Lisbon. This is the heart of Lisbon. Although its only a large open square this is where Lisbon residents go to watch event like the recent Portugal victory in the Euro Cup futebol championship. You can catch the Hills Tram Tour here, find a beer museum and various cafes along the edges of the square.

Praca do Comercio. This river front square was formally the area where ships would dock and sell their cargoes.  A statue of King Jose 1st on his horse is the center piece. On this monument the horse is meant to be symbolic of triumph stomping on snakes representing evil or perhaps Protestants ( you decide ). The elephants stand for the Portuguese empires colonies in Africa and India. The arch here is Lisbon's Arch of Triumph with Vasco de Gama on the left and Pompal on the right. Other than those monuments, there is not much here.

With fantastic views both the river and the whole of Lisbon it would be a great miss.

Rich with history. Beautiful architecture on a gorgeous streey paved in marble that leads you to a river w/ views of the city and the square has an impressive statue. Lisbon is a beautiful city w/ very nice people inhabiting this big capitol city.

Drink in the atmosphere. Repays several visits at different times of day and night, and the proportions and colours of the square are always pleasing on the eye. Claims to have the world's sexiest toilet in one corner, whatever that can mean - and it'll cost you a euro to find out.

The place was nice but being approached by every individual while passing by gets quite irritating at some point. Beautiful area to enjoy a walk in Lisbon. I was so impressed with Lisbon, but this area has the wow factor... Loads of lovely restaurants skirt the square and it is a great place to sit and have a coffee, ice-cream or meal.

Lovely. Excellent place to walk, browse and generally soak up the atmosphere. The only downside is the waiters touting for business, there are so many to choose from. Don't get 'bullied' into eating/drinking where you don't want to.

One of the most beautiful in the world. "Praça do Comércio" more known by "Terreiro do Paço", is a large square down town Lisbon, by the river Tagus.Traditional local of Portuguese Kings, today is occupied by Government Ministeries, luxury hotels, terraces, restaurants, etc. It is one of the largest squares in Europe.It has always been the noble entrance of Lisbon, visited by Heads of State and Kings and Queens, like Isabel II from UK. In April 25th 1974 the square assisted to our "Revolution" that put aside the dictatorship. In 2010 Pope Bento XVI celebrated a mass with about 280.000 people present.This square is blessed for those who want to believe in a different world, a world of peace and beauty, a world where you respect the past to protect the future. This is my square! My wife and I visit it every single week,

There are also many restaurants and shops nearby so you can hang around for a while. The large open plaza is quite impressive and you can go back in time after learning about the history of the area and imagining it filled with merchants selling exotic spices and animals brought over on the ships.
Nice square with a lot of things going on. Theres lots to see here, beer museum, the arch which you can go to the top of. A nice coastal walk , its near a few nice restaurants as well

Very nice. Absolutely worth visiting!!! Exciting and sitting drinking a beer is highly recommended. Close to the river offers a good view.

Main Street . This is a very charming street closed to traffic. It was one block from our apartment. It has plenty of shops and restaurants and leads down to the river. We had cappuccino here every morning and there are a number of bakeries along the way.
Beautiful Old Lisbon. This is what you have come to see. The place is throwing with people and places where you can part with your money, so enjoy...

Lovely architecture. The architecture in Lisbon is simply stunning and walking around these streets is the perfect example. The arch is a perfect monument at the end of the street and there is a plaque that tells you about the history of it. Careful on the marble - it's slippery!

Architect and cobblestone filled stress with many street performers.. A good example of the famous architecture and cobblestones Portugal is famous for. Lots of tourist friendly shops and restaurants. Plenty of street performers trying to attract your attention and money.
Beautiful archway. Everywhere you go there is beautiful architecture and stonework. Look upwards in Lisbon and there's lots to see.

An Impressive Journey to the River. It's busy, but at the end you get to the Arch, then you're onto the Royal Square and then a half hour watching the life of the River Tagus - always my first stop off point in the city
Beautiful walk. We had a wonderful time exploring this area. We walked through and found many wonderful shops and cafes. It did not disappoint.

Large open plaza in Lisbon. Praca do Comercio, also referred to as Palace Square is a large open plaza in the south side of the city along the bay near the mouth of the Tagus River. This was the site of the Royal Palace until it was relocated to Sao Jorge in the early 16th century. At that time, the area became the gateway to Lisbon for those arriving by sea and a location of commercial and state activity. Today, you can see symmetric and arcaded buildings on the north, east and west sides of Praca do Comercio, these are painted yellow and are quite attractive. Amongst the buildings are a handful of restaurants with alfresco seating. We found a open market with falls selling handmade goods and other interesting items in the arcades along the north side of the plaza during our visit. Not sure if this is held year round or only for summer months. There are also a couple of museum attractions; Museum of Lisbon: Torreao Poente and the Story of Lisbon and a centre monument to King Jose I which is quite attractive to view. The Arco de Rua Augusta monument on the north end of the square is also a rather appealing structure worth viewing while you are at Praca do Comercio.During our visit, the large plaza was hosting a EURO 2016 event, with large screen TV, seating, foosball and Carlsberg stands for those interested in watching tournament games. This was a great way to spend some time at Praca do Comercio, for football fans and general tourists alike. Note: You can visit Praca do Comercio conveniently by walking down Rua Augusta or by way of several trams that stop here while transversing across Lisbon.

"Gateway to ancient Lisbon". This huge arcaded square, dominated by the statue of Dom Jose, king of Portugal following the great earthquake of 1755, was once the premier entry to riverfront Lisbon. It was the site of a former royal palace, but today serves the city as a popular meeting and entertainment center and also the ferry departure port across the estuary to Barreiro on the opposite bank of the Tagus.
Must see. Very cool area. I felt like I was in a European San Francisco. Hills, hills and more hills. transportation was inexpensive though and we used it a lot.
A whistle stop tour.. We took a tram to see the local sights and were amazed to see much of everything we needed to do this way.

Cool area to walk around and check out.. Lots of shops and restaurants in this area including a mall. Very tourist oriented. Lots of neat buildings to look at and a great place to people watch. There are beggars and drug pushers here.

Beautiful Place to Walk. Really beautiful area of Lisbon. You have to walk around this area when you go to Lisbon. It's also really nice to go sit on the waterfront and relax for a bit and look at the harbour area.Definitely a must see in Lisbon.
Lovely . This was lovely it is right down by the water. It looks beautiful from the ground, unfortunately we did not go up to have a view from the top

Fan friendly. We recently visited Lisbon and found not only this beautiful area but the Carlsberg Euro lounge. Buildings and architecture was stunning and a great location for public events. Short walk to either beach or city centre. Plenty to see or do only downside forever being offered "substances" that's no fault of location but bear in mind for family visits.

This is the place to be if you like street artists and terraces. We went here on a Sunday, walked towards it along the "Tejo". (The River Tague, which is impressive too)
Very busy, touristic, but friendly.
Market stalls with art, food and drinks.
The buildings are impressive.

Iconic. This is a beautiful and monumental French-style square.It was built in the 18th century to glorify the monarchy. Present day it remains a glorious, not to be missed place in Lisbon. Its riverside location gives it even more appeal. It has lots of shops, restaurants, cafes etc but my favorite part is the history and the architecture and monuments.

Must see on a good wx day- but won't take long . This is the heart of Lisbon that dates in its current architecture to the mid to late 18th century thanks to the big earthquake of 1755. It is fun to imagine the world explorers of days past either launching from or arriving back to a plaza similar to this one. There is much to do from this central location...views of the fort on the hill above, the far shore, the bridge, the cross on the far shore, and all the other sights. This is a good spot to start a walking tour of Lisbon.

Touristic highlight. A lot of people trying to sit you down in their commercial restaurants where the atmosphere and portugese are absent. The view towards te River Tague is magnificent, but any other street will also take you to the grand square.

Do not miss it!. That's part of the old Lisbon where modern life mixes with old times. Walk through the arch and marvel at the architectura and the view of Tejo river. Pay attention to the cobblestone streets and enjoy a "cafe " in one of the multiple outdoor "esplanades"....do not forget to eat the traditional "pastel de nata"...
The Hub of Lisbon.. Lots of shops, restaurants, cafes and bars. All tourists head here and it is very busy. Street artists are very good,

Impossible to miss!. Praca do Commercio is the center of town. It is the gateway to the most awesome pedestrian street with great food, shops, people. We were there when the Plaza was home to the soccer viewing - loads of fun.

Nothing special but will inevitably become part of your daily route . This did become the route of mine most days to find new excursions, however, there was nothing much special about it. It was clouded by the fact that Euro 2026 had completely taken over the main square, that was quite an atmosphere as Portugal won the match at the time, but without that, it is beautiful and the architecture is stunning, just not really a lot to do. I don't think it warrants being so high up in the 'things to do' list
Fun to Wander. Great restaurants and people watching. The shops are fun to wander in and out and it is architecturally interesting.

Tourist Mecca. While this area is filled with well preserved buildings that are a 'must see,' I was disappointed with the fact that there were quite a large number of people hawking (be it restaurants, goods, photos, etc.), but I guess that is to be expected as this is one of the most popular tourist spots in Lisbon.

The heart of town, where commercial deals have been completed. Rua Augusta will lead to the Square and them to the Targus river. It is not so pompous as the well-known squares of Paris but gives a good impression of the historical times. It is spacious and decorated in the middle with a very nice monument of the King Jose I. This is the place of big people gatherings, as for the fans of the Portuguese national football team, who watch the matches on a huge monitor. Unfortunately a good river embankment was found missing, and it all makes the place not very memorable, just for a time.

Beautiful historic place. Lots of things happened here. Too much to write here. Go to the Lisbon Story Centre (on the east side of the praça) to learn everything.The monument in the center is impressive.Unfortunately, the square is often used for events as the diffusion of the Euro 2016 which spoils the beauty of the place.

Did I miss something?. There wasn't much here to see it do. There's a statue. And and arch. It's by the river. Due to Eurocup the area had a huge screen setup right by the statue so no matter what it was in your photos. Wasn't too happy about that. But really not much to do or see

Wonderful History. This was very interesting and I went back about 3 times over the course of the week, both to experience the history as well as t people watch. Take your time through here as there are many treasures worth discovering on your own.
Terreiro do Paco. Full of life and magnificent views to the south side of the river, major link routes to everywhere in Lisbon. Lovely restaurants to just sit down and enjoy.

Busy, Bustling area but some great sights. Pros- many different shops, bars, restaurants and nice buildings along the way, great architecture.Cons- street merchants, loud, traffic, watch out for pickpockets (like in any tourist city). There are many tourists walking around the area, but also a lot of tour buses, Tuk-Tuks and cars. Also with the Euro championships ongoing you got the big Carlsberg Public Viewing lounge blocking the statue in the middle of the open square. THIS IS VERY POOR Planning, I love soccer and watching the games but that is something that should have been avoided.

Yeah, sure, you may as well do the walk.. Walking from Rossio square down Rua Augusta towards the water on a summer day is pleasant enough. The atmosphere created by the presence of the numerous tourists has a, well, touristic feel to it. There are shops and many outdoor restaurants on this and parallel streets. Sadly, the food is mostly unimpressive, with the typical, very ordinary Portuguese fare showing little variation amongst the establishments. If you can find a place that serves Cataplana (seafood) and if they happen to do it reasonably well, you will have something noteworthy. Otherwise, my own preference is to stick with grilled fish, as this rarely fails. Caldeirada can also be good, whereas EVERY seafood rice I've ever had came watery, and nowhere near what one should expect given the description. But I digress...At the end of the street you are at a very large square - Praca do Comercio, where you can take some reasonable photos. Immediately on the other side of the square you are by the water, where people congregate just to hang out a bit. When the water level permits, some souls take to the mini beach thus exposed and wet their feet to cool off a bit.There is nothing strikingly remarkable about the entire walk, but as a tourist it is something you should see, as it does reflect some of what makes this country what it is/was.
Great area to visit. This is a nice area to visit. Great architecture. Beautiful buildings and nice to see. It's a nice spot for a quick visit unless you want to shop or eat at the local spots.

Arch of elegance. Some beautiful architecture in this stretch of Lisbon, close to the water. Excellent place to take a few snaps, people watch...and maybe a glass of chilled white wine or two in the square.

Busy chaotic shopping area...but many options. There are many umbrella-covered cafe tables set in the center tiled area with many shops and eateries on the side. There are street performers here and you can spend 1-2 hours or simply pass through. You can also walk through the arches and reach the beach. When I was here, they had a large viewing stadium to watch the European soccer finals. The plaza is easy to find so was a good way to regain your bearings as you walk to the city and use it as a point of reference for other places you want to visit. One of the businesses here is a bank that has a Museum of archaeology where you can see some Roman ruins ...try to find that ... that's pretty cool

Plenty of shops / restaurants / cafe's etc .... This was a very busy place (do watch for pick pockets). It was a lovely place with plenty of shops (etc) before the large square offering some peace & quiet & walks.

blah...and boring. It is a boring place not like the piazzas in Italy or France..There are no flowers(no colour ) in sight in a country full of tropical plants.I will write the same review for all Lisbon attractions...Tired looking buildings, unloved old historical structures,shabby old downtown neighbourhoods...Clearly overrated city...

Boring center of Lisbon with typical touristy restaurants and shops. Generally a very boring central part of Lisbon with cafes and restaurants selling food at very high prices compared to local prices but with mediocre standard. Nice looking architecture but probably worth only. 10 minutes of your time.
A huge square!. A great square full with cafe's and restaurants near to the seaside... We watched a big military ceremony during the day and a great concert at night! An unforgettable place!

A good place for people watching. A large square with a view of the Targus river. It is centrally located where one can catch the trams or the buses to Alfama or to the other districts in Lisbon. It is also surrounded by cafes where one can stop to rest before heading to the other Lisbon sites.
Lovely but very commercial higher prices. Nice for stroll along front and see the river pretty location go get the ferry over to Christo Rei really worth it

Pass through the arch!. This beautiful spot is home to the Rua Augusta Arch and many decent bars and restaurants.The Arch is a must as it gives an awesome lakeside view of the city (though every spot in Lisbon is a great vantage point).We had the chance to enjoy the Fan Zone (during the Euro 2016) and had a nice moment along with some fun activities.

Great Shopping and Outdoor Dining. This is a great place to people watch, shop for souvenirs (never pat asking price), and have some tapas or bocadillos on one of the many outdoor cafes/restaurants. Great place to stroll.

Lots of activities in this area. When we visited there was a lot going on, Euro 2016 games shown on a giant screen (not just the Portugal games) and many other activities. In addition, the streets leading to the praca have lots of restaurants and cafes, mainly on rua Augusta. Warning: there are pickpocketers in the area looking for distracted tourists

Meh. This is the huge square at the bottom of the pedestrian street (Rua Augusta). It's next to the water. Nothing much to it. Just a big open space with tons of people. While we were there they did have a great set up there for viewing the Euro Cup games. Other than that, this is just another square.
A walk to the Rio Tejo. Our first day we walked down flights of stairs , winding our way down to the river. One great way is to walk through Terreiro do Paco. Amazing site

Praca do Comercio. What a magnificent square. It is not a place to miss on your visit to Lisbon. Wander around and feel the ambience and sit down at one of the restaurants for a drink or a meal and enjoy.

A lot to do there. You have almost everything in the Praca or in the vicinity. We went to the beach - a lot of rocks but nice sand. A concert scene was being installed in the center- perhaps for the Celebration of Lisbon national day. And we tried one of the tens of terraces and restaurants on the side.

Great for people watching. If there is one place to watch the diversity of visitors that come to this city....that is Praca do Comercio! If you are into wine, make sure to visit the shop of Wines of Portugal, you will find a great selection of wines from all over the country.

The ancient entry in Lisbon. Some decades ago, if you arrived in Lisbon by boat, this was the grand entry into the city: it was called the Quay of the Columns and so much happened there. People should try to look at old paintings or photographs to understand its grandeur, a plaza completely opened to the river and to reflect the sun's light, as in a mirror, from the white buildings around. Today it's a place where you can sit and enjoy a drink or quick bite in any of the restaurants which are a recent development. Nevertheless, S. Martinho in the Arcade is a restaurant that belongs to an older Lisbon and tells stories of writers and artists who frequented it. Not to be missed, if you enjoy knowing about wine, the place, on the right hand of the Arcades (facing the river), where you can buy a card and taste,inexpensively, some top wines directly from the producers.

Great Square perfect for people watching. Huge area looking out onto the river with lots of restaurants around it to sit in the shade with friends and watch the world go by. the museum of beer does lots of different beers and is avoid spot
Great for shopping. Very nice areas. Lots of restaurants. Shopping good in this area. Great spaces near the river. Well worth a visit.

EURO CUP AND MUSIC. Free big screen Euro Cup futbal (soccer) and fusbal! A must-see after you stroll down the promenades from the upper plazas to this plaza on the river. Beautiful setting among Lisbon’s older buildings. They are showing the Euro Cup on the big screen and there is nothing like watching good futbal in Europe outside with real fans. Later, the screens turned to American music and while the videos were not always family friendly, the crowd kept it clean and cool. We saw young kids and old geezers, black, white, and brown, from countries all over the world enjoying some heavy beats at river-side. Great weather this time of year, and great fun after a long day walking!
Pedestrial Street. This pedestrian street is a fun place to shop, people watch and get a snack, coffee or beer; at the end near the Arch you will find the Museum of Design.

Lovely plaza, with great views over the river and architecture. One can't really go to Lisbon and not visit this fabulous square and the bottom of the main shopping street, Rua Augusta. The views over the river are spectacular enough, but I notice that people online are puzzled by the Latin inscription on the arch. It's some time since I did Latin, but I make it as follows:Virtutibus maiorum ut sit omnibus documento - P[ecunia] P[ublica] D[ictatum]Major virtues, that they may be a lesson to all – Dedicated at the pubic expense.The figures on top ar Glory, dressed as a woman of Ancient Greece and holding laurels crowns over Valour (an Amazon) and Genius (who has a stature of Jupiter being his left arm.Enjoy!

Main square of Lisbon; can't miss. When visiting Lisbon, you can't miss out on the main square of the city. It is not my favourite place for sitting on the terrace, but it is spacious and well-maintained and beautiful with the great gate standing on one side. Also great start point for a stroll along the river. The sides of the square are lined with market stands and terraces.

Impressive. This square/area is quite large, particularly considering the built up neighbourhood surrounding it. Shows how expensive it must have been. There is a nice place to watch the water (with buskers and the like around) and cafes (although pricey) around the edge. There are also people peddling drugs and the like here so be on guard.

Great place to shop eat and relax. The square near the river is hustling bustling with tourists and locals and the road only for padestrians leads upto restaurados city centere with shops and restaurants on both sides.

Nice Walk. Beautiful area to walk around historically and architecturally. Places to stop and have a meal or espresso. The square was quite busy when I was there. Large screen TV placed in the centre for soccer matches- took away the ambiance but understandably important to have so all can watch and celebrate the Euro cup.

One of the best places in Europe. Nice square. It has a nice gate. There are archs in three parts because there is not any buiding in the riverside. Nice terraces to take coffe or drinks (very turistic) and not cheap.

Walking place. I walked through this place after getting down from the metro station. A far view of the 25 de Abril bridge and the square where I could see a large screen placed, probably for the football matches and other events. Had taken a walk from here to the cathedral and the Jorge castle. A great walking experience.
Portugal and its history.. Great place to walk. There are many places to eat. Local history is very rich. very pleasant walk. There are always many people visiting.

10/10 would walk through again. Good range of shops here and lots of outdoor cafes. And just off is the santa Justa elevador. We found a very cool bakery/coffee shop with the best chocolate croissants I've had. Super cheap and quick service just eating at the counter. The only thing is the people trying to ferry you in their cafes.. One guy nearly blew his top trying to get people to his resturant.But 10/10 would walk up through again.
Lisbon's downtown. Your trip to Lisbon wouldn't be complete without visiting the square and plazas around it. I always go there whenever we are in Lisbon

To market to market. A place to party and where there are often various side acts like live music performers or a big screen to watch sports events Good variety of restaurants all around the praca and great view of the river
Lisbon's Finest Street. The arch, the beautiful buildings and street lanterns were all so impressive, but the highlight for me was the walkway, which was marble with incredible designs.

Must see . This is one of the best places in Lisbon. Very nice place to wander through the streets, look at the people, so some shopping, watch people, and enjoy the street performers. Watch out for the men trying to sell you sunglasses. They are really drug dealers and pick pockets.

People watching and more.. This magnificent, spacious Praca is ideal for people watching. There are nice terraces which serve excellent food and drinks. Do not forget to visit the Arch. An elevator brings you to the top where you can see an amasing view of Lisbon.
Great Place. This is one of the highlights to visit in Lisbon. A very unique place to visit. This square has lovely views of the river and a nice atmosphere , lots of tourists, restaurants and shops.
Main old shopping boulevard. A boulevard central to Lisbon city, probably used to be the main street when the Roman built the gate to the city. Rebuilt after 1755 earthquake

Beautiful public square. This square was probably one of my favourite places in Lisbon. It is so picturesque and stunning with its old architecture. As was explained to us on a tour of the city, the statue in the middle of the square is supposed to be the former King of Portugal who turned his back on the city and that is why he is facing the water, as if running away.
Nice for visit not to shop/dine. Interesting area where you can see the rebuilt Lisbon after the 1755 earthquake. Don't fall into the tourist traps though!
busy, lively place to walk around. Great place to walk around, with lots of restaurants and shops to chose from. Lots of street music and great architecture to see.
Marvelous, historic and lively walking area you are sure to enjoy!. Walking tour allows for exploration, shopping and snacking in a beautiful area vibrant and alive with activity.

The View. My second time in Lisbon and it feels like home. Walking on this square, there is so much to see. It is very spacious and beautiful. Love the architecture, ideal for Instagram or Snapchat. And very romantic because it's near the river.
Feel Lisbon. I think it is one of the most amazing and full of life streets in Lisbon, full of street art performances, smells of portuguese and international cousine and breath taking views

end of Lisbon shopping and beginning of Tejo river. when you're done with shopping and drinking coffee you inevitably find yourself crossing the busy street and getting to Praca do Comercio....en keep walking so you can rest on the side of river Tejo. if still in need of shopping, museum of coffee you can find it here....

Nice shops, and good beer. . I bought some porcelain dishes which I can cherish for a long time now. The malls and coffee shops are very helpful for a photographer like me. I needed cards to buy and got them easy.
Amazing architecture.. Came across this building whilst exploring the city. Appreciated the intricate design and scale of it. Picture - worthy! Travelled April 2015

One of the most beautiful places in the world. Its conception, the fact of being by the Tagus, its amplitude, all these surprise the visitor. A nice place to stroll around, to eat at one of the several restaurants around the square, to take your time. Many celebrations, parties, special occasions take place there. A place full of history and of beauty.
Nice view. It is surrounded by old buildings. In the middle there is a large monument and one side is the river . It is relatively quiet place .

Nice place, central location. I guess you can't miss this square when in Lisbon. You can sit and enjoy the view of the river and then take a stroll up the main shopping street and enjoy shops and restaurants.

Must see in Lisbon . I've seen it during day and during night. It's kind of special during night because of those amazing lights.
I've been happy because in front of it was Portuguese's army concert - THEY WERE AMAZING!
Must see place in Lisbon!

Nice view and place to walk. A very nice place to see, take pictures and history from Portugal, very close to other attractions. Try to get on the top of the Arch of Rua Augusta you will get a greater view from Lisbon.
