Worth seeing if you like...big squares and statues.. Little to do, but worth seeing once. Save your money and don't eat or drink on the square. Many better options nearby.

An amazing urban square. What surprises me on this, my first visit to Lisbon, is the monumental scale of the city. This square, with one side open to the river (the Tejo), is huge, symmetrical and stately, with extremely tall, shady (important on a sunny summer day) arcades on three sides, with cafés and restaurants of the most varied types, several of great historical importance.

Heart of the City Waterfront. This is the main square in Lisbon fronting onto the river and offers excellent views across the estuary. The buildings are well worth the walk as is the waterfront where there is often a cruise ship in dock as well as a number of Bars & Cafes

Great place for people watching. This is a great place for having an espresso, coffee with a pastrie or a refreshing drink and relax in people watching. The plaza is quite large and has many restaurants and cafe

Nice square. It's usually a very crowded place with lots of turists and locals where you can go shopping, have a drink or something to eat. I also noticed that you have many opportunities for a city tour: by tram, by bus, by tuk-tuk (an interesting means of transportation), by bike and even by segway! Everyone is very helpful and you can also enjoy the view of the ocean at the end of the street.
Beautiful place!. Lots of shops and restaurants, but watch your pocket books. Like in any large city there are pickpockets everywhere, but despite that we always felt safe.
Lots of good cafes and restaurants plus shops. It is nice to sit out at one of the many cafes, drink coffee and eat natas - traditional Portuguese pastries and possibly the best thing ever invented.
A nice place on a sunny day. Magnificent square, a place to sit and enjoy the view after a long walk, metro, tram, water shuttle and bus are nearby..

Absolutely beautiful.. This is one of the most beautiful areas in Lisbon and any other city. We stayed in Lisbon for four days and loved walking along the main streets down to the square and all the way to the water, even in the rain. Could not get enough of the place.
Impressive architecture. Just another of the amazing sites of Lisbon. No matter in which direction one walks, up and down, sideways and straight, the views are always special..
GOOOOD. City cetre. Good place to relax. Walk from baxia chiado to cais de sodre. Story center lisbon should be checked out as well.
downtown shopping. bought some fab shoes here, not too crowded.Street artists. visited Paul Patisserie for Tea and pastry
When you go to sea coast . Very simbolic, nice to take pic from street but nothing very special. Good to go thru but not destination
Fun place . I like this place! Had a lots of restaurants and shops ! Great spot for selfie and pictures lovers! I really enjoyed walking around
Fun Saturday afternoon shopping. . About 70% of the shops where open Saturday afternoon. Same for the restaurants. Bought stylish and comfortable Portuguese made shoes for 48 euros.

A peaceful esplanade to rest your tired feet. A place to remember whether its day or night , it has its beauty and hive of activity. Lots of open air cafe around and beautiful esplanade by the calm and serene sea surrounded by the unque city lifestyle at the inner end. You can get nice photo shots here and enjoy the cool spring sea breeze. The sea gulls flying in the wind with the deep blue sky background really satified my dreamed imagination. You can walk around the area to hunt for soveniours and very Portuguese art and handycrafts. The hop on and off coaches stops are nearby and making it convenient for tourists on free and easy holidays.

one of the many stunning and not to be missed sights in lisbon. when you walk along the pedestrian only street towards the Tagus river you can see the ornate triumphal arch in the distance. It was completed in 1875; it's massive and impressive as you get closer and approach the Praca do Comercio. Along the way there are many upscale shops, tons of restaurants and patisseries (places along the side streets are mostly less expensive).The plaza is huge. After the 1755 earth quake the square of completely remodeled. In the center is the statue of King Jose I (1775).All along the Praca are more restaurants that lend themselves well for people watching.

Gorgeous and imposing square. Perfect place to start exploring Alfama with a great perspective on castelo São Jorge from the river and easy access to the pedestrian shopping streets of Rua Augusta (leading to Rossio), the tram 28 line and also a great view of the River and Almada (south bank)

Great huge outdoor square at the side of the River Tagus. A large U shaped square regarded as the gateway to Lisbon, this was the main commercial hub of the city called ‘ the square of commerce’, where centuries ago wealth was brought to the city from far off countries such as Africa, Asia and America.The site of the former Royal Palace of Ribeira unfortunately totally destroyed in the 1755 earthquake, in those days this area developed as a portThis huge open square is filled with masses of tourists and a dry and sunny day, taking photo’s, drinking coffee, people watching, if you go right to the very edge of the square and just across the road you will find a very small beach on the side of the River Tagus.In the centre is the bronze statue dedicated to a King in Lisbon, was designed by Joaquim Machado de Castro, Portugal's foremost sculptor of the time, notice the unusual animals around the base.Great people place on a sunny day.
Cant miss this place . You will definitely find this square if you happen to be in Lisbao. Very lively but stormed with tourists at times. From here you can take walking tour to Chiado or Alfama.

Leads on to Praca Comercio. This is an interesting street with shops, patisseries and restaurants. At one end is the Arco Vitoria shown in the photograph, which leads onto the large square Praca Comercio andf down to the waterfront of Rio Tejo.

Shopping street . Pedestrians street. Easy to go it is right in the centre of Lisboa. Care full to the drugs dealer and pickpocket. You can do shopping and having food. But I will recommend not to eat in those places, tourist trap.

Impressive Praca and Views. The place is immense and impressive just for size alone. It sits at the bottom of the main pedestrian street lined with shops and restaurants. It's right on the water and even has a small sand beach. Another do not miss Lisbon site.

Great Street for Restaurants and Shops. This is a great place to wander through and soak up the atmosphere. Browse through all the shops and stop to get some good traditional food at one of the many restaurants.

Shopping street with lots of restaurants and lots of places to explore nearby. This is the main heart of new Lisboa , nice to window shopping and lots of touristic restaurants.We found food was costly in most of these touristic restaurants and finally end up eating in "Vitamins" restaurant which was healthy and wide variety of food.Better to visit during evening times and if you're lucky you may come across street performances.Also do visit nearby streets around this main street, there are some really nice and hidden shops.

Beautiful historic centre where you can take the tram to Belém. If you take the train into the old historical centre of Lisbon one of the first sites you see coming down the steps into the centre is beautiful. Walk through to the Augusta Street Arch and you'll find yourself in a huge square that opens up to the Tagus River; it's a beautiful place for you to take pictures. If you're thinking of taking a day trip to Belém, you can easily take either tram 15 or 127 boarding just in front of the arch in the square, and stop as soon as you see the Jeronimos Monastery. As this place is very popular with tourists, make sure to take care of your belongings! Even the taxi drivers passing by at red lights warned my family of pickpockets and to wear our backpacks at the front.

Great pedestrian street with an incredible arch.. This was a great pedestrian shopping street with beautiful buildings on either side leading to the stunning arch and statue on the water. Loved this area of the city.
Walk with ease. Enjoy this part of the city soak up the atmosphere and browe arund stop of coffee, beer or wine, relax in this place

Great for people watching. Get a table at one of the many squareside restaurants. Just enjoy the sun, food and drink. Everyone gravitates towards the square and the beaches. The Metro station for the blue line is right there as well as the ferries and rhe buses and trams. Perfect.

Beautiful and lively!. Located to the immediate south of the Rua Augusta Arch, this lively massive waterfront square is lined with classical buildings now housing many shops and cafes. The main tourist office is located here. A short and easy walk to the west takes you to the Time Out Mercado da Ribeira, a farmer's market and food hall.
Typical European Square. If you are in the vicinity worth having a look. Some picture opportunities. Much more interesting places to spend your time in Lisbon.

Huge Square with a Great View of the Sea. This square is massive and empty except for the statue in the middle. The sides are lined with restaurants and shops however, and it is a lot of fun to just wander through the hilly and twisty streets. Lots of good lunch choices.

Brilliant Place. So much to see and do in this area. It really is a hub for tourists to Lisbon but that doesn't mean you can't experience life like a local there.
I enjoyed sitting in a small cafe and soaking up the atmosphere and watching the world go by. A very enjoyable afternoon in a historically charming place.
AMAZING EXPERIENCE!. If you like to walk and see, this is the place to visit theirs are restaurants, bakery, coffee house, shops something for everyone.

Sea veiw square. Great massive square with its amazing arch that draws you towards it like a magnet. Through this triumphal arch is the trendy street of Rua Augusta with its mosaic floor that eventually leads to Rossio square with its fountains and statues and amazing patterned mosaic floor that gives an illusion of waves or ridges. Praca do Comercio is best reached by metro station Terreiro do Paco. The square does have a lot of street sellers. Also there is a huge statue of King Jose I in the square. You will see everyone taking pictures and selfies.
Good time to spend. Good restaurants and street performances . Must visit if you are in Lisbon. we as a family enjoyed this location
A must. The core os Lisbon for turists. Beatiful. There you'll find tourist office, tram stops to go to other turistic places, metro station, all.
Beautiful!. Beautiful square, wonderful view (river, bridges...) A few restaurants with sea food and local vine.
Fantastic square and harbour views. . A must see spot to tick off and take some great photos. Beautiful palace buildings surround this square, and the harbour looks terrific from this view point.

Lots to see. This whole area is steeped in history and has some wonderful buildings. Lots of street cafes nearby where you can just sit and watch the rest of the world go by. Good evening restaurants in the square too. It can be busy, trams and buses whizzing past, there was a segway tour when we were there last week, beware, these things can be dangerous when people get on them for the first time!
Impressive monument . This was awesome an archway to the rest of Lisbon. Majestic monument overlooking the Square and the Tagus Much activity trams and bus and restaurants

Wonderful! . It's touristy, but hey so were we. My little ones really enjoyed the living statues and it was a great place for a gelato and people watching. Beware of the homeless population near the fountain area.

The widest square in Europe, a marvellous place!. Everything in this square is wonderful: the Architecture, the Tejo River view, the fresh breeze and the history that is all around! Nice (expensive) restaurants all around and the Statue of King D.José - the one that was ruling Portugal when the Earthquake of 1755 destroyed the city of Lisbon! Also in this square was assassinated Portugal's last King (D. Carlos I) and the heir to the Throne (Prince D. Luis Filipe).... a place full of history!

The place to start your exploring of Lisbon.. This is an impressive arch that connects the port to the commercial part of the city. Walk right under the arch and up Rua do Comercio. Notice how the patterns made with black and white cobble stones change. This use of coloured cobble stones is unique to Lisbon.

High grade shopping, and many cafes and places to eat.. Take in much of the feel of this beautiful city, fronted by the Lisbon gate to the city. This heads onto a huge open square and the river, and is simply stunning. Again much begging and drugs being offered around, so say a firm "No", and enjoy the places around, turning off into the small streets, Explore here and around on foot!
A street for a stroll. Some streets are just for strolling down - and this is a 'must' for that. Lovely architecture, good shops, witha wonderful vista in either direction. Don't be in a rush.

Loved it looks amazing. Awesome to walk through the arch and see the architecture. I loved the fact you walk down and then you see the arch with the clock on the top. Very iconic and is really in the center. When visiting Lisbon very difficult to miss.
Iconic Lisbon. It's not out of this world but your picture of Lisbon wouldn't be complete without it. Lovely view and close to other attractions. Picture perfect.
Impressive Square. This riverside square is impressive, with lovely monuments and the arch to go through. On a sunny day, it's a good place to get a drink and enjoy watching the people going by.

Must see but only once. Its like the champs elysees in Paris, beautiful street and architecture but filled, filled filled with tourists. In front of the ocean, the view and the buildings are amazing, however, as soon as you turn around you see only tourists everywhere and people trying to sell drugs to you. I really liked it.. once, and then I was done with it. For Lisboa, I found the little untraveled streets way more charming.

Nice touristy walk. A good way to get the flavor of what and how Lisbon serves tourists. You'll bump into some pushy restaurant owners trying to entice you into their places, but avoid the ones that look too cookie cutter eateries. A lot if cheap souvenir stuff too, but there are some quality goods here and there.
Great shopping . Loved walking around this area. Great for shopping and plenty of restaurants. Has a great vibe to t as does the rest of this beautiful city. Felt very safe as well.

Beautiful and historic place.. It's architecture shows the grandeur and the importance of doing commerce with the world. The 3 sides of this huge and very busy square, are framed with collonnades and all looking towards the sea. It's colorfull , and the size of it, allows for plenty of activities, like enjoying a drink, Keating at restaurant or browsing in the temporary stands that open under the arcades everyday.
A bit of everything here!. You can walk from the river, up into the main area of Lisbon and enjoy historic buildings, shops and restaurants - we visited many times during our visit

Lively Portuguese Square. Lots going on here, with some interesting architecture. It's also a sort of hub for setting off and exploring the roads, streets and alleyways leading away from it. Plenty of places to eat and drink nearby.

Nice huge square. It is quite broad square, and looks really good with the buildings painted in yellow. Besides you have the sea right there, so you enjoy a nice view. Don't drink nor eat anything in those restaurants or area if you are under a tight budget!
A great walking tour. We enjoyed the walking tour. Very fascinating architecture. I recommend comfortable walking shoes and a light jacket.

Beautiful place. It's an extremely big place, really nice, close to the see and to the very little sweet beach :D It's one of the places that you can't miss in Lisboa. In one of the corners you have the oldest cafe shop in Lisboa.

Just beautiful. I've worked near Terreiro do Paço for almost three years. Everyday I crossed the road in front of it and the view always surprised me, over and over again. It made my days, no exception. You can see Saint George's Castle from some angles in the square, the space is ample and there is always people around, bringing life to the square. The river and the view is also magic. Around the square there are plenty of restaurants for all tastes and even a museum and a disco. You can even climb to the top of the Triumphal arch before entering Rua Augusta (Augusta Street), the most famous street of downtown Lisbon, full of stores, restaurants and street art and animation.

Lisboa Praca do Comercio. A great Lisbon day out from Faro with the hubby. Strolled around the praca in a cloudy day taking pictures prior to visiting Castelo Sao Jorge. This has been a wonderful couple time :)

A well deserved "must see in Lisbon". Any standard Lisbon tourist guide includes Praça do Comércio as a place to visit. It has always been for its history, its architecture, its location by the river. Nowadays it is also pleasure and fun. Since traffic was eliminated some years ago, it got a new life. It is worth looking at the city events program to check what's up, or simply walk around or have a cup of coffee or a beer in one of the many coffee shops. But for me, the best of all is the golden light of sunshine reflecting from the yellow ministerial buildings. I love "feeling" and "breathing" it. I live in Lisbon. Biased? Maybe, but I don't think so.

A great daylight view ... a great disappointment by night.... I've visited this square numerous times over the last couple of months. It is interesting how the place where until not very long the nation's government used to sit has been converted into a leisure area. Although I applaud the work, and I do enjoy the restaurants and bars in the square I was surprised and disappointed to have visited it by night and find no lights at all. Surely it would be worth investing in this square as a day-and-night attraction. It has full potential to it!
One of my favourite places. One of my favourite places in Lisbon, its a must see in the city. You must go here for a walk and see the view by the river.

Visit at night for shows. If you have a go pro camera try to take pics from the top of the statues. It's €5 to go up and you get a different viewpoint. Also see if you can take panoramic pic of the beautiful building.
Scenic spot in Lisbon. Nice place to visit with lots of shops and interesting restaurants. Just be careful with pickpockets.
Nice square. Nice square at the waterside which makes it a bit cooler on a hot day. Nice restaurants and bars aside the square. Great place to relax
Beautiful shopping street. This is great street with shops and cafes along the way to the water or town. You just feel the history around you.

Praca de Commercio visit. Totally magnificent both the arch as you approach the Praca and the Commercio Praca itself as it looks onto the river Tagus. If you are in Commercio visit the tourist centre to learn about the Lisbon Story which is done on an interactive basis and give you a great insight into the history and development of Lisbon.Paul B
For a sunny day. Roam around this Praca and in the streets around. Have an ice cream and enjoy the view. Imagine the navigators coming into the city after a world tour.

Lovely Square . This is a great location to start your walking tour of Lisbon. It's easy to walk most places from here, and the square is a lovely place to have a drink, people watch, enjoy the waterfront etc. The kids loved being near the water and oddly enough looking at all the rubbish that was washing up and gathering along the shoreline. The children's highlight of the day was finding a very large headless fish just in front of the square...

Beautiful waterfron Plaza. This plaza is the gateway to the city of Lisbon and abuts the Targus River. The architecture and statues are interesting and the views across the river are nice. The plaza is easily reached (walkable) if you come by cruise ship or ferry.

Full of activity. This area is full of variety of bars, Bistros, cafes etc. and some good attraction. The Santa Justa lift gives a good view of the River front and the Castle above in the evening time. There are lot of activities happening around in the evening time as people come out to sing, dance and have a gala time with their drink. The porch near Targus River is a beautiful place to sit around in evening or early night and soak in the beauty of Lisbon. I would definitely visit this again in future.

Beautiful Plaza!. My daughter and I found ourselves wondering around after visiting the Santa Justa Lift. As we walked towards the Targus River my daughter said "turn around mom", with the statue and the arch in full view I was surprised by the beauty of this place! Hope to visit again in the future!

On a sunny day, this is a lovely place to sip a cool drink. Grand architecture, lots of space and a variety of bars, Bistros and cafes make this place a good choice for having a cool drink in the evenings.

Touristy area, but still a key part of Lisbon. This area, which leads you to the riverfront, is full of mediocre restaurants, but it is picturesque and iconic for Lisbon, so don't miss it - but be sure to eat elsewhere.
Necessary part of the Lisbon experience. With its location by the river, this is part of the heart of Lisbon. It is easy to walk here, and if you are tired, take a cab back to the hotel.

One of the most beautiful in europe!. This square is absolutely great! It's where lisbon opens up its arms to the river and welcomes everyone with open heart. Summer nights are specially great when frequently concerts are held here. Also its the beating heart of the city, surrounded by downtown, the riverside, great shops and restaurants..its a must in lisbon! A refreshing beer or a white wine by the glass in the end of a summer day is precious :) recomend especially the Populi restaurant and Can the Can. Now, before that, one unforgetable view is the one from the top of the arch. It's well worth the ticket as from here you have a true panoramic view. And do bring your camera!
View to river. Great street for a stroll. Pavement cafes and restaurants. Pastry shops are a must visit. Delicious nata.

Great shops and funky restaurants . We had a great time walking around and found a funky artsy restaurant. In addition to great food and sangria. There were several wonderful plazas to walk through. One was having a festival of traditional food and crafts.
Lovely to see the busy city and the calm river working together. A good trip from Rossio to Praça do Comércio, enjoying the shops, Pastel de Nata and to finish resting near the river.
Beautiful archway. A definite must see while out in Lisbon. its a beautiful walk with lots of little outdoor cafes and restaurants surrounding the arch

Absolutely a MUST-See when in Lisbon!!!. My wife and I visited the "Praca de Commercio" on a Sunday! You are right at the waterfront! The place is absolutely Beautiful! There were lots of vendors with tables selling things! Places to eat! People to watch and one of the most interesting afternoons spent in Lisbon to say the least!!! If you are downtown, near the waterfront, you will do yourself an injustice if you don't seize this opportunity! Lotsa photo opportunity here too!!! You'll love this location!!!
Many original Victorian shopfronts worth seeing . Basically just shops and restaurants- however you can almost feel transported back to the 1870-1880's walking around here.

Beautiful. And majestic .. Walking with my friend along the front and after crossing a road saw this stunning sight .really takes the breath away .The heart of the city .After awhile taking in the surrounding , we walked through the archway .Many cafes and restaurants. .The street is wide and in the middle full of. Cafe , restaurants .These are not cheap , but much cheaper than I expected .Other. Cities would charge much more .Plenty of choices too .A drink , snack or full meal .Very good service and staff not pushy .

Great Location for Relaxing and Experiencing Lisboa's Special Atmosphere!. This was one of the first places we went to after arriving in Lisboa and getting settled in for a 4-day visit! Even the slightly rainy weather (mid-September) couldn't dampen our enjoyment!Located just a short walk from the Tagus River, it's a great starting point for exploring one of Europe's greatest 'secrets' ... the wonderful city of Lisboa!We sat in a cafe for a while having some wine and local fare ... then walked some of it off by strolling around the square, window shopping a enjoying just watching the locals!
Little bit of Lisbon . THis part of town is interesting and there is a mixture of the typical tourist tat shops and European brands for shopping.

Lovely place to people watch. Restaurants and cafes line the middle of the avenue so it's a lovely place to sit and watch the passers by. I easily lost several hours facing the archway at the end drinking cocktails. Lovely place to soak in Lisbon atmosphere.
What a square. Great place, loads of space and magnificent buildings and a very nice view over the Taag river. As it is a very iconic place this is a must see for every first time visitor.

Historic Lisbon, Portugal via the Arch. If you know anything about the history of discovery, Lisbon is sure to be on your "to do" list. Arriving via ship, you will pass the tower of Belem, a symbol of Portuguese exploration and the Cristo Rei ( a replica of the Christ the King Statue in Rio).The public Square is on the river Tagus. Explorers left from here on heroic voyages of discovery. The square is fronted by the river, framed on two sides by official buildings, and on the fourth the arch that serves as the gateway to the old city. From the square, you look upon the hills that Lisbon was built upon. Castillo de Sao Jorge, located on a hilltop overlooking the city should be visited (allow at least one hour). Entering via the Arch, you are in the old city center surrounded by buildings that have survived for centuries. This is the nerve center of the old city, now converted to shops, offices and other commerce. Get a map, walk the streets, take the Santa JustaLift to the upper areas of the city and explore. Visit the historic churches, public squares and museums. A few days in Lisbon will bring history alive!

Watch your pockets, get your finger ready. Literally as a reasonably young looking person I got constantly hassled for the 4 days I was here to buy all manner of drugs (which are fake by the way) It detracts from the experience of the city, also several pick pockets around so be cautious, a friend lost her purse here.
to do thing in Lisbon. This was my first stop in Lisbon . Lovely architecture and great for a walk.But be carefull of the drug dealer .they keep offering you good staff :D

The main spot in the city. You can't miss it! Always full of people and yet so light and full of air. Listen to strret musicians at the river side, drink some ginga or chill at the restaurants patio - everything is great!
Beautifull!. As well as Bairro Alto, Praça do Comércio has a beautifull arquitecture! It's really a living place.

One of a kind, world class. This is my favorite place in Lisbon. So open, calm, big, very nicely rebuilt and full of options for leisure, eating, ice cream or just a walk. What a light! What a city! Every time I come to Praça do Comércio, I just can't hold my self and say a big "woooooahhhh". Fantastic at night too. Good place for events.
Grandiose. Very grand and majestic. Try to soak up and immerse in the food and walk around the area. Not too crowded as well. This is a must when in Lisbon.

Too much hassle.. This is a lovely street to amble up, but it is spoilt by the constant hassle of waiters trying to get you to stop at their restaurant. If they would leave you alone to read their menus they would get more trade. We did not eat there at all.

nice shops in central shopping street. It has its own charme. The old centralk street starting on the central square and ending at the river. Shops are not the ordenary shops you find in every big city in Europe. It is more local oriented on Lisbon and surroundings.

Beautiful, impressive heart of Lisbon. Wide open square on the banks of the river in central Lisbon, ringed by restaurants, bars, museums & historic sights & sites. Lovely view, but in peak hours can be very busy & full of guided tours.

wander around!. Great place to get lost in and absorb the local culture. I was lucky enough to see university students perform (Tunas). There are loads of restaurants, shops, and snacks. Definitely have a cod cake around here

Majestic Square. This square is a hotbed of activity at all times - lots of shops, restaurants, trams, etc. Lovely arch and statue of King Sebastian in the centre of the open section of the square with its own unique history - to learn more about the significance of the statue I would highly recommend going on the free walking tours round the square

Amazing views. Excepcional views! Every time in Lisbon I go there. During the winter they have ice skating thing, during the summer restaurants put their tables outside. Fantastic place to hang out. Once you are there go to museum of beer.
Good to wander around. a very nice piaza to walk around and take pictures. Easily accesible and near restaurants and attractions just by Via Augusta.

one of the world best city's to visit. My favourite place is Lisbon,a vibrant city with variety of everything.As the city has never been damaged by a war this city has a beautiful skyline of modern combined with Neo classic architecture,the old electric tram and a busy night life in the old city.The climate is amazing ,great temperatures in February,while we been there it was 17 C without humidity. The little brother of Christo from Brazil is 1/2 by boat trip away,you are able to commute easy everywhere and walking is safe and enjoyable.Most of the population speak English and Lisbon is a paradise for shopping and art.Try the roof top bat at Hotel Mundial,it got a beautiful 180 C view over the city of Lisbon.

Nice place to people watch. Plenty of places to stop for a beer or a bite or both and engage in my favourite pastime of people watching. It is clean and tidy and a very attractive pace to saunter and relax

Great Place to Visit!. We spent two days walking the area of Baxia, this monument is at the end of one vehicle free street. It is close to the river with a large city square right behind it where we spent a few hours people watching. Underneath the monument is an artist's market. I picked up some lovely handmade jewelery for a reasonable price.

Wow Factor. Designed to welcome visitors arriving by sea, though most modern tourists will reach it from the opposite direction via Rua Augusta, this is the showpiece square in Lisbon. You will be approached by people selling sunglasses, selfie sticks and, just as openly, hash and coke but they happily take No as an answer (unless you want to buy from them!) so it doesn't feel like being harassed. There isn't a lot to do on the square itself and nowhere to sit - though cafés and museums flank the sides - but there are great views and it's full of atmosphere.

one of the most fantastic squares in Europe.... This kind of squares is quite common, especially in Portugal And Spain, were an important place on the 15 centuries, used for important events from monarchy.This one in particular, is quite unique, mainly because one side of the square is open and is limited by the river, giving a special atmosphere.On our days is still a important place in city, with a lot of events, musical and others, and with sunny days is a fantastic scenery for pictures.If you are visiting the city you can't miss!
Very good place for drinking a coffe. Very good place for drinking a coffe, sitting relaxing and having a wonderfull time just for 1,2 euro

What a beautiful square. It was a National holiday & there was lots of people watching on this beautiful sunny day. The temperature was in the mid 70°'s. The arch is beautiful. This is quite a large square with beautiful surroundings. This is a great place to take photos, walk around, & cross the street to the riverfront. There were also lots of street vendors selling some beautiful items, not common souvenirs. The best part is this is a free activity.

Best place for afternoon stroll. Seems this is the down town area in lisbon. So many shops for shopping also coffee place/cafe for hang out. This place is so crowded, fill with teenagers, street performancers, and die-hard-shoppers.  If you wanna see or to be seen, just come to this vicinity.

Best place for afternoon stroll. Seems this is the down town area in lisbon. So many shops for shopping also coffee place/cafe for hang out. This place is so crowded, fill with teenagers, street performancers, and die-hard-shoppers.
If you wanna see or to be seen, just come to this vicinity.

Beautiful spot; good food can be found. This is a great place to have dinner or lunch on a nice day. The setting is spectacular and there are tons of restaurants. I had a seafood Paella that was very good. I can't say the prices are the best, but the setting certainly makes up for it.

Lovely Square. Lisbon's monumental riverside square close to the waterfront. It is surrounded by many restaurants and cafe. You can spend walking the promenade annd a pleasant way to people watch. The architectures are quite stunning. Its also the transportation hub for many of Lisbon's trams and buses. Great place to take pictures.

Amazing . Amazing and beautiful place to visit, vast space and laid out beautifully. Great place to while away time just people watching. But be aware of hawkers and pick pockets, they seem to be working in groups , not really a problem if you keep your wits about you.

Touristy but still beautuful. After years of construction works, the square is now truly a magnificent harmonious sight. The Tagus river on one side, symmetrical and beautiful buildings on three sides, and the castle looking down on it from afar. And of course that gorgeous Lisbon light. The square is now far more popular with tourists than with Lisbonites, but hey, who can blame them?
Always seems to be windy. Lots of people walking around, doing nothing much. Join the crowd, do some people-watching, have an ice cream or take some sun. Watch for pickpockets and wear good shoes!

Beautiful and must see place in Lisbon. The most beatiful and clean square of Lisbon. At Tejo's riverside. But don't waste yor time and money at bars and restaurants of this square. You'll probaly find plenty of better and cheaper on the neiborghood.

Take your time. To start you can have lunch at "Martinho da Arcada", a centennial restaurant where history and arts were made since the last 120 years. If you speak the language it is worth the nights when when first class intellectuals debate their views. If not make sure to grab the elevator to see Praca do Comércio (renamed by the Republic from Terreiro do Paco, the place where the king leaved after the 1755 earthquake. the place was rebuild from scratch by his PM the Maquis of Pombal) from the top ou have a gorgeous view, river and city. Once downstairs its worth just to walk around along the river, make sure is there is a light and sound show at night.

Beautiful square and archway, interesting monument. Better value restaurants behind archway in front of design museum as those on main Comercio square are expensive. Row of haberdashery shops really charming on street nearby.
Must visit. Praca do Comercio is fantastic, you must visit. There are so many tourist visiting all year around. good restaurants to eat and a lots of shopping and it is cheap.
very vast square, impresive. too big. when you get to the square you feel small, it's beautiful and very impressive, but very big. too big
Important. It is very important to visit this historical sight for understand a little about the history of Lisbon. And it is a beautiful square.
Nice area but geared to take your money. Street restaurants abound but do not expect haute cuisine. Street entertainers, vendors and of course beggars are all after your cash in this area.
Nuce street. But a lottle bit overrated... you can have a tuk tuk to pick you up from there. In a sunny day it can get very hot.
Nice plaza. Huge plaza and a wonderful place to sit down and enjoy people watching. Restaurants around the Plaza are a bit pricey, but it is worth it due to location

Great day to spend the day!. Very nice to walk around the old roads and building, Lots of shops and places to eat, some fun talent on display in the streets as well, dancers, music, magic and so on. A must visit if in Lisbon, make sure the weather is nice.

Nice square. This square is one of the central areas of Lisbon located just at the end of downtown area of Baixa. It's a huge square surrounded by lots of cafes and shops. In front of this runs the Tejo river with a beautiful view of the 25th April Freedom bridge. You will feel transported to a different world altogether, very relaxed and calm. I would suggest spending some time at this square, maybe at one of the outdoor cafes with a hot chocolate or a coffee.Must visit if in Lisbon.
Amazing . If you want to have the full Lisbon experience make sure you go to Praca do Comercio and its viewpoint. It's just amazing, couldn't recommend more.

beautiful square. This square is, no doubt, the most beautiful of Europe. Many busses and trams stop there, also the famous line 28. There are cafe's and restaurants, musea and shops. And you can sit at the river.
Time for a break. A pretty square leading onto the shop's (just go through the arch). A nice place to sit a chill on a warm day. Nothing to do as such, just to see and relax

Fresh breeze!. Also known as the Terreiro do Paço, after the royal palace (the Paço) that once stood here, the Praça do Comércio is lined with 18th-century buildings now fronted by expansive esplanades.
Down by the river, steps lead up from the water.
Nice City atmosphere and view of the River Tagus. This square has lovely views of the river and a nice atmosphere - worth spending a while here if the weather is good

Magnificent Square!. This is the first place one should visit,to understand the vision of Portuguese rulers and architecture.Large paved square on the river Tagus with ochre coloured buildings on three sides.Magnificent statue in the centre.The square Is connected to rest of the city by trams,buses and Metro station terroro de parco.There are fine restaurants and cafes on all sides.These buildings house govt offices and a heritage hotel'Posada'
Nice hang out spot. If you enjoy people watching from a plaza size restaurant, this is the spot. Plenty of ocean view as well as the former palace is an excellent photo opportunity.

Great view, restaurants. A don't miss area. Might want your camera. Several great restaurants but we liked the one on the left closest to the river (as you face the water). Get the trolley here for Belem. Metro stop just to the east.

Fabulous for things to see & do. Avenue that is at the heart of Lisbon for shopping/eating out and things to do.Leads to other fantastic areas & a must see in the evening. Walked from one end (Rua De Augusta) to the other (leads to Rossio Plaza or Zoo) and it took our breath away.So much to see and do, or lots of chance to just relax & eat/drink.Lovely!

Pedestrian street that can not be missed. It is one of the places in Lisbon that you will always visit. It is full of shops and restaurants, a few of them very good, some tourist traps, a lot of streets restaurants with decent prices. It is nice for a walk or if you want to buy that gift that will reflect the essence of Lisbon.It is also a good place for nice photos or for festivals.

Lovely square and pedestrian area.. This is one of the highlights to visit in Lisbon.It's a bustling square, overlooking the river Tagus, surrounded by shops, cafes and restaurants with lots of photo opportunities.Consequently it's more expensive than other areas in the city for food and drinks!There's a wine tasting shop, on the right of the square as you look towards the river, which is worth a visit if it rains.Under the great arch, it leads to a very nice pedestrian only carriageway with lots of shops and open air cafes and restaurants.Well worth a visit!
You just can't miss it. If someone mentions Lisbon, this is what I think of. So - you can't miss it! After you see it and the Tejo then walk up the Rua augusta.
Lots of shops. A good shopping area and good restaurants. This it a flat part of Lisbon so good to give your legs a rest.

Stunning Square. A really beautiful square and the heart of Lisbon, we loved the elegant arcade buildings that surround the square on 3 sides and then the waterfront at the end. It feels grand and very elegant. Check out the statue in the middle - very imposing. We also walked to the waterfront at the bottom end of the square and saw the marble steps where once royals and dignitaries arrived in the city, great views from here to the bridge and the Christ statue.We dined at one of the restaurants on the square - all are a great place to sit and watch the world go past. Don't miss the viewing platform from the arch - lovely views of the city and streets below.

Beautiful square with Pedestrian street. Pedestrian street (rua agusta) right next to the square. The square often celebrates events, fairs or market. I had the opportunity to attend to the Lisbon Fish and Flavours festival. Also, perfect views of the ocean

Great spot!. Touristy, of course---but you're a tourist! Enjoy the friendly service, a cold beer, and a delicious Tosta Mixta ( pressed ham and cheese sandwich ) while you watch the people in this beautifully proportioned waterfront plaza. Very relaxing. ( The guy out front waving in the diners using a menu as a flag is a hoot.)

Good public transport hub (tram, metro, catamaran). The sand at the river side is small but great with young children, but keep them away from the stairs. When you're lucky (as we were) they may be playing some live music and together with an oceanic wind and some sun, the place is great to be at.
City Centre Lisbon. Praca do Comercio is located in the heart of old city Lisbon. It is ideal for shopping, long walks and exploring. Me and my fiancee loved it.
Great street. Great people watching & shopping street. Beautiful architecture. Great ice cream shop Amorino Baixa. Quality shops & restaurants
Full of drug dealers. Very beautiful setting and lovely buildings however couldn't take more than 10 paces without bring approached by pushy drug dealers who wouldn't go away when told no
Very decorative....relaxing open place to eat or drink. A lovely area, very grand, worth a sit if not a little expensive however but expected to admire surrounding. Worth a visit

Your general shopping street. Connecting two major squares together you are practically forced to walk this route. And commerce knows that too. With a beautiful goal to go to when walking to the river side, the traffic lights are a bit too keen on holding you back. But OK, the buildings are not that bad to look at and you can be amazed by the traffic in general trying to cross the busy street.

The Gateway to Lisbon. Many few ocean cities and towns have this view. You can just enter in to the city stepping out of water and just walk in.Very attractive place with three sides filled with cafes and restaurants. In the middle there is huge statue with stairs to sit and watch walk of life. On one corner these is station for train, metro and boat which connects Lisbon to other side of main land. On the bank there are steps where you can chill out in summer nights and watch the beautiful golden gate replica bridge with jesus statue on other end. The continuous movement of ferries across add up to liveliness of this place. This is one of the place which will make you love Lisbon.

Just loved the buzz of this area,. This is just a calm relaxed street and area in Lisbon, great to just stroll along and with a great view out to the river. There were some stalls where people were selling their crafts

Beautiful . The architecture is amazing particularly on a sunny day, you can make many a picture perfect postcard under the arch or with it in the background, plenty of bars and restaurants along the Main Street to sit and enjoy the view, a must see in Lisbon.
Great place to eat and shop. A great place to walk daytime or evening with a multitude of restaurants and shops. Try the local cod fish delicacy with white port wine.

Always busy. If you have not walked this street you have not been in Lisbon. Lots of things to look at, people dressed and acting like the most incredible creatures, or even statues. Students singing, small bars and cafés to relax and enjoy. Also lots of restaurants that are too touristy to me with waiters begging you to eat, a bit annoying.

Pedestrian Heaven!. Whether shopping, people watching or just in need of a bite to eat this is a wonderful place to be. During our week long stay we visited 5 times. There is always something new to see or do. Be sure to stop at one of the many, many outdoor cafes. Great food, wonderful downtown Lisbon atmosphere.

Beautiful Buildings. Former gateway to the city the Praca do Commercio is a must for all Lisbon visitors. Large open space surrounded by magnificent buildings opening on to the river side. The black horse statue is wonderful
Beautiful! . To walk, shop and eat! The best and €10 takes you a long way! The stores are all over the place, bring an extra bag to put all your shoppings. Try all the desserts you can! Its worth it!
Amazing Plaza. This should be your first stop in Lisbon. Enjoy the broad expanse of this riverside plaza and imagine ships sailing up to the dock.

Grand. My family arrived by cruise ship so we had the day to spend in Lisbon. We decided to try to get up to the Castle but my kids being in wheelchair found it impossible to climb the steep and cobbled streets. So my wife and the children decided to call it a day and go back to the ship, leaving me loose on my own in Lisbon.The irony is that, having climbed to the castle and then back down to the centre of town, I found the Main Street, the grand archway leading to this large and dramatic square on the waterfront. Irony because wheelchair access couldn't be easier.It's a very grand square with the centre statue, surrounding buildings no archways, and a great vista out across the water. Just beyond the archway (back the way I came in) is a pedestrianised area with all the main shops and some great things to see.This square was a bit of a highlight in Lisbon for me.
spectacular arch. Along the approach is busy so keep focuses and enjoy this as you pass through it. A porthole of history with the river to aim for

Welcomes you to Lisbon. A great place to start a self-guided tour around Baxia, Chiado and Bairro Alto. The opening gates of Lisbon and has a lovely view of the beach, a great place to sit and enjoy the sun.
Big empty space. Vast plaza surrounded on 3 sides with arcades, but not much in the arcades but a couple of restaurants. Looked like the buildings were seriously underused.

Lovely place . Great square with cafes and restaurants.
Wine tasting is good fun and not too expensive here. Lovely gelatos and views.

Lovely Square with Two names. A lovely square in the centre of Lisbon. This square has 2 names. It is also known as Terreiro do Paco. You can pick up local buses/trams and other tourists transportation here. The 15E tram to Belem can be pick up here. You can also take the main street at the back of the statue and it would lead to Rossio Train station where you can get the Train to Sintra, about 1 hour or so away. In Sintra you can visit the PalaceWe were on a cruise ship that docked in Lisbon at Santa Apolonia terminal. This is over an hour's tram/bus ride to Belem. However, it is very easy to get there by bus/tram or train. So, exit the Port, go left and walk along the waters edge until you get to Praca de Comercio Square, one of Lisbon's main square. The square is on your right. Praca de Comercio is also called Terreiro do Paco. It is about an 8-10 min walk. It is a stopping point for buses and trams etc.Look for the stop for Tram #15E, should be ahead to the left. We paid 2.85Euros each way per person. You can buy the ticket on the Tram from the machine, which takes coins and notes. The machine gives change. Or you can buy it at a Metro station before you get on the Tram. The 15E to Belem would say "ALGES" because that is the last stop, but Belem is before this, about the 13th stop. The tram stops right in front of the Monastery, so you will know when you are in Belem.You can also take Bus #728, which I think is about 2 streets over in front of Apolonia cruise terminal. Look for the 728 going in the same direction you would have to walk to get to the square. If you take the bus you just sit on it until it arrives in Belem. It would also pick up passengers on its way at Praca de Comercio Square.On the way back we took Bus # 728, across the street from the Monastery. The cost was less than the Tram...1.80Euros each. You can buy on the bus. We got off at Praca de Comercio and walked around to see Lisbon's city centre. It takes a different route, passing the the Alcantara Mar & Cais Sodre Train station. We saw different things on the way back.

Lovely square, interesting history.. A very pretty square with a lovely view out over the river. The statue at the heart of it has a fascinating story behind it, definitely worth looking it up. However a square is a square and unlike Rossio, not much seems to be going on.

One of the most scenic sights in Lisbon. A lovely looking bright square, you can sit on small beach and look across river or look behind at square and arch.The tourist info centre on square is very helpful.
Very Nice Walk!. Lisbon at his best! Bunch of Cafe'S , Restaurants ...this is full of history. Its a great way to feel Lisbon...i Like it :)

Nice to walk around. Its a big square with an elegant entrance arch. There is a statue of one of the kings on the middle of the square where some dance groups or other street entertainers will perform. There is a Beer museum on the east side of the square, and vendors all around. The square has some pretty views of the river and some places to sit down, eat and people watch.
One of my favourite places in Europe!. The most beautiful place in Lisbon, very central, nice restaurants around, beautiful view, access to famous and historical places...
Busy spot to take trams and tucktucks. This is where every visit starts, being by foot, tramway or tucktuck. The buldings are gorgeous. No worry about pick-pockets as there is police everyware.
wonderful place. wonderful place to be. love the outdoorsy cafe's , restaurants and slow paced lifestyle... definitely worth a visit

Worth a stop!. We went through the Praca to get to the river. What a neat area! There is a monument in the middle and the square is surrounded by old buildings and cafes...we enjoyed a glass of sangria at one of them! Definitely worth a short stop and you don't have to stay long although you might want to stay to have a glass of wine or a snack!

Do Not Miss This. There are so many great things to do in Lisbon, but after a long day of sightseeing, one that I liked best was just strolling on this promenade. So fun for people watching, architecture ancient and modern, cafes, music, and more. A little touristy but also authentic feeling.
Nice place . Very nice place in historic Lisbon, within a walking distance from Bairro Alto and the estuary of the River Tejo in one direction and from Avenida da Libertade on the other.
Tourist centre. This is the tourist center of the city. Nice to walk up and down once, but that's it. The view is nice in some places, but there are better places to see in Lisbon.
It was not amazing but it was nice. It is pretty much like any other European city. The building were nice and it was enjoyable. Nothing exceptional.

Excellent place to start your visit to Lisbon. Built on the banks of the Tagus river, this large open square is the most prominant in the city. It is full of history including being the location of the assassination of Carlos I, the King of Portugal in 1908. Much of the square and Lisbon for that matter was destroyed after the 1755 earthquake, tsunami, and fires.

Lovely Square. This is a really nice square close to the waterfront. It is surrounded by cafes where you can spend a pleasant time people watching. Prices in these establishments are reasonable. The architecture is quite stunning, and it is not at all tacky, unlike some better known squares such as St Mark's in Venice.

Break time in Lisbon. Praca do Comercio is a giant square, where the Government used to have Ministeriums, some of them now converted into restaurants, clubs and venues. There's also a recently opened hotel, which in fact is very good too. The views are great, and connections with public transportation are great, either trams, buses, subway, taxis... Intriguing place though, being so central and such a beautiful place it's sad to have so many drug dealers right in day light everywhere offering you drugs, and even worse is to see no police around...

Wanna shop ?. Praca do Comercio is great to walk around, lots of shops, bars, restaurants, animation and street art.Walk till the end of it and pass the arch, enjoy the view to the river, smell the atmosphere, the music and if the sun is shining, you got a blue sky for free!

Terreiro do Paco. The Praça do Comércio is located in the city of Lisbon, Portugal. Situated near the Tagus river, the square is still commonly known as Terreiro do Paço, because it was the location of the Paços
Lovely shopping. Lovely area with great shops, totally loved the atmosphere that was about. Friendly shops and staff in all the shops, great baragains.

Great to see- don't eat here!. First time to Lisbon. Great place to visit. Enjoyed my time immensely here in the city and surrounding area.. and the people are great. Walk from here through the clock town entrance area down the (walking) tourist street. I recommend you stop to ask the outdoor vendor selling tile replicas what the symbols and meanings are of the tiles. He gave us a nice history of the earthquake, tsunami, and fire in the tiles. (see photos)BEWARE! I suggest you ask someone in advance about good authentic restaurants! There were plenty of imitation places around. Had several bad meals.Don't eat where the tourists walk. I especially don't suggest you buy a meal at the Praca do Comercio. Quite possibly the worse fish meal I've ever had. I can't find the name of that restaurant online-they've good reason to stay of Google maps... but it was smack dab in the middle of the outdoor seating. If you want to enjoy the sun in this area, buy a coffee or go with Italian!

Leisurely Sunday Stroll. Pleasant stroll on a nice sunny sunday afternoon, numerous shops to visit and enjoy, popular with locals and tourist alike. Fantastic architecture to admire, historic building still showing their past glory.

Where the city meets the river. A fantastic place where the famous brightness of Lisbon can be observed. Nice restaurants and cafes. It has a very interesting WC, appropriately designated "the sexiest WC in the world"! Praça do Comércio is one of the places you cannot miss when visiting Lisbon!
Fantastic Center of Old Lisbon. Crafts people set up in the corners, the ocean is in view, the architecture is magnificent. The funicular trains run from here to other sites.
Nice Walk. This is a nice walk in the morning or evening when it isn't too crowded. Lots of shops and restaurants. Begin at the water and walk up. Good location for souvenir shops too.

Very nice place. Very nice place to visit. As portuguese I recommend you to go during the day. The only problem is at night, there are drug dealers selling there and the restaurants are terrible (touristic).

Great Place to hang out on the Water. There are lots of resturants and stores in the square. It is on the water and the street that passes through is pedistrian so really nice to walk. Can pick up all the tourist trams there and not far walk from the Castle Sao Jorge.

Vortex. Definitely not a place for locals, but it's the heart of the tourist highlights. It's also a good place to feel the excitement of the city of the past, a culmination of the three historical neighborhoods. A transportation hub.
SHOPPING!. Wonderful shopping district with something for everyone. Cartier, Versace, Gap, you name it and all in historic buildings.

Praca do Comercio. This area in in the very center of Lisbon, between the hills and extending down to water. It is a very commercial area with stores, banks, restaurants, large squares and the Se Cathedral. The large gate to the city is there and worth seeing. You can hire a Tuk Tuk there or just walk around. there are some cafes as well. I didn't find it to be very appealing or exciting but it is definitely worth a quick walk through. It gets a little seedy later at night.

Large vivid place. Praca do Comercio is a large open space, very touristy, as Rua Augusta is right there too.. There are lots of restaurants around it, lots of people.. The square lies towards the river with Cais das Colunas... some wide steps where people sit down and enjoy the view over Tejo/Tagus.

Delightful place to visit. A huge square with beautiful buildings (Justice ministry) and a small beach at the edge of the square.Great photo opportunities and nice places to sit and have a coffee on a sunny afternoon.

Lovely perspective with Pombaline buildings. The Praca do Comercio, on the Tagus Shore, is a vast area surrounded by lovely Pombaline buildings. In its midst is the statue of King Don Jose I who led the reconstruction of Lisbon after the earthquake of the XVIIIth century. There are several bars and cafés with outdoor seating.

Pretty but a tourist trap. Lots going on, pretty buildings, but it serves as a place for locals to take advantage of tourists by luring them into crappy restaurants and selling crappy souvenirs. Gets a little weird at night. Preferred the view from a distance (and in peace and quiet).
Lively square!!. Very lively square; wonderul building, loads of shopping options (Lisbon is a very cheap city to shopping!!!), food and beverage. I reccomend!!

Tourist Trap. The whole area is a tourist trap. The main square is OK to pass through but nothing other than that. There is a beer museum in the area. Which considering Portugal only has two main beer exports is proof that the area is nothing more than a tourist trap.
Great walk. Beautiful walk from up the hill all the way to the river. Hundreds of shops and places to eat. Felt safe and the area was clean. Downhill even better!
Good for shopping and displays. Attractive shop window displays, eating spots and street entertainers. A busy street with no traffic except when you need to cross intersections. Plenty to see and do.

Beautiful sqaure on the Tagus River!. This square is a starting or ending point to a beautiful walk up Rua Agusta. On Sunday there was vendors all along the square under the covered walk. On one side there is a Portuguese Beer Museum and the other a Portuguese Wine Museum as well as a Ginja stand. There are many restaurants along the square as well.The history of the monument in the centre and the arch way are very interesting.The Yellow Bus Tours has a stand here as well to book tour or change online voucher for a ticket. There are always people in the square preforming and many just enjoying the beautiful view of the river. It also has a metro stop for the Azul line of the subway which is very handy to get down to the water front. Enjoy yet another gorgeous spot in Lisbon:)

Excellent walk through the center of Lisbon. All the area between Rossio Square and Praca do Comercio (Terreiro do Paco) was re-built after the 1755 earthquake and tsunami that destroyed Lisbon with an estimated 100,000 victims.My suggestion is to get the Metro to Rossio and walk to the Praca do Comercio. Several of the streets that go that way are pedestrian only. The buildings all reflect the style of the period (second half of 1700). It is really worthwhile.The Praca do Comercio (Trade Square because of the fairs that was held there for many years) is surrounded by historical buildings hosting many of the Portuguese Ministries - this square, until the earthquake hosted the Palace of the king and its government (this is why also the name Terreiro do Paço - meaning Courtyard - the yard of the court of the king).The square opens up to a magnificent view of the Tagus estuary.

Historically Important - Very Touristic - Overpriced. This place is very significant in the history of Lisbon and is the epitome of the reconstruction of Lisbon after the tsunami that wiped out the center of the city. It's a important place, you should go. Just be weary of the pick-pockets and get ready to be ripped off by the restaurants and cafés in the area. Many guided tours start from here - it's absolutely worth going on one to find out a bit of the history of this fantastic city.
Great view of Lisbon. Fabulous view of the city and shops. Worth climbing to the top, which is a new attraction for this sight.

A beautifull place with egards an space; nearby the river.. A sunny breakfast in the morning and a sunny glas of wine in the afternoon! We enjoyed staying at our appartment nearby the Praca do Comercio.

Sunny meeting point in Lisbon. The largest square in Lisbon where all trams, buses seem to leave from, bordered on one side by the Tagus, this could seem crammed and bustly but because it's so large it doesn't. There are several resuarants and bars that are on the square but unlike some European cities, you aren't ripped off here.
Main touristy street. loads of tourists watch out for your pockets, people offer Drugs on every corner! overall fun place to be, street performers are everywhere!

Worth a visit. Walk down through the arch to the main square and the sea front. Some lovely cafes to sit outside and watch the world go by. Lots of Tuk Tuks for city sight seeing and also some trams. Close to the walk way to get to the Castle of Jorges. Great place for some pictures.

Peaceful Getaway. Because of its great location, it's an ideal base, when we went here we sort of orientated ourselves from it, there's some lovely smaller squares, a ridiculous amount of reasonably priced restaurants, lots of historical sites as well as the charming historical city that all converge on this square.And when you're actually in the square the view is gorgeous nd its got a nice vibe with street performers, locals & tourists all lounging about in the sun. Be warned though, some of the bar are unsurprisingly tourist traps but we got some very reasonably priced local beer (large = 3EUR) from this boat on the harbour then we just chilled on the beach chairs littered around.Its also lovely throughout the day: laid back in the afternoon, romantic in the evening and busy with party-goers at night!

Only for the view . The recently renewed square is surrounded by lots of "typical" expensive restaurants with a lovely view on the Tage river. But you will have to support the multiple beggars and numerous drug dealers. We were offered cannabis 6 times and cocaïne 1 while crossing the square, not counting the counterfeit Ray Ban resellers.

Lisbon living room!. No tourist comes to Lisbon without visiting this enormeous square, the really Lisbon living room. You can reach it by foot, Metro, Bus Tram or Boat. Spend some minutes or hours, visit the Lisbon Story Centre, any of the Bars or Restaurants or just enjoy the nice weather if is the case.
Rue Augusta to the Comercio. So pretty and great view of the water... be sure to walk down to the beach. Also, check out the Beer Museum while on the square.

Easy and relaxing. Strolling along and window shopping, seeing the street artists and performers, selecting a place to eat, wandering along the side streets...this seems to be THE place to walk in Lisbon. Beautiful and lively!
Beautiful. Take a walk through this beautiful area with shops lined on either side and leading to be the beautiful square at the bottom.

most beautiful square in Europe. Imagine when standing in the middle of this incredible, large, beautiful square, that this is where people used to come into Lisbon by boat. At one time their palaces were here. Such a beautiful example of architecture.

The main Street of Lisbon with great food and artists!. Go along this street during the day and you will be able to feel the variety of sounds and smells of Lisbon!There are street artists performing and great food served in from of you!Tip 1: Wonder off little parallel streets and you will be able to find cheeper family restaurants and souvenir shops.Tip 2: From her you can jump in the tram 28 and visit other exciting places of Lisbon such as the Castle and Alfalfa district!Tip 3: Go to the design museum. It is free of charge and has 2 permanent and 2 temporary exhibitions on!Tip 4: if you like sports this street is perfect to jog as it is flat and you will be able to access the river side as well!
Great place to visit. Lovely place to visit lots of great places to eat and drink in. Right by the sea. would recommend going

Grand promenade. A lovely stroll leading to the water brings you past arches, monuments, wandering minstrels, and local craft vendors. Many stores, pastry shops, restaurants and ice cream parlors from which to choose. Keep your wallets and purses guarded.

One of the Great People Plazas of Europe. This is a beautiful plaza to visit. I love the street tile patterns, but be very careful when they are wet. Also, I love the entrance way to the shopping district. Beautiful Portuguese architecture and many nice store owners willing to assist travelers along the path. Lots of good restaurants. If you get a chance go here just prior to sunset, like many locals, and watch it go down across the street. over the water. Everything is pedestrian friendly, so, wear comfortable shoes and enjoy exploring!
Impressive. Impressive square. That was on a rainy day. We looked over the river, and I must say that rainy days give a mysterious character to the city

Great vibe. Beautiful plaza with a great, historical vibe to it. Spacious with cafes and people everywhere. Also features some old street trolleys that look from the period. Definitely worth talking a walk through here and perhaps having a coffee. I was disappointed that I was approach to purchase cocaine. I didn't feel unsafe at all, but I guess I must have looked like a potential customer. Brushed it off.Check it out!

Nothing interesting to see here.. One of the most touristy spot in Lisbon. Nothing authentic about it. Many overprized touristy restaurants with sales persons, some international clothes stores and stores that sell tourist-stuff. Nothing special to see.
Great views and restaurants. lots of people all year long, good for any kind business, great to take some cool pictures, historic.

Best when sunny. My first visit here was bit bad . It was rainy and windy and so cold, still I could have seen the beauty if the place with the waters edge at the back.I went back about 3 days later when it was a bit sunny. Enjoyed it much better. The place was filled with tourists . I enjoyed it to the max. So much to see here or just hang out. Lots of restaurants around and lots of shops not too far away...It's definitely a must do.

Nice walk in the city center. It is at the end of a street full of restaurants and shops, the walk is very nice, full of people, and at the there is the tram and a fantastic view of the sea and the bridge.. I also suggest to go in the evening
nice square. Really impressive acr de rua augusta! really nice on a sunny day. nice shops to visit. Be sure to visit this place
Beautiful Architecture. We climbed to the top of the tower, the view is impressive. The area is generally busy, full of cute souvenir stores.

Nice square and landmark arch . It was not the best of weather but the square had a good atmosphere. Around the square are some nice restaurants, musea and the tourist information. Also you have a great view over the river. Very good place to start your city trip.
Beautiful but bad in rainy days. It was beautiful but damn it was raining so couldn't enjoy much but the next day was sunny though it was good ..
Feel on the center of Lisbon!. Wonderful and magnificent plaza located by the river. Historical buildings and very nice esplanades and restaurants. Don't forget to go up the arch.
Good views to be had. Great street and worth the €2.50 to go up to clock tower as nice views from the top not a top attraction but worth the visit
Beautiful. What a fantastic spot! A must see and somewhere a y tourist will undoubtedly pass through. We had a drink very near here on a sunny day and it was splendid.

Monumental square!. Excellent starting point to explore Lisbon! This stunning square with a majestic frontage is huge and it's near to the rio Tejo (Tagus river). On the seafront you'll have an amazing sunset you'll never forget with the 25 de Abril bridge on the horizon, especially on the summer. But you can enjoy the sunrise also.This square it's perfect to take pictures, to seat and relax or to appreciate a good meal or a beverage on the terraces. From this spot you can go anywhere on foot, tram, bus, subway, taxi and tuk tuk. It's near everything and in some times of the year have some amusents settled.It's next to the Ribeira das Naus, Cais do Sodré, Rua Augusta, etc.
Shopping district. A little bit of shopping never hurt, there is great cafes and you can find the famous pasteles. Nice during the night.

Very touristy but nice area. The entire area that is open to pedestrians only is not very large (maybe 6 square blocks) but it's lively, lined with shops and restaurants and many street performers. It's kept quite clean and although it does have sort of cobblestone streets (which I detest), it's much easier to walk on than many other cobblestone-style streets. Completely wheelchair accessible, with broad streets - also a wonderful thing!

Lovely place in heart of city. Staying at Rossio helped me to take a short walk to visit this lovely place, a great mix of commercial activities with stupendous architecture admist the great sea view. You can spend hours strolling through the market, the square and on the sea shore. Relax and enjoy all at one place.
Placa do Comercio. A must -see! We took the 3-in -1 Hop-on hop-off lisbon City Tour and this was one of the stops. Lisbon is a beautiful city with lots of histoy- beautiful architectural buildings-

A nice walk, with shops, restaurants, bakeries and views!. Very popular strip for tourists, as it is lined with shops, restaurants, coffee shops, bakeries, etc... Great place to just a stroll, window shop, and drink coffee and beers a long the way. At the end, you will be treated with a great view and nice breeze at the pier. Highly recommend it.... and it costs nothing to do.

Beautiful streets, beautiful architecture. City center with a maize of comercial streets, terrace cafés (pricey), shops and restaurants. As with much of Lisbon you're here mainly for the spectacular architecture though I imagine the shopping is fun too. If you have sunglasses take them and ware them. I didn't and was stopped every five minutes or so by guys selling glasses though to be fair they weren't too persistent.

Shop here but eat elsewhere. Great street for shopping but the restaurants are really geared up for hooking in the tourists. To be fair i didnt actually eat here but that was mainly due to comments from other travellers.
On a sunny day beautiful waterfront location and perfect setting for lunch. On a sunny day, beautiful waterfront location and the perfect setting for lunch and to watch the world go by.

A very large and impressive square. A very large - but mainly empty, apart from the statue of King Dome Jose I in the middle - and impressive square with the focal point being the beautiful triumphal Arch. There are shops and lots of outdoor restaurants lining both sides of the square.

Beautifull view for the river and city. The colors are unique.
I love to go to the river and walk along in direction of Cais do Sodre.
Imagine how busy it was durin the XVI with all the markets full of things from the New World :D

One of the best squares in Europe. Praça do Comércio is the heart of Lisboa. On a sunny day you can feel the good old times of portuguese empire and imagine the bustle of departure and arrival of ships. With very nice terraces is a very good point to depart discovering the old city or, if you have enough time, to cross the river and see Lisbon from the other side.

Lovely Area for Shopping & Eating. This is a lovely area to while away a few hours sightseeing, shopping and eating.There are many beautiful buildings, plenty of shops and lots of restaurants for a Al fresco meal in the sunshine.
Nice . Nice view, nice music. We had a great time there. The tourist board is also on this square. Nice place to relax a little bit.

Great for watching the world go by.. In years gone by, they allowed traffic all around Praça do Comércio, but nowadays it's a lot nicer with bars and restaurants with just the top of the square being used by drivers, buses and trams.Get a seat at one of the outdoor cafés, maybe facing the river, grab a coffee or beer and just enjoy the atmosphere. Note though, if you're sitting near the Lisbon Story attraction and it's a school day, you're likely to also "enjoy" the sound of hoards of 12-year-olds etc who are arriving or leaving in crocodile formation...

Lovely area, watch out for the restaurant touts!. This is a lovely area, with some great shops. There are also some lovely cafe's with tables in ther street, However, be prepared to run the gauntlet of restaurant staff trying to tout for business. One chap followed us down the street shoving a menu in our face until we told him to go away!

smells, light and people. In January the sun broke through, before 3 days of much rain. The walk down to the river was magnificent. The smells of chestnuts cooking, the international mix of people and the sunshine dazzling was brilliant

Beautiful sightseeing. You can easily go to Praca do Comercio by taking the metro and by bus. There are many shops (zara, h&m, restaurants and souvenir shops) around the location. It is really a nice play to go for a walk at night since there are less people and you can enjoy the night view of Lisbon more easily.
Lisbon Delight. Very crowded almost all year. A great place for taking pictures and discover new things. Portugal at its best. A must-see! I highly recommend it.
A must !. Great monuments and perfect atmosphere. Enjoyed the energy of the crowd as we walked around. This is a must for your visit.
Beautiful. Lisbon is a beautiful city and you would love to walk in the downtown, and enjoy its architecture, restaurant, and shops. You cannot miss this street.

eh. Well, it's certainly large, and has a couple of interesting sites, including the arch and statue, and yes, it has a view (not particularly inspiring) of the river. There are also many vendors and entertainers, restaurants (over priced) an information centre, and what appeared to be over abundance of drug dealers. The square has played an important role in Lisbon's history, and is worth a visit for that reason alone; other than that, I found it to be a large slab of concrete with limited appeal.
Nice for a walk. Really nice place to go for a walk. Make sure you take a lift to the arc. Lots of people, but lots of space as well. Really nice small shops. Really tasty ice cream.

Lovely early morning in the sun or evening. We loved strolling round here and down by the water. Lots of restaurants and little stalls here to browse. We had a lovely shot of cherry liqueur in a chocolate cup here...very nice!

Huge square at end of attractive paved walkway. It is a fun walk down from Rossio along Rua Augusta to this vast square bordering the river, so wide and close to the open sea, it feels no different. There are some good 18th century buildings and it was here people disembarked for the city. It now feels like the end, not the beginning of a journey so the steps down to the water look oddly inconcusive

Nice to walk!. This is a nice area to walk through, it has many restaurants and shops. It reminds me of Lincoln Rd in Miami. There are street entertainers and solicitors, which can be annoying. But it draws you towards the river and is solely for pedestrian traffic.

Beautiful Area Ruined by Drug Dealers. I really wanted to like this area as the views are really great and some of the old architecture is just beautiful. However, quite a few of the buildings along the main pedestrian area are in disrepair, which could add to the "charm" were it not for the absolutely INCESSANT offers of drugs as you walk along. My boyfriend and I were approached literally 4 times by different dealers in under a minute while walking across the square. They are quite insistent and get uncomfortably close or even touch you. I had to elbow one guy to get him away from me at which point he started yelling at me and asking what my problem was. There seems to be no police presence whatsoever, which is really disappointing as it seems like a minimal amount of effort on their part could substantially curtail the practice and make it a more pleasant place. As it was, the whole area had an unfortunately seedy and unsafe vibe, so I cannot recommend it for persons traveling alone or with children. At most I'd recommend stopping very quickly for a couple photos and then leaving immediately. Such a shame.

Beautiful square overlooking the river. A really beautiful square once the seat of power of the Kings of Portugal, the buildings around it are now occupied by governmental entities. Beautiful the view out across the river especially on a sunny day.Noteworthy are the Triumphal arch of Rua Augusta and the statue of King Jose I.One negative thing is the many drug sellers bothering people.

Impressive square. This square is in itself impressive and is surrounded by a number of other attractions including exhibits, restaurants, wine tasting and when we visited (January) a temporary ice rink.

Beautiful area with an great view atthe end. The pathway is just amazing, full with shops and people. During the walk you can enjoy the nice architecture, if you care about this. But in the square you have a stunning view of the ocean and from different parts of the city. The square itself is very big and beautiful. You also have many restaurants and cafes.

Surprising Lisboa. One evening we asked the taxi driver to take us near the waterfront as we were intending to have dinner in one of the restaurants. Unfortunately it is not open for dinner so we decided to walk along Praca do Comercio and it turned out to such a lovely way to spend your evening walking along the shops, cafes and retail outlets.
