From one square to another, the experience was very relaxing.

Nice place to take photos. It's not the first time that I go there and I found it could be better. I saw a lot of closed stores and many poor people asking for money on the streets :( but if you want to take photos of the beautiful view you are in the perfect place. I don't recommend in winter, but in the summer is perfect because you really feel that the city is alive with many attractions. During the winter this part of the city looks sad and rains a lot! :/ don't forget the baby stroller if you are going with young children and please use a comfortable pairs of trainers!

Great place to start your exploration of Lisbon. This large and beautiful square is between the river frontage and the main shopping streets - it's a great place to start your exploration. There are some lovely cafes and restaurants surrounding the square, and it's a great place to people watch too but watch out for pickpockets.
Beautifull. It is a nice square with a lot of restaurants and a great view. Great connection with trams and busses and even airport shuttles. A must visit while in Lisboa.
Waking tour. Love this place. So much to see and many places to go from here. The shops are pretty great too. Barrio Alto is close by too. Go see.

The Wealth of the Distant Lands. For me, this is almost the only place in Lisbon where I could not feel the ubiquitous atmosphere of "saudade" (melancholy, nostalgia, solitude, everything combined...). That is maybe because it is a sunny open space right next to the sea and gives to display the tremendous wealth of the colonial past.

Must-See if in Lisbon. This is a spot that is definitely a must-see in Lisbon. It is located in a very beautiful area and next to the sea. Surrounded by great shops and restaurants. The square is beautiful itself.

Nice town gathering place. The Praca is a great spot for meeting up with people and for watching others meet up with people. There are restaurants, monuments and the grand arch that leads to an interesting promenade.
Stunning. Lovely square to walk around plenty of architecture and full of the locals as well as tourists, not far from the tram stop.take your camera you will not be disappointed

We were here New Year's Eve. My Teenage Kids and myself spent New Year's Eve here - they had a live Portuguese Band playing, and at midnight - the countdown on big screens and the most beautiful fireworks I have ever seen...awesome music, awesome experience !

Nostalgia. Always a walk down here. Up and down. See shops and people and acts to experiences and music and Winter sales of chestnuts. Short easy walk with lots to experience. Stop and refresh at one of the many restaurants.
Beautiful architecture. Square characterizes a greatness of Portugal, we were there in the evening but anyway it worth to visit
Shopping street. Shopping street for tourists. Interesting to walk here. Be careful for your wallets. Bad idea to go to the restaurants at this street. Almost all of them for tourists.

Nice square!. It's a beautiful square, although in January it was quite windy. The square itself is more for the eyes, apart from a few cafes there isn't much, but the avenue leading to it is full of restaurants and shops. Unusually many unsolicited drug dealers on the streets and even around the restaurants. It's not something that spoils the atmosphere, but can be annoying when you are asked every 10 steps. I guess it's more of a solo traveller problem.

Nice but spoiled... Great atmosphere with some amazing Street performers and plenty of shops .. Unfortunately ruined by persistent drug dealers (6 different people accosted us by time we walked the length of a busy street, in broad daylight).. Shame really..

Square near the river. This praca is an open space, with beautiful architecture (the arc and the statue) and with the river Teju right there. There are things to see here, and definitely should be on everyone's list, but there is nothing much to do here, other than look around. There are some bars on the periphery of the praca, but it feels somewhat too comercial. This is a central location to go either to Chiado or Alfama next.

The symbol of Lisbon!. This is the place where starting your day visiting the city! Make sure you cross the square and also take a picture of you with the bridge and the Christ statue on the background! Wait the necessary time for taking a snap of one of the classic trams passing by. And then... Go explore! This city is fantastic and this square is the gate to its wonders! Have a wonderful day!

Elegant Square. Surrounded on three sides by noble buildings this is a place for people watching.In the centre is a statue of King Jose 1 on a horse. At the time of our visit, Christmas 2015 - there were buskers and an ice rink for the children, despite it being very cold and misty, people were still paddiing in the water!!!Contunue through the arch to the main shopping area, Rua Augusta, passing the Rua de Prata and Rua Aurea, where silver and goldsmiths one plied their trade.A good start to any tour of the city.

Beautiful sight in the middle of baixa. In Baixa (downtown) you have many sights to visit. Praca de comercio is obviously the biggest of it.You have a nice view to the river and the bridge and you can take amazing pictures there.Tkae care that no one misstakenly kills you with a selfie stick. The amount of drug dealers there is also a bit annoying. Just go into the direction of the water, walk to the right and then you will pass kind of a small park where you can relax.The restaurants / cafés in/next to praca de comercio are three time more expensive than the average in lisboa.
Beautiful views all around!. This is a really nice open space, free for the public to enjoy! So many fantastic photo spots; marvelous waterfront; impressive statues; expansive square; etc.
Great Area. Lovely view, good vibe, shopping area. Good restaurants and a lot of activities. great area to relax and enjoy Portugal's vibe.

Amazing. Stay close to here & you will not be bored. Kids can roam, lots of shopping. Do not eat on the main stretch, the food is pretty horrendous and the servers are like hawks pulling you in to sit.

Expansive. This hub in Lisbon serves as the backdrop for various events. When we visited, for example, a stage was set up for New Year's activities. Also there was an outdoor ice skating rink for people to enjoy. This is a grand place that is fun to hang around and people watch.

Oh so Majestic sun drenched waterfront!. This place is something of a rarity with the Grand 18th century arcades, mosaic cobbles and the absolutely magical riverfront - it surely is something of a rarity and exudes the old world charm. Spend the evening and watch the sun set and the entire place glow in gold at dusk. The majestic equestrian statue of Dom Jose I reminds one of the royal roots of this place. It is certainly not difficult to believe that this was also the gateway to Lisbon for all those who arrived by boat for centuriesThe cafe lined boulevards and the chattering crowds is definitely a place to get lost on an evening and spend few hours through the dusk and experience the magic of Lisbon!!

A real surprise at the Port. I was walking down the pedestrian mall and received a huge surprise when I arrived in the square to find the incredible stature and portico overlooking the river Targus. Well worth just wandering around and relaxing in this area.

Grand and fun. Walking around here you understand why Lisbon has its position in Europe. Did not do any shopping but just walking thru, admiring the statues, the wonder of architect, totally enjoyable.

Be there or be square. Called The Square of Commerce in English, some of the symmetrical buildings of the square are still government offices. The bronze statue of King José I,dominants the square. It was designed by the Portuguese sculptor Joaquim Machado de Castro.We stayed in Alfama and everyday we walked down to the square which was our starting point of the day. The tourist office is here and many tram and bus stops and it is walking distance to the main shopping streets.

Praca do Comercio. It's a very imposing and grand-looking plaza. It was built after the earthquake of 1755 as part of the rebuilding effort of Lisbon under Marquis de Pombal, the prime minister of Jose I whose monumental equestrian statue stands in the middle of the plaza. Also Praca do Comercio was the scene of assassination of King Carlos I in 1908.

Praça do Comércio - Terreiro do Paço. A place that you have to visit. Besides the beautiful space it provides, it is near several monuments, shops, restaurants and plenty of lighting that makes it enjoyable and appealing visiting the city of Lisbon. I strongly recommend

Tourist stop.. Place where lovely Ribeira Palace used to be before being ravaged during the 1755 earthquake.Also assassination of king Carlos happened here.Opportunity for plenty of good pictures catching lovely arch and buildings.
Beautiful square. This is a big and beautiful square surrounded by nice buildings and a massive portal. In a sunny day this place is perfect for pretty pictures.

New Years Eve . What a scary place to go on New Years Eve!! It was so packed you had no control over where you went! You could feel the pressure of the people behind trying to push forward. Didn't see any police!
Fireworks were impressive.
Good place to go when it's not busy, nice bars around the area especially the Museu de Cerveja.

Very Nice Street in Downtown Lisboa. We came here on the evening of 31 Dec. 2015 and it was packed. Street shows everywhere. It is a good place to stroll every day of the year as well. The main square is by the sea which gives you a nice view. In the main square there was a band playing so we had fun.

Worth a stroll. My daughter and I strolled around the area. Some interesting buildings, but not sure a teenager is looking at architecture?! Shops disappointing, unless you like shoes!! It was a very wet day, so maybe the experience was spoilt a little. Once you've seen it that's it really! The back and side streets were more interesting!
Center of Lisbon. In the center of Old Lisbon, a very crowded place with shops and restaurants. One can enjoy also the old architectural buildings.

Pretty Amazing Place. Loved the shops and shopping area. loved the architecture,
Like a Mall but just awesome shops branded
A must see.

Busy and Beautiful. The plaza offers a wonderful view of the water and is surrounded on three sides by charming architecture. Our visit was during the Christmas season so an outdoor ice rink was set up and in use. The top of the arch has some of the best views of the city.
Beautiful . Beautiful spot in Lisbon. Very old architecture, charming buildings surrounding it with restaurants and a newly renovated hotel. Worth a visit.
Holiday. Pleasant and relaxing.. enjoyed ourselves browsing through shops, having lunch and coffee in local cafe..

BUSTLING BEAUTY. This is a wonderful plaza to explore history and beauty with a lovely view of the port. We walk here from our ship. The day we came, there were local craftsmen with exhibits of their wares. There is also an excellent tourist information office and a HOH booth. This is also a great place to have lunch and people watch.Be sure to carry change with you as the toilets are not free anywhere in the area.

Heart of the city!. This is the main drag down the center of the city. You can stroll up and down while window shopping and not spend a dime. Plenty of photo opportunities. Prices are higher in this area as it is main tourist spot and food is average at most places. One of the few flat areas of Lisbon! The arch alone is worth the visit.

Nice place. This is a perfect point to start your discovery of the city, as the main tram routes to all the sights run from here. Besides, you can go up the street and find lots of souvenir shops, stores and places to eat. The square also offers a great view of the April 25 bridge and the Christ statue.
connects coast to shopping street. square with lots of life and restaurants. nice view on the arch of triumph. from this square you can have a nice walk in the shopping street to the other squares
Okay. It's an okay place, with lots of restaurants on the sides, although I must say there are lots of better places to eat in the city.

Busy place, nice shops. The place is full of tourists, but the area is definitely worth a walk. A lot of souvenir shops and places to eat. Some beggars in the area and dancing gangs around as well.Most upsetting - a lot of strange dudes selling marijuana and all that kind of stuff.

Very nice square, big, full of people and facing the water!. Another place with lots of history, so unless you're just interested for the people walking around you or the buses passing through and going almost to all locations (it's a very central location), you should totally participate in some kind of tour to find out how the square has taken part is some very interesting parts of Portugal's recent political history :D
Beuatiful view of water. This a huge square (used to be a parking lot) and a point of departure for Yellow Boat Tours. We took a boat to Belem from here. Also good place to catch a tram to Belem.

On of Europes biggest squares. Down by the Tejo river is the big square Praca do Comércio. a very impressive sight in Lisbon which was totally devastated durig the big earthquake in 18th century but rebuilt again. Lots of events going on on the square. On Christmas Eve when we were there this year they had a skating arena, a market, etc. Nice to stroll around here to avoid all the traffic on the streets. The square are surrounded with nice houses with arcades where you can get shdow in the summer time. Really worth a visit whie being in Lisbon. Close to other districts such as Alfama, Baixa, Bairro Alto.

Nice view of the river. Great Arch and nice place to visit. Apparently there are a lot of touristy restaurants on the street leading up here. But the arch is a welcoming arch to the port.
There is a part of the right where there is a plaque with a black crown for where they shot their King and the heir.
Lots to do. Perfect to spend the day. People watch, eat, shop, ride the trams and tuk tuks or just walk and take pictures. Can't go wrong. And, it's close to the water :-)

Memories of Portugal's glory days brought to life. Incredibly impressive square and vista which I saw again last October. I am having difficulty in finding words to describe the utter majesty of this attraction.
Please don't miss it!

Steps from the ocean. Once you go through the arches, the beac/ocean is in full view and a couple of minutes walk. Like a central square where they had set-up a skating rink for the kids. Also, nice hot chestnuts from the street vendors along with cafes and restaurants. Great views of the bridges and mountains of Portugal

Lisbon's Famous Square. This is the very large square near the Tagus River. Shops surround it. King Edward sits in the center and watches over all. From here you can take a tram to Belem or just walk away from the water along the main shopping streets.

Lisbon's impressive main square. On both my visits to Lisbon this main square has struck me as one of the more interesting places. One can really imagine historical figures such as Vasco da Gama being greeted here upon his return from discovering the new world. One of the highlights of the Chiado district.
Pah!. This place send you back in the 15th century, with its historical market and their fabolous sailors! Speechless! Must see!

just a touristey place. my wife and i went there to have ice skating on 25 dec 15.
on 24 dec, there is nothing that really scared my wife when we were getting out from metro exit, which gave us horrible feeling .
good
many restaurants and shops

Big open square in center. This used to be a poor. That is essentially the beginning of a stroll through the downtown area of Lisbon to Rossio and continuing on to the Avenida Liberdade. Because this was destroyed by the earthquake and then the tsunami in the eighteenth century and subsequently rebuilt in military style, this is a large open area with a statue, right in the middle, of the king who was responsible for the rebuilding of the city. There are cafes on both sides of the square and an Arch of Triumph through which you walk to get to the shopping street and the stroll upwards from the Lower City. This is also a major stop for trams.

The arch and statuary are great. Walking around the plaza is nice. It was really quite busy when we were there. There was a race or 10k ending there at the same time, so it was really very busy. I'm sure under normal circumstances, it's not so packed. It's a lovely square, with the arch, the statue and the water's edge right there. Nice pictures.

Wanted to visit . I was on a city tour and passed by this area. I came back later the same day as it's just beautiful. Overlooking the sea , in front of a big square and leading to shopping belt. A must visit .

Monumental place, looks wonderful now. This is a beautiful monumental square at the very center of the city. Some years ago it was perhaps a bit neglected, but nowadays everything looks great, as the monuments have been cleaned and buildings around have been refurbished, so all its magnificent architecture looks brand new. New pedestrian promenades have been created around the place, providing beautiful views over the Tagus and the city. It´s the right place to stroll around in a sunny day enjoying its beauty.

Best in Lisbon. Best place to start. Orientate yourself and move on from here.Get a tuk tuk and ask to be dropped at the palace on top. Work your way down from there. We used the app Lisbon City Walks.Their directions was not spot on but a good way to do the right things walking down to the square again. In main streets down time nice shops to keep you busy.A lot better than Alfama en Bairo Alto.

Go here! go here!. If you get here before Xmas, lucky you!! This place is hoping just based on time of year and weekends including late hours still hops with action as streets are packed with shoppers, street vendors are set up with all kinds of kiosks in downtown squares with speciality foods, local hand made goods, live entertainment and pictures with Santa. International food fare on every corner. This is awesome whether you are alone or with a family. The shopping is amazing especially if you are into high end goods as it less then rest of Europe. Know your prices and be ready to shop. Don't miss bringing back Port. It's very little known for me, but once there I found out there are tons that never make the world wide market so try taste tasting and don't just dive into whatever is being peddled as some are smoother and sweeter and unless you know all this by self education, you will shop poorly. Women, don't drag a large purse. Crowds are huge and pick pocketing is infamous here. Spread money into various pockets and take a very small hand clutch. Happy shopping with some wisdom and education.

Great place ruined by drug dealers. I really wanted to like this place. There were some street entertainers that were decent so I enjoyed that part. However, being a solo traveller around here was hell, on my first evening in Lisbon I was stopped by around 30 drug dealers asking if I wanted hashish or cocaine. I said no thanks but they were persistent so it was one after the other of me saying no thanks 100 times. I just wanted to be able to walk without being stopped by what I'd call scum. After that I just avoided these areas and got to really like Lisbon.

Massive Square. This massive square (With 36.000 m2) is in the heart of Lisbon, has great view of the hills and the Tagus river. This used to be the main entrance to Lisbon. Worth a walk around. Cafés and restaurants in the area.

Nice walk around . We were there once more for the night Christmas shows with light over the facade of the big historical building. Great. The environment is always good. Nice restaurants in the surroundings.

It is just a square, but a really special one, you have to wander around to get it!. This large square emcompasses loads of history of Lisbon, it was the first harbour in antiquity.Tourists in a hurry do not care about that, so try to grasp its uniqueness: it is just an odd square where 1 of the sides is the majestic river estuary; thus in order to get its beauty with its various sights one has to move and walk around, you can even have a coffee in a special place under the arcades, Martinho da Arcada, where the great poet Fernando Pessoa had a special table on a corner...

Not sure what to say.... This is obviously a monument, however once in the square it is pretty lifeless in my opinion. A few buildings, couple of restaurants and that is about it. It really lacks life, and could do with significant improvements. The hustlers in Lisbon are just a pain, and probably some of the worst in Europe, such a shame.
Nice square. This is a nice square with a lot of people. Buildings with nice architecture all around. Nice place to walk around.

Place of honour and fame. Always feel exited once getting on this widely open place with an excellent view on the surroundings of Lisbon, the bridges and related arhitecture. Place of many events and meeting point for most foreigners in the city.

Lisbon's heart. Beautiful square in the heart of Lisbon. Lots of tourists, cafes and restaurants. There were some nice 3D projections on the buildings but unfortunately heavy rain started so we had to leave.
Good for walking around. Great for strolling around and looking at shops etc. Whenever you are walking through Lisbon you seem to end up walking through here. Very busy with tourists.

City centre architecture . The main street can be very busy at popular times and they lead onto the square that leads to the riverside. The architecture is good to the eye and the shops are worth a gander

Very touristic. This area of the city is beautiful, but attracts too many tourists. So you'd probably want to get out of there ASAP. Especially annoying are those drug dealers that try to offer their stuff to you on every corner. The best part of it all is definitely the square. You should pay a visit there, but better during the day. As in the evening it can be very crowded. There are a lot of restaurants, but, in my mind, they are just ripping off the tourists. The food is below average.

Busy and crowed place but worth a visit. We took the tour bus and it brought us here. Busy and crowded area with plenty of shops. Interesting thou and it's worth the trip. U can sit down at the cafe and people watching is fun too.

Can be very crowded. The downtown walking/shopping street. Few high end shops, these are farther to the north on the Ave de Liberidad. Lots of street performers, some restaurants about a half mile long ending at the riverfront.

Good view of Lisbon architecture. This was our trolley stop to explore downtown Lisbon. There are several outdoor cafes surrounding the plaza but we chose to just review the central fountain and admire the yellow façade buildings that surround it.

Excellent walk. A very beautiful place. Ideal for a nice walk in order to enjoy the view to the waters. Ideal for a relaxing break while running here and there in the city. When I arrived here, it was sunrise time. Amazing one. Totally worth the visit! Very close by any means of transportation. It took me around 15 minutes to get here from Rossio area. Everything is close and nearby in Lisbon :)
Splendid. A huge square with triumphal arch and horse statue. Not much else to say except it is worth a visit. Try a beer at the museum of beer and watch the world go by.

The icon. I shall say the Praça is a place to relax and practically see the good and simple life in Lisbon.
Easy to reach by tram or bus.
Coffee shops are everywhere, if on budget you may find one in a more secluded area but still near the plaza. Praça de Comercio is facing the river/sea. Windy and romantic place.

What a nice place for a walking!. The Praça do Comercio totally worth the visit!!! Street arts, music and a great atmosphere. Just one thing really disappointed me! A lot, I mean, several drug dealers walking around!

Not to be missed. This square has a lovely back drop.....the river. It is busy, but not overcrowded. It is exceptionally clean. Restaurants and cafes all around the edges, many with music in the evenings. Small craft stalls, where it was a pleasure to look and not feel obliged to make a purchase, were also present.

One of the most beautiful places of Lisbon. All of the cities have a big Plaza, however not even one is open to the river, and just because of that this is one of the most beautiful Plazas of the world.One open front to the river Tagus, and on the other three sides, XVIII century buildings with restaurants and a very good museum, with the singular light of Lisbon, what do you want more!!!

Shopping galore. This is a good place to catch up on some shopping. ..with most of ur famous brands all at a same stretch...a good place for the fashion crazy...and if ur accompanied by someone thats not into shopping. ..they could just wait outside and grab a drink while you shop till u drop :)

Bustly and Fun. Lisbon has many "centres", but the Praco do Commercio is a fabulous place to hang out, particularly in the mornings.There are fine coffee shops, old Lisbon retailers, beautiful cobbled pavements, the best show shiners in Europe and the feeling of Lisbon all around.It has an air of controlled hustle, and this ancient location has been the heart of the Portuguese economy for centuries.

Pedestrian walk way to the water front - worth the wander. Walk down this street to the port taking in the history around you. Watch for the street entertainers that dress up and pose for pictures for a donation. A great way to explore Lisbon by foot!

Heart of historic Lisbon. A must see for every tourist and site of revolution and commerce, a key part of Portuguese history. All of the tourist routes lead here and a walk down to the sea side is a must do activity. Take sun glasses - walking across the square in the height of summer will hurt your eyes without them!
Beautiful!. Near the cruise port this is a beautiful, spacious square and a great place to relax and sample the local pastries in one of the pavement cafes.

A beautiful square . We enjoyed everything about this place /: the historical background , monument , size and the fact that it is right by the water so you have a wonderful view . It is such a pleasure to hang out there before the sunset , the plaza is very big with lots of coffeeshops and some restaurants .
biggest Praca of Lisboa. This is the biggest square in Lisboa and it's difficult not too miss ;) Always something going on and a nice place to just hang out and chill at the river.

Laid back in Lisbon. If you want to truly appreciate the Marques de Pombal's vision for Lisbon you need to take time out in this magnificent square and if it reminds you of Washington, Paris or bits of London then it is no accident. Architecturally this belongs to cosmopolitan 18th century Northern Europe not the Mediterranean/Moorish tradition. It's a great place just to sit with a glass of something and watch people pass by. Or take part in the meny public entertainments staged here. Hard to believe when looking at this expanse of stone work that it used to be a royal park, then for many years a car park.

Beautiful place on the river bank. If you visit Lisbon, you will end up here - recommended by tour book or to catch yellow tourist bus. The square is huge, open and nice place to hang out for 30-40 minutes. Rua da Augusta starts here and is full of touristy restaurants and shops. Very lively area. The river bank is very nice and you can clearly see Lisbon replicas of the Golden Gate Bridge (the same company built it in Lisbon) and Rio de Janerio's Statue of Jesus. Late in the evening, the square gets bit creepy with drug peddlers.
Grand square. The hub of the old city. You get a view along the river, can walk the main streets and experience history.
Excelent food. I recomend to go anywhere, ther is also Brazilian food cooked in the braza. Excelent esrvice and very polite people.

A pleasant open space with historic buildings. What a loverly open space at the end of the restaurants, shopping area.Nice to just walk around enjoying the grand buildings on one side & the river on the other.
Impressive square. Actually not to be reviewed because not one single tourist will come to Lisbon without passing this place...
Lovely place! . I've been here few times day/night , a really nice area , nice view and good place to stay chill. Just too many drug dealers in the night!

Nice historical square . Lacking the grandeur of its counterparts in France and Italy this square is still worth a visit. We were there on a beautiful sunny day. There are lots of restaurants all the way around the square and it is perfect to be able to sit, enjoy a meal and watch the water.
Terreiro do Paco. Lovely street, pedestrians only. Perfect place to have a cold beer or hot coffee with a cheese filled cod cake, do some shopping or simply people watch. Cant wait to go back.
Imbperial Grandeur!. Any visit in Lisbon would be incomplete without a walk down the Praca do Comercio, the former glorious entrance to Lisbon from the sea.

Awesome square with river view.. It is beautiful both day and night with beautiful river scene. From there you can catch tram or buses to Belém and it´s connected with Rua Augusta (one of the main touristic street in Lisboa) through Puerta de Augusta.

Faded grandeur. The square is a superb open space, with the river on one side and the Arco Triunfal da Rua Augusta on the other. Lots of very good (but expensive) cafes and bars line the square. A lovely place for people watching.

Main shopping. Mostly clothes shopping and restaurants here. Nice to walk around, but I would avoid eating here as it seems like a tourist trap - you know the type of restaurant where they serve expensive bad quality food. This country has such a lovely cuisine so don't bother with these.

The historical heart of Portuguese trading tradition. Praça do Comercio is the first place we visited after landing.
A nice architecture and a central point to start discovering the city.
We spent a few minutes by the river before heading to Alfama area.

Soul of Lisbon. Praça do Comercio is the soul of Lisbon. In this place you can see people from everywhere and inside the main building you can find all sort of Portuguese dinning. The atmosphere is wonderful and exciting.
Buzzing at any time of the day or night. Full of lovely shops and restaurants. Local bands put on fantastic displays very enjoyable. Brilliant for people watching
Another Must See While In Lisbon. Great view of all the shops and restaurants that Lisbon has to offer. Close to the Museum of Beer or just to hang out and people watch.
Pleasant place. great area for walking, shopping. A lot of history around every corner. A must see, do not hesitate, Lisbon has a lot to offer.
Pretty spot.. It's an interesting street to walk down. Contains many good restaurants and shops and beautiful buildings.
Pleasant walk with lots to view. This avenue is very lively and has lots of restaurants to enjoy a good meal. Stores for your sovernier shopping in every corner street.
The heartbeat of Lisbon. The square is vibrant, with view to Tejo and beautiful classical buildings around. Perfect anytime of the year.
Stunning!. Beautiful and grand. It is worth a visit, take a walk under the arcades, have a drink at sunset, the Tejo river is right at your feet, enjoy the moment.
Great sunsets. Time your visit right, walk over to the riverfront, and look towards the April 25th bridge. To see the most incredible sunsets.

Great place of Lisbon. Located towards the end of the famous Avenue da Liberdade and thus just near the sea front.
Always plenty of people walking around there and many restaurants, bars,....
A Grand Square. An impressive square right on the river with views to the hills of the city. There is a large street ascending the hill through the arch filled with shops and restaurants.

Beautiful walk and views.. This is a beautiful walk with a lot of stores and restaurants. Also, a lot of local entertainers are doing there thing as you walk by and for free. You can give money if you like or not if you prefer. Its really a nice stroll.

Beautiful square in Lisbon. This is one of the largest squares in Europe, has great view of the hills and the river. It's mostly filled with people and NOT packed with a bunch of vendors trying to sell you things. It's also close to the bus/trolley stop to Belem.

Pedestrian area next to the Tagus river. It's a nicely organized pedestrian area flanked by the Modern Design Museum. Vistis at the museum is free! Enjoy the sun and sights a few steps further at the dock of Tagus River. I came here daily to enjoy moments of peace. The "Victory " arch is above head, and the cobblestones are fantastic to trace the patterns of. Wide open space is amazing to behold. Restaurants, cafes and hotel lobbied are at the border of the plaza.

Centre of Lisbon. a nice walk to Rio Tejo.... appreciate the cobblestones and many shops on the way.... large number of coffee shops offering excellent coffee and pastries.... a wonderful, affordable, holiday!

Nice to stroll up a nice traffic free road!. Quite a pleasant experience strolling the length of this road! plenty of shops and restaurants (with seating outdoors in the middle of the road), As like everywhere in Lisbon ,all the pavements are made up of small tiles ,which are quite slippery when dry so must be treacherous when wet! So good rubber soled footwear is advised!

Fun pedestrian walking street with lots to see. A day visit vs night visit is a must at this pedestrian walking street. It's lined with many shops and restaurants. At night, it's lit up with many street performers. One evening we watched the sunset by the bay, then walked over to the Praca de Comercio. Very romantic and fun.

Terreiro do Paço - the waiting room for Kings and Queens. With 36.000 m2 this square is magnificent. Opening the town for Royalty who disembarked in "Cais das Colunas", it should be impressive to enter Lisbon this way.Built by The Marquis of Pombal after the 1755 earthquake, it's also known as "Praça do Comércio" as a tribute to the rich bourgeois who helped to rebuild the City.Today is reserved to pedestrians, and you can enjoy a drink in one of the many terraces you'll find there.

Baroque splendour. This used to be the main entrance to Lisbon. Nice baroque architecture and triumphal arch at the top end of the pedestrian street Rua Augusta which has a mosaic pavement, outdoor cafes and shops. Very busy and bustling, Worth a walk around.
A Lisbon Highlight. A nice shopping street with abundant restaurants centrally located to a variety of Lisbon facilities.

Lisbon Baroque Plaza. Like other 'Plaza Mayor', Terreiro do Paço iwas the main entrance in Lisbon at the time of Discoveries. There was the King's Palace ( 'Paço') before the huge earthquake of 1775. The area was redesigned by Marquês de Pombal and it is quite impressive to understand the geometric pattern of streets and buildings that come to an end at Tereiro do Paço. Nowadays, the beautiful baroque architecture lodges several trendy restaurants, a museum ( Lisbon Story centre), a nightclub ( Ministerium Club) and esplanadades where you can lounge your tired legs. Don't forget to take your photos on the top of the Arch at Rua Augusta and at 'cais das Colunas' , a quay near the water.

Great place to start a walking tour. We started a walking tour with Sintrat Magik at Comercio Square (The Palace Square), a riverside square where the royal palace once stood until it was destroyed by the earthquake. The royal family then moved to Belem and the new arcaded buildings acted as the port of entry to the city. Many government offices are now located here as well as several restaurants. Also here is a beautiful triumphal arch at which begins the pedestrian street Rua Augusta with its mosaic pavement, outdoor cafes, shops and street performers, etc. We also passed by Conceicao Velha Church with its elaborate doorway which survived the earthquake is a fine example of the early Manueline architecture. It’s decorated with angels, beasts, flowers and a cross. It also shows it protecting the king and queen. From here we made our way up the pedestrian street to the end. Great walk!

The Bottom of the City. This is a lovely square, where our Downtown ends, the heart of the city. Nowadays is full of nice restaurants and coffee places, where people can see the river, take a deep breath before going around to find more beauties.You can walk around as it has less traffic than before, and from this place you can go to meet those wonderful typical areas as Alfama, Bairro Alto, and so much more. Also if you want you can go up inside that Arch from Augusta Street we got in the middle of the square, that has an elevator who will take you up to a breathtaking view.. And i'm sure you won't miss it. The tickets to go upstairs are sold when u cross the Arch and go immediately to your right side. If you are fun of shopping you go straight ahead in that street and you will find several stores, coffees, our Downtown city area.If you come from cruises that have the pier near Sta Apolónia, you can reach this area, walking to your left for about 20 minutes. Its better to go by the street inside, that takes you there easily, then going in the main street full of traffic. You can also take a tuck tuck there, as its too much close to go by taxi. If you have any free transfer from the port, go ahead! Have fun !!!

A little disapointing. This area is not as attractive as we expected. Shops are average. We visited 2 restaurants in this area, one was okay, the second one was really bad. Fish was bad (off). We ordered some other dish. This was acceptable but there was no apology nor compensation. Dissapointing.

Charming. Beautiful place, with pretty architecture and places to see around. The whole street covered with Portuguese stone makes it special. The shops around are good, you have from high end luxury thing to normal h&m and pull&bear. For all tastes

Wonderful! Wide open and picturesque historic river front square - the focal starting point for central old Lisbon.. The Praca do Comercio is a wonderful, central starting point / meeting place, and is also an AMAZING photographers focal point!Located on the shore of the wide and expansive Tagus River,The Praca do Comercio is a wide open public square - surrounded on three sides by historic building and amazing architecture. With the arched portico's of the buildings are a collection of restaurants, cafes, a few shops, museums, and points of interest. Most of the restaurants have extensive out door cafe/ seating areas, for that you could literally spend hours people / tourist watching and viewing a ton of activities taking place in the central square.The centre piece of the square is a larger than life bronze statue of King Jose the 1st on mount (on horse back) which itself proves to be a major and dramatic focal point for photography. The building and architecture that surround the square add dramatic backdrops to the statue and to the surroundings. On the north side of the square - opposite the river - there is a large and dramatic triumphal arch 'Arco da Rua Augusta' - itself worth more than a few pictures - through which leads you onto Augusta Street - a wide pedistrian outdoor shopping area called the Rossio. Here and for seveal amazing blocks, you will find amazing shops, shopping, restaurants (many again with outdoor cafe seating areas in the centre of the pedestrian paths), street entertains, and many locals and tourists alike - out for a quiet evenings stroll.On Saturdays and Sundays there is a very nice, high quality craft / artist market under the arches of the north building.The square - primarily right in front of the archway (Arco da Rua Augusta) also seems to serve a very convenient central hub for a variety a public transport opportunity - buses, trams, cabs / taxis, tuc tuc's, bicycles, and even segways. The square was obviously a feature stop for many tourist tour groups, and not far way along the river's edge to the east, several major international cruise ships were docked.This amazing square provides a starting point to explore many nearby neighbourhoods, sites, and attractions not to be missed.In planning our 1st and unfortunately brief stay in Lisbon, I did extensive research on accommodations and ended up booking an amazing 5th floor penthouse apartment through AIR BNB that was only one block away from the Praca do Comercio. AND I truly specifically booked this apartment because of it's proximity and view right onto the square and access to Augusta St. and the Rossio area - truly the central heart of old historic central Lisbon - steps from major 'must do' sites and to the waterfront.TIPS: For an amazing experience, and to get a genuine feeling of old world Lisbon and true sense of real living, stay in the old town central core if possible. We found that the location of our totally private and self contained rental apartment (again not what we know or expect as a bed and breakfast property in North America) was more than perfect in creating an amazing experience. We were steps away for amazing sites, shopping, genuine neighbourhoods, amazing street and alleyway with amazing shops and restaurants around each corner, and an amazing church or cathedral on almost every block. We were one block away from the waterfront, several blocks from the castle, a short interesting walk from the massive Saturday outdoor flea market, and tons of other things to see and do.DO NOT MISS the convent ruins, and the elevated / elevator tower.Can not wait to return!!!

Shopping, good view of the harbour, many eating places. Is this the biggest square in Lisbon? It feels that way, and you will be surrounded by eateries on two sides, the waterfront, and the triumphal arch in the photo above; through which you have access to some ritzy shops, as well as many selling the standard tourist tat. Worth a visit in the evening to see the lighting, the bridge, and across the Tagus.
spectacular. must see place and all around this area so much to see buildingsstatues squares go on the trams etc walk along the river

Absolutely beautiful to stroll . This square has everything to offer. It is spacious has beautiful oceanic views and has some great small cafes/restaurants where sipping down sangrias would definitely relax you.
Part of the things to be seen in Lisbon. A short walk will bring you from downtown to the Praca de Comercio. Large Square with a view on the Tagus river, great lighting in the evening.

The most beautiful square . This is the most beautiful square in Lisbon It has a large open space surrounded by outdoor cafes and souvenir shops and opens out to the River Tagus. It is surrounded by beautiful yellow buildings and archways. We sat at one of the cafes and had lunch. It was a lovely way to spend a couple of hours in the sun while watching the passing traffic.

Beautifull buildings. Like its name says it is a commerce place. Lot of small shops and outside tables selling souvenirs. Also lots of cafe's and restaurants. Like all tourist spots they are not economical but you have choices for a chocolate, beer or coffeee. It is sorrounded by beatifull buildings and a lot of traffic.

Spectacular square. Wonderful open square with beautiful yellow buildings and a statue of King Jose in the centre. There's a beautiful arch leading to a shop and cafe lined street. The square is huge with not much shade but it is a must see when in Lisbon. As we are a little older we saw nothing of the drug dealers mentioned in many other reviews.

Beautiful awesome Lisbon.. A walk around old Lisbon is not to be missed - especially around the Praca do Comercio area - interesting shops and cafes - people sitting outside on the tiled pavements enjoying life and a coffee - tourists milling around the interesting shop fronts and many tiled building fronts - it's an incredible vision for the eyes and of course, a camera opportunity.
great window shopping. This is a great place to wander and windows shop. Stroll down the avenue, then go thru the arch to the river.

Great space but little activity to be seen. This is definitely a great public space. It's huge, it spreads from the Triumphal Arch down to the sea, with a great equestrian statue, and is surrounded by some elegant 18th century buildings with a good number of cafes and restaurants. Maybe it's because winter is coming, or maybe the civic authorities like the expansive monumental look, but it was surprising how little activity there was to be seen on the square. No buskers, no living statues, no stalls of any kind. So a stroll around and hot chocolate was the sum total of the time we devoted to it.
Good food abounds. Plenty to eat here. Turn off the main drag to find cheaper places but its a lovely spot to sit and have a beer or coffee with the compulsory egg tart and do some people watching.

A Central Gathering Place . A classic 19th century square opening on the river. Monumental Arch on the other side, amusing in that for a fee you can go up for a good view of the 25 April bridge, a smaller version of the Golden Gate and done by the same architect.

Grandeur on a large scale. Although not the most engaging of the open spaces in Lisbon, the sheer scale of this one gives it a special edge. It opens directly on to the Tagus with the imposing Arco Triunfal leading up to the beating heart of the city. A monumental space.

Nice street but one drug dealer every 50 metres. Nice street, bustling with people and life, and a nice perspective with the arch at the end but if you look young, you will be badgered by drug dealers every 50 metres, on this street, on the huge square at the end of it and on the sea front. What are the police doing? Well they are watching the street artists of course instead of doing their jobs. Very weird experience.

Gateway to Lisbon. This is the best place to absorb the Lisbon air, culture and life. Lots of places to eat , lots of monuments nearby to see or just sit to watch the world walk by and imagine the spender of Portuguese past . Beautiful, must visit.

one of the most beautiful squares in Europe!. walk by the Rua Augusta to reach the lovely Praca do Comercio. Beautiful both by day and night. Enjoy the view of the Tejo river, the Bridge 25 April and the Cristo Rey on the other side of the river, walk past the colonnades of the square sides, and choose one of the nice restaurants
Nice place but be careful of pickpockets. A great place to soak yourself up with the Lisboa atmosphere. Take care of your own belongings as pickpockets are active here. My friend lost his phone here.

Central location. A pretty square with an arch on one side which leads to a street of shops and restaurants; opposite to that is an open expanse of river views that have boating trips; and the large square itself, which has mostly touristy restaurants but nice for the views.

Pleasant Walk. This is a really good place to experience many aspects of Portuguese life. From their heritage in what must have been quite a grand entrance from the sea to Lisbon waterfront to their refreshing culinary, the way they enjoy their favorite pastel while sipping a cup of bica, and Portuguese goods and crafts among the many modern shops lining up the Rua Augusta and the adjacent streets. We had a few hours to spare before heading to the nearby airport, which only cost 9.60 euro and we chose to spent it here.
Good for a stroll. Nice walk, and when you go under the arch at the end, you can see the sea! The square is pretty cool.

Nice walk but touristy. This runs down the centre of Lisbon and is a good position to get your bearings and orientate yourself to the rest of the city. It sits in the valley of the city between to high ridges and lined with shops and restaurants. Much nicer on a quiet day and when you are not constantly being blagged by restauranteurs.

Good spot for people watching :). This is one of the crowded places - so if you like to have people around, go for it. I love the larfe open area. The srchitecture is great and the light makes it look even better - being a large plaza, there's hardly any shadow on the buildings!

Busy and bustling street. Although this avenue and plaza is busy during the day, it really comes to life at night. The placa has some good restaurants and cafes, even a stand where one can sample some Port. The avenue leading to the Placa is a shoppers paradise.Be mindful of some notorious individuals attempting to sell you some "illegal substances" - they are not shy, and seem to pull the wool over the eyes of the policia.

Worth a visit and definitely worth a snack and drink . A large open square on the banks of the Tagus, bounded in three sides by cloistered buildings. On the north side the centre is dominated by the Triumphal arch leading to the main walking street of the old town. In the centre, a large monument. On the East and West there are cafes and restaurants - quite expensive but worth the money to sit in such a pleasant environment and watch the world go by.
Very nice Square. It was designed after 1755 earthquake, it used to house the royal palace. hence the statue of king Jose

A pleasant area for shopping and simple dining.. A main shopping street with simple restaurants leading to the square which is bordered by the Rio Tejo to the south, and nicer restaurants in the square.

as Lisbon as it can be. all the surrounding area is nice to walk, with shops, restaurants and tourists. The square has nothing special, but the area around provides a great atmosphere. It is awful to be stopped every 5 minutes by sellers of fake marijuana.

walking pleasure. a beautiful place to spend the day walking around with lovely building and gothic look. a you just wanna be there till the day ends.. not to miss the beer museum... with the weather being chilly it lovely
Very Nice to enjoy. Very beautiful and nice place where you have a lot of restaurants and shops along the street where you can buy a lot of stuff or enjoy a drink and eat a "Pastel de Nata".

pickpockets, drug pushers & oblivious cops. This is apparently the largest square in Europe. The means a whole lot of space with a statue in the middle. The space is full of tourists feeling obliged to photograph the statue. There are also pickpockets for the tourists and belligerent dope dealers who get upset if you don't want their product. Everyone is watched over, with loving grace, by nicely dressed cops absorbed in their cell phones. Hey, if you actually saw crime you might have to do something about it. No sense getting sweat stains on a nice uniform.Also a nice view of the river & restaurants on the periphery.

The most Popular Street in Lisbon !!. If you looking for a good restaurant a bottle of aged Port Wine , gift shop or any other kind of gift drink you got it just seat inside for the begas don't disturb you but if you don't mind that great atmosphere !! you wil enjoy it seat in the sun !!
Old town centre . The old town is full of small shops, snaxk bars, cafes and restaurants. You need to spend 2 hours at least in order to see the whole place.

Pickpocket Central. I don't really see the point of setting up TA landmarks for squares but what the hell. It's THE square. You'll visit it for sure. Nice views of the other side of the river.When waiting for the tram to the Jeronimos Monastery, pay extremely close watch of your belongings. They stand right behind you and hit when the crowd starts ramming onto the carriage and you reach over the shoulder of others to validate your ticket. We were almost successfully pickpocketed by a very unassuming looking thief who only got caught because he was too stupid to look surprised when I noticed nearly immediately that my wallet is missing.

A Square with a statue. Well, what do you really want to know about this place? It is a square, with a statue in it. The buildings around it look nice, even the "World's sexiest toilets" (an experience I regrettably missed out on.....).

An absolutely stunning Square. An enormous, traffic free historic square lined with numerous cafes and restaurants with large amounts of outdoor seating, all within view of the river and the beautiful historic architecture. A real gem
beautiful relaxed. was not sure what to expect from Lisbon. The places you dont have expectations for often turn out to be the most positive surprises.

Iconic place in downtown Lisbon. Everyone eventually ends up passing through here, either by design or by accident. Ours was by accident, as we walked down from Rossio and just came upon this at the end of one of the roads down. Lovely open square, surrounded by shops and with the river beyond make it a great place to come and drink in the atmosphere. Look back from the river to see the arch and the yellow buildings flanking it - that's on every tourist guide!

Take a Time Out. Nice area, clean with plenty of cafés, bric-a-brac shops as well as good retail shops. Some delicious patisseries and a wide range of restaurants. Take a camera, lots of picture opportunities.

The most see it of Lisboa. By the river and on one side the Douro, on the other the Baixa, the Alfama on the other and the Cais do Sodre on the other. Meeting point and circled by restaurants and museums under the Arcades. Entrance to the City by the Arco Triunfal da Rua Augusta which starts in the middle of it.

GREAT ARCHITECTURE WITH A GREAT MIX OF OLD AND MODERN. We enjoyed a great walk through the beautiful big square and all the interesting roads surrounding
Plenty of cafes/restaurants to choose from and shops to suit all pockets
...and a tremendous atmosphere
We loved Lisbon and will be back

Take a side street!. This is a lively area full of commercial shops like Mango and Zara and lots of cafes for lunch. Avoid the ones in the main thoroughfare and take a side road. The portions were large and the food was cheap and lovely.

Magnificent!. In 1755, Portuguese architect Eugénio dos Santos designed a large, rectangular square in the shape of a "U", open towards the Tagus. The Square was built at the site of destroyed (by earthquake) Royal Ribeira Palace. The arms of the "U" end in two large towers (The east tower finished in the 19th century) In the Northside of the Square, facing Rua Augusta, there was the Arco da Rua Augusta ( Triumphal Arch ), started in 1759 and completed in 1873. The square was named Praça do Comércio (The Square of Commerce). The Commerce Square was filled with government bureaus that regulated customs and port activities. In the center of the square, there was the equestrian statue of King José I, inaugurated in 1775. (King José I faced once the main maritime entrance to Lisbon.) Joaquim Machado de Castro, Portugal's foremost sculptor of the time, designed this bronze statue.
Place to start walk in old town Lisbon.. Beautiful big square with a view of the river. Go through the arch and start exploring. Plenty of streets to get lost in and get something to eat.
Nice square.. Very nice square with many cafes, few museums, fanatastic monument, mini beach and spectacular river view.

Nice place to visit. One of the place you have to visit when in Lisbon, although I have to say I was hoping for it to be a bit more lively at night time, ie music/jugglers/ entertainers maybe their not allowed here and it was October on our visit, but a pleasant walking area with bars/Restuarants
Nice walk. Nice walk great viewsExcellent wine ( place to taste different Portuguese wines)Be aware of drug dealers suggesting to buy grass

Large, lovely square perfect for viewing the river or just people watching. This huge and beautiful riverfront square is a wonderful place to start or end the day. The view back toward the city includes imposing statuary and the arch over Rua Augusta, as well as the impressive buildings facing the square. Look toward the river and you'll see probably see birds, various harbor boats (both working vessels and tour boats), a cruise ship or two, and, at a distance, the Ponte 25 de Abril suspension bridge and the Cristo Rei monument. There will be also be street musicians playing for you, and you can get also get tourist information or stop for a drink or something to eat. Because of the size of the square, a lot of people can enjoy it at once without getting in each other's way. When you get tired of people watching or tired of enjoying the river breeze, you can catch a tram from there to continue your sightseeing (catch Tram 15 from there to go to Belem). One sight I viewed at this square is probably something you won't see: one morning we watched dozens of young men and women wearing only flip flops and what appeared to be flesh-colored underwear. They were performing some actions to the direction of someone shouting orders. They periodically were given towels to put on and take off. In a city of sights ranging from the Tower of Belem to the Castelo de Sao Jorge, this outdoor activity was certainly unique. Visit this wonderful square, linger a while, and maybe you'll see something equally intriguing.

Lovely place to visit . When we were in Lisbon we spent much of time in this area. There are some good bars especially near the river. Take a Walk down through the arch and find some restaurants great for lunch and reasonably priced.

One of the best?. Possibly one of the best squares in Europe. A beautiful gate, many fine buildings with arcades all around. This is where King Carlos and his son where killed in 1908. Not to be missed.
Centre of Attraction. Large city centre square in between the Arc Augusta and the river promenade. Always a hive of activity and not to be missed.

Impressive Architecture, Annoying Drug Dealers!!. This open square which meets the river at one end and leads through an immense arch to the main tourist shopping areas at the other end is surrounded on three sides by stunning architecture and has a very elaborate sculpture as the centrepiece. Is it a lovely place to pass some time especially in the evening or around sunset. Restaurants and cafes line both sides as well so there are dining opportunities. The one ( major) annoyance are the people who quite openly hassle you to buy drugs. I don't think they are dangerous just more of a nuisance when you may have come here to get some quiet time to yourself. There always seems to be police presence but they seem to opt not to notice what is going on. From the shore end of the square you get great views all the way out to the suspension bridge and the steps into the water are a nice (and popular) place to watch the sun set.

Nice Place To Start And Finish Your Day's Sightseeing. This is a Great Place to Begin Your Day as well as Rounding of Your Days Travel. The Square lies at the end of Three Parallel Streets Connecting the Area around Rossio & Praça da Figueira to the River. Walk through the Triumphal Arch that Straddles the Lower end of Rua Augusta and the Praca do Comercio Opens out in to a wide open Plaza that has Restaurants & Bars on both Flanks, The Main Street going from East To West on the North side ( This is where to catch the Tram number 15 for a Trip to Belem ) a Pedestrian Area in the Centre with a Very Large Statue of King Jose on Horseback & on the South Side another East - West Street with an Embankment with low walls and Terraced steps that Lower down from street level in to the River on the Last Section. From the steps there is a Pier on the left from where you can take the frequent ferries across the River if you plan to visit the Huge Statue of Christ on the South Bank ( The Terreiro do Paco Metro Station Entrance sits directly Opposite the Pier ). The view from the Terrace is Great during early morning with the Golden Gate like Abril 25 Bridge to the West & The Monument Of Christ Towering over the South Bank of the River but it is Even better after dark when everything lights up & the throng of people just Socialising Together makes this a Perfect Space to just Catch Your Breath & watch the World go by.

The view from one end is spectacular especially at night.. Lots of shops and restaurants either on the street or in the side streets. The weather was beautiful on the day we visited and had a really good look round.

Shopping and people. The newer side of Lisbon, nice place for a walk of you are into shopping, but seems to be pricier tourist part of town to grab something to eat, great for pictures at night when there are less people around
A sense of liberty. Huge square in front of the river. Be yourself here. Carefull with the gipsies trying to sell you "drugs". Run from them!
View to the river. A wanderful street going toward the squere and the river, usally full of people, but if you are there early in the morning, you can enjoy the silence and empty streets

A must see. Despite it being a big open square it feels breathtaking. As you pass through the ornate arch have a look up. Then as you enter the square you see the electricos. We loved standing by the water, enjoying the breeze whilst taking in the square's majesty. As you can possibly tell, we liked it.

Largest European Square. A magnificient 18th century square, built after the terrific 1755 earthquake.A royal harbour in Tagus river which, as it is so large, looks like a sea.A safe and sophisticated place to have drinks, a snack or a full meal in different styles restaurantsAn architectural masterpiece!
Very touristic. I liked this place. It's very touristic and busy. It had loads of restaurants and places to shop. Nice walk :)

Drug dealers at night. When we first saw the Arch and the square we were very impressed. The Arch commemorates the 18th Century earthquake which devastated Lisbon. There are some nice pastry shops nearby and is obviously the centre for Portuguese banks (they are everywhere). However, we stayed in the area and went there again at night. There are gangs of drug dealers openly selling anything from cannabis to crack cocaine in the street. We saw a police car once, when they all disappeared, but five minutes later they were back. We were asked by different individuals about 12 times if we wanted anything. Not a nice thing to see, something I have never encountered in larger cities like London or Rome.
Great place.. Seems very authentic. Looks magnificent. Reminded the great Portuguese past. Come and you won’t regret.

Prada de Commercio. Beautiful town plaza facing the river Tagus. A must visit during stay in Lisbon. Also has tourist information center. The ticket booth and the boat cruise boarding point are closeby. This is on the Lisbon tourist bus map.

Hopping place not to be missed. This plaza on the river offers free wine tasting, multiple open air restaurants, historic buildings live music. All right next to a main transportation hub for trains, trolleys and subway. for several blocks north, it's all manor of shopping and outdoor dining. Try the local cherry liquor in little chocolate cups offered at a small stand near the main street.

Great walking - can easily spend a whol day in the area eating, walking, shopping. There are some great shops, good restaurants, and great places to walk and explore. We went in the evening and the breeze was nice. We later found out the area nearest the water and not sure how far extended is all supported by wooden beams in the water emplaced not to long after the earthquake in 1755. The believe it has seismic properties ahead of its time.

A pleasant stroll. A lovely place to stroll and perhaps stop for a coffee at one of the many street cafes. Walk the whole length and you eventually come onto a big square. Please look at all the wonderful buildings.
Just another shopping district. Just another shopping district. By Portugal's standards, probably pretty good. By anyone else's standards, just average. Lots of tourists.
Great view. The location is very beautiful, offering you the best of architecture and view. I preferred to see it during the night based on the lighting but both daytime and nighttime should be seen.
Catch the sunset. I do strongly recommend catching the sunset there. You also have the perfect view of the bridge and the harbor.

Very picturesque area. It is a large square with historical buildings, statues and restaurants. It backs onto the river at the square and then once you cross the road you are in the pedestrianised street which contains a variety of shops and restaurants. There are also side streets off the main thoroughfare.There is also street entertainment. A popular area of the city.
Nice Shopping Area. One can shop here for souvenirs or just walk around or sit down in one of the many cafes. Very busy area and very crowded.

Pleasant walk with good shops. This was a pleasant walking area with no traffic and nice shops. Some reasonable places to eat and drink on the street with plenty of choice along the side streets off the main street.
MUST SEE. A big square with big historical signs. You can take photos at the square and near the river. There were some live music performance, a good atmosphere. Must see in Lisbon.

Chill and shop (or not). Shopping around if you are up for it, walk around if you are not. restaurants... well i would not recommend, may be check with rating in tripadvisor but generally not the best food
Lovely area. lots to see on the main street through Lisbn, shops, cafe's etc and street entertainment. Gets very busy
Amazing place. What an amazing view from the Tejo river and for the city. This place is historical and full of passion. Take a walk by the new "beach" and enjoy it!
A nice place to visit. This is a main square in Lisbon, it's very pretty. You can pick up,the boat trip on the Tagus River. All of the bus tours pass through here.
Grandeur of times passed. a big sqaure near the river were you can feel portugal's old grandeur very well. Very leasant vieuw's

Something for everyone. Beautiful architecture, bustling, busy and vigorous, this place has so many shops, restaurants and thing to look at. Nice wide pedestrian only streets with sidewalk cafes and plenty of people watching, if you walk all the way up to the rundown Rossio Station area, you have gone too far, turn around and walk back to the colossal arch and pass through it to enter into a magnificent square with the Tagus as a backdrop. Go here!

Place to walk and walk and people watch!. The Central Square of Lisbon adjoining the equally well known Praca da Figueira is the large square to enjoy a sunny afternoon taking in the environment, the bustle and multiple lingua Franca of all the tourists gathering for the various tours of Lisbon....tram, bus, walking, boat etc etc. This is one place you can have a late lunch, a glass of local wine and watch the crowds, the pigeons who walk more than fly and the hawkers ply their trade. If you've not been here, you've not been to Lisbon. The restaurants though are pricey charging possibly a 100% premium but every one is having such a gala time! there's no reason to complain!

Fitting end to a walking tour. This was our last stop of a walking tour - such a great way to finish.Lovely pedestrian square with water views and numerous eateries flanking either side of the square and a monument thrown in for good measure (tells the tail of Lisbons rebirth).It was a glorious afternoon and we skipped the touristy looking eateries (in the square) and strolled along the water front to reflect and relax, with a couple of refreshing drinks & pizza before heading back to our apartment in the Bairro Alto district.

Symbol of reborn Lisbon after the earthquake. Imagine yourself at the dawn of the XIX's century, arriving in Lisbon by boat and disembarking in the pier at Terreiro do Paço. First thing you see of Lisbon is this very large, colored, square teeming with people, and the great arch indicating that this is where you enter. Amazing first impression!Going up the arch is 2,5€, and definitely worth it. Great views towards the square and the city behind it.

A nice walk through downtown Lisbon. If in Lisbon you will probably end up walking through here. Lot of nice shops along the way. Restaurants are typically in the side streets or 1 block over. Fun to sit and watch the world go by, especially as there are no cars allowed. Probably want to walk all the way down to the river to at least see that view. Keep in mind that the sidewalk can be very slippery when wet.

Lovely walk, food and shopping. This was just round the corner from our hotel, we walked down it every day, it's pedestrian friendly and has lots of restaurants and shops, could not keep the fiancée out of them.

Lisbon oct2015. Great time lots to see and do, bus tours give you a great round trip, can hope on and of at places of interest, buy multi passes to save money if you want to do a few different routes.

Our most beautiful Square in Lisbon. Portugal is known for it's sea travel and world discoveries in the ancient times. From India to America to Africa we have been everywhere. Terreiro do Paço was one of the places where the boats would sail from. Nowadays it's a beautiful square, with restaurantes, great view and also the possibility to go put to the clock in the tower in the entrance of the square. From there there is also much to see.

Large open space. The thing that strikes you most about the main square is the size and space. Unlike most main squares in other European Capitals it feels vast and not enclosed. It helps that it is open to the river on one side too. A lovely square on a sunny day, there is not much to do there, but it does look nice.

Praca do Comercio. A nice square near the river with the famous statue of King Jose I and the archway leading through to the shops and cafés of Rua Augusta. It's also a really nice place to have a coffee and chill near the water steps and enjoy the sun a bit.

Save the best until last!. Take a wander round the lovely district of Chiado, down from Rossio square through Rua Augusta and under the very impressive arch and finish up in this lovely wide square.Walk all the way across the square and finish your walk by sitting on the steps of the Cais das Colunas.

Plenty to do. Great area, shops, restaurants, bars, everything you need. Sit on the wall on the Tagus River with a glass of something from the Boat bar on the prom and watch the sunset. Walk along the prom and people watch, sit in one of the restaurants and enjoy a fabulous meal. The restaurants in the square are lovely but slightly more expensive than if you go to one in the streets behind the arch. I recommend Sao Nicholau Cafeteria, about two streets back. Not flashy but superb food at very reasonable prices (my hubby & I had two courses, coffee and a bottle of wine for €40 You can get on the buses, tuctucs,the old and new trams and boat tours from this square so it's a good place to head to for getting your bearings in the city
A must visit while in Lisbon. A historically rich and beautiful place to visit while you're in Lisbon. Placed down town you can easily access.
Lots to explore. A lovely paved area to explore the shops and enjoy a quiet coffee in one of the many patisseries. Make sure you explore the adjoining streets also,

Beautiful and cultural. Lovely area, pretty and clean with plenty of little cafés, bric-a-brac shops aswell as good retail shops. Some gorgeous patisseries and restaurants. The place is well guarded by police and you feel safer for that. Lots of picture opportunities.
Vibrant square . Vibrant square locked between Rua Augusta and the nostalgic trams. Cosmopolitan architecture and Latin spirit. Shouldn't be missed.
Great atmosphere!. I truly enjoyed the atmosphere at the square and came here several evenings during the stay. Great to sit down at one of the cafes and enjoy a cup of coffee!
It's amazing. Wonderful place where you can drink or eat just before go up to bairro alto to have fun. If you have to book a hotel this area is very smart to have everything near

Big area with a lot to do. Praca do Comercio is very unique place and one of the things that you must do while in Lisbon. The place is big and right across the street is the ocean, the whole area is wonderful for photography enthusiast, walk aroung, check the several monuments on the square and go to the beach for even bigger thrill. Spend some time here, don’t rush, there is a lot to see and enjoy.
Nice walk . Nice walk, food the same everywhere and overpriced. Got tired of ignoring drug dealers who are selling hashish. 7 times in 10minutes!

Personal Favorite Plaza in Europe!. I am absolutely in love with this plaza! The yellow color is so different and just amazing! I loved just sitting in the plaza and soaking up the sun and breathing the fresh air coming off the water! I can't wait to return!

Beautiful old square right on the water's edge. This is a beautiful big square leading down to the river and a tiny beach. Around the square are cafes, bars and restaurants. It's a great place to head to especially at sunset for cocktails at happy hour.

Central Showpiece. Praca do Comercio is a beautiful central place to start your walking exploration of Lisbon, it is a large square, close to the Tagus River, a short distance to the labyrinth of Alfama or the entrance way through the arch to Augusta Street, which has some fantastic shops and eateries.

Touristy but fun. This is a crowded area but is the central part of the city.Unike Alfama and Chiado its not steep. You can take a walk around. The square is very big and has a lot of history. Our guide from Sandeman tour was very knowledgeable and gave us lot of insights about the place.There are various restaurants and bakeries nearby. You can also catch the famed tram 28 from closeby
Lively and beautiful. A wonderful stroll through the busy streets of Lisbon into an open, lively square. Plenty of cafes around and a beautiful view of the Ocean.
Must do. Nice thing to do at sunset, great view of the Rua Augusta, the river and the Bridge. Good restaurants .
The "Grand Place" of Lisbon. The central place of Lisbon. It MUST to be visited. I had the sentiment of walking on the ... history.
very lively square. great views, lots of bars and restaurants around, slightly too touristy but quite pleasant and there is even a little beach

Where the city meets the sea. How often does the beach meet the main square in a city? This square is filled with great bars and restaurants, buskers and people selling ice cream by the sea. Be aware though there are lots of people selling marijuana here at night time. I was approached at least 6 times in one evening here. The people are not threatening at all however and will turn away with a simple no. For this reason I have marked down my overall score

True Portugal. Tile and cobblestone are typical of Portugal's streets and architecture. This square is a good starting point to walk to any of the bordering neighbourhoods - make your way to the castle on the hill top. As we found out, getting lost as you are wandering is part of the fun.
Very beautifull. This square is a must go in the town of Lisbon. With wonderfull buildings looking at Tejo river, you will find lots of restaurants and other interesting atractions.
Spatious place. We have been there in a bike tour with greenwalk. It was cool being on bikes because we could play around a litle bit.The gate to the city is magnificent seing from the river side.

A place to walk around. To me it is just another urban street, but it is one of the places you must see so one can say you have been there. Really it was nothing special, just a big square with buildings around, lots of people and buskers, and shops.

One of the first recommended stops in Lisbon. The "Praça do Comércio" is a touch (one of the first and best) of Lisbon's spirit: cosmopolitan, always in a rush, permeated with tiles, past architecture, bars and restaurants all around, and best of all, Tejo river at its window.

great old buildings. very good walk through the shopping area and to the water. Artificial ice rink set up by the water and people lined up to try skating - fun to watch. Loved the cafes and sitting outside to have coffee and people watch
Lively shopping street. Beautiful, lively shopping street with mozaic pavement. Lots of pastellerias, restaurants, "living statues", music.
Nice area. We stayed in a hotel in a 2 minute walk from here, and nice area to walk around in. Alot of different resturants and shops near.
Beautiful walj, heart of Lisbon. Very lovely place which I always miss as soon as I leave Lisbon. Beautiful walk, but should everybody be there aware of the pickpockets.

Stunning suqare - gate to the town!. Massive, beautiful square right next to the river, with stunning gate to the city. Many nice ( but pricey) restaurants and tourist offices around. Beware of tourist traps!
Lisbon at it's best.. Great place to walk through. Close to the river and there are many restaurants here. A great view of the sunset can be seen from the top of the arch!
Lisbon downtown streets are nice. Best place to shop and have a drink or something to eat at lunch, in one of many coffee shops that an outdoor esplanade.

Lissbon magic. Beautiful! Go in the morning, have a breakfast on one of the many places along the way. Maybe a "Tosta Mista", very traditional ;) After eating go down to the river and enjoy the view for some minutes and get your feet wet if you like. At Praça do Comerçio there are many tours starting or passing so if you want to ride the eletrico or have a bus tour, you can just go there and organize ;)
Nice area for evening stroll. Nice area for evening stroll and plenty of bars and restaurants to visit to watch the world go by. Good location to pick up trams and buses.

Breath taking. One of the most elegant squares I have seen. Impressive royal and inspiring. The view of Tagus river is never better. sitting in the big square facing the river and taking a break before embarking on the shopping in Baxia Chiado is a delight. Simply amazing

Interesting. Centreal place with a lot of branded shops, the square itself offers beautiful views of the river, also interesting at night. The downside are homeless people but they will fortunately ignore you.

An enjoyable attraction on a walking tour of Lisbon. We've been to Lisbon and returned for a short stay which offered the opportunity to take a self-guided walking tour which included a stop for coffee. This was one of our favorite places to explore on our trip.
Lively square, nice views of the river. . One of the main attractions in Lisbon and always seems to be busy. Lovely views over the river and an impressive rebuild after the Lisbon earthquake.
Stunning view to arch and square. We enjoyed the scenic walk to the main square by the water.Also a great place to stop and get a drink.

The Portuguese enlightenment. The place where business was Dan,where visitors came to this city that was the fast known port before the great "Black Sea"-the Atlantic. The urban birth of Portuguese enlightenment with a scale of the empire. Don't miss the new elevator

It´s nice but not sure its worth running the risk. Well this is a very pretty square, the problem is that its full of pickpockets and although the restaurants are nice they are expensive and the staff loves to hustle tourists.
