There is some shopping, the normal stores, Zara, Bennetton etc. It´s a place I avoid because I don´t like to walk around worried I am going to be mugged, or have a drug dealer approach me, this is almost sure to happen, its full of gypsy drug dealers. There is a police presence but they kind of just look on and will only interfere if you get attacked and they are nearby.
Shopping and the sights . Visit during the day and at night... Very different vibes.... Very impressive... With fantastic views over the water.

Drug dealers and scammers . We had a really bad experience here and it completely tainted our experience of lisbon, so I would say that in busy areas like this, be alert and on your guard at all times. Thankfully there are many police around the area at all times which saved us from a very scary situation. We have visited many large European cities and are certainly not naive but have never experienced anything like in Lisbon around this area, especially Rua Augusta (?)Do not acknowledge the chancers who will try and sell you drugs at every opportunity. Most will give up and walk away but there are some who will not so be wary.

The central square is nice. Very nice to sit calmly at the waterside next to this central square. Square itself is ok, interesting for a few pictures and looks nice. Adjacent cafes are wildly expensive and no seating in the square itself. The waterside next to it, however, great for unwinding. Wouldn't recommend the road leading up to it, crazy touristy and busy.
One of the largest public squares anywhere. The gateway to the river, this impressive square reserved mostly for pedestrians is wonderful to hang around

Good start to a holiday. Fantastic square offering up some great views of the river. Ideal if you only have time for a quick wander as we did on our first afternoon in Lisbon. also has several stops for trams and buses which connect to other key areas of the city. Worth a visit!

Mandatory visit. Very nice square.
For a Portuguese citizen it is more special because all the government ministeries used to be there. All country was managed from that square and you can also ser the "cais das pedras" from where the ships set sail in the Portuguese Discoveries era.

Drug dealers a real problem and a nuisance.... As main squares of European capital cities go this one is average at best. A vast maw of nothing set in between some pretty standard buildings with a lonely statue sat in the middle looking almost lost amongst the sea of tourists and drug dealers. Oh by the way, I forgot to mention. This area of Lisbon is pretty much a 1 to 1 ration between normal people and drug dealers. They make no effort to hide their pushing. They literally just come up to you with Class A drugs in their hands and openly ask you if you want to buy drugs. In one 15 minute period of walking around the Baixa I was offered drugs on no less than 8 different occasions. At first it was a bit scary, then it became annoying, finally it became downright frustrating. It was such a problem after a while that it actually put us off going to this area of the centre. Its not a once in a while thing either. Other people were similarly getting harassed by these peddlers within plain sight of Police officers who really don't seem to care.Bottom line is; this is an ok but average area. Its not massively intriguing as it lost most of its very historic buildings in the 18th century earthquake and was rebuilt on a fairly sanitised grid pattern. Its one of those places in Lisbon you have to see just because of where it is but if it was anywhere else it really wouldn't be worth the trip. After a couple of evenings walking around we used it solely as a place to get on and off trams or buses while heading to or from the much prettier and safer neighbourhoods of Alfama and Bairro Alto. Another thing many people have said is to be wary of pickpockets too. Certainly better in the day than the night.
Space in the heart of the city. A vibrant part of the city, leading to a huge square next to the river. There's a feeling of space and light, with many cafés to relax in.
great view. Very nice part of town,lots of street dancers and entertainers.lots of shops and restaurants in this area.
Cosmopolitan. Beautiful ocean view, not to mention the wonderful promenade that stretches for miles and miles along the Lisbon coast.

Good place to hang out and gt a coffee. This is the main tourist street in Lisbon. Worth seeing thouh obviously it is crowded with inflated prices. Shop around for a bit if you are lookkng for food- prices vary.
A great walking experience. A Must Visit! at night it is still a very busy place and the fancy stone work on the street and sidewalk floors shine like they have been waxed.
Lovely square. A big, spaceous square, where you have several nice cafés around it and a beautiful view of the river Tejo.

See the river and observe the changing colours. Always full of tourists but clean! Also some non-discrete dealers for any kind of illigal products but smart enough not to insist too much.Against all that? the view, the wind from the river, a smell of freedom thanks the "open" space and some very nice buildings around. Even nicer since the street along the river is forbidden for cars. If you feel like going to for refreshing walk after diner this is the ideal place (pretty safe at night also);
My favorite. One of my favorite places in Lisbon, Portugal! Very live and fun! Restaurants serve traditional food! Beautiful view!
Just for the walk. I would ignore the bars and restaurants in the area, too touristy for my taste, but a nice walk nevertheless - one of the must walks in Lisbon
Large square, but not much else. A must visit in Lisbon and due to the central location a good point of orientation but the bars on the edges are all expensive touristtraps.
Interesting. Great street with no cars, nice restaurants and many shops. The street was very crowded. Very popular a must to visit. It takes you down to the ocean.
Fantastic waterfront plaza at the heart of Lisbon. Gorgeous Portuguese black and white cobblestone streets and magnificent 17th century palatial architecture abound here.
Great public square. A great public square with nice places to eat and great photo opportunities. Apparently the biggest public square in Europe. Be sure to visit this if you are in Lisbon.

The wide avenue leading up to the Praca has many shops and as it is pedestrrianised is safe for everyone, young and old.. This is a large impressive square to see and has the advantage of having tram stops for many of the tram lines.
Most popular tourist area. In the centre of the city. Very crowded during the day with street artists, musicians, tourist souvenir shops.
Great square. A very large square near the Tagus river and next to the bridge. Walking during the day is refreshing but cold at night. Be careful with drugs offers.

Commerce Square is extravagant touch in an understated city. Walk around the stately arcades and bold yellow government buildings that line all three sides of this vast square. You may ask what is on the fourth side - the river with its marble stairs leading down to the water. This venue has no metro station so either use your car and use one of the carparks nearby or catch a bus or tram or even get a taxi in.The city's main tourist office is on the west side on Rua do Arsenal 15. Naturally there are street market stalls under the arches where craft souvenirs may be bought. There are also bars and cafes to quench your thirst.
nice sqare. I'm not so much fun of different squares - this is nice and spcaious with nice architecture around and the estuary in south.
A joyful walk!. This is a great walk towards the waterfront. There are entertainers, street performers and a lot of restaurants BUT they are expensive as they are in prime location.@instabuilt
Nice place to visit and walk.... One of the must nice places to visit in old Lisbon. Near to the Tejo River, with many old buildings to see, food to taste and some shopping too.

Nice Walk..... A nice place to walk and see, the square and nearby allies are very nice and easy to visit. Lots of tourists around with lots of touristic cafes and restaurants all around but be careful of the occasional pickpocket that shadows all the above. Really nice architecture to see, specially after some recent renovations been done.
Good food,good shopping. Had a stroll down here first day .very busy but open.Had a meal on one of the pavement restaurant's.very nice,great friendly staff.

Was offered drugs around 10 times in 10 min.. in the evenings, they offer you to buy drugs (mostly fake marihuana) around every 50m. If you look like a dumb naive tourist (like me), all of them will approach you. To me it is no problem though, I just tell them I have something much more powerful, and as They ask me what kind of drugs I have, I tell them that I have Jesus in my life (as I tend to be quite bold about my faith). I got many interesting conversations with those guys I tell you....But by all means, it is a nice street...Just not in the evening after 21 o clock...

Nice Place. The plaze is very nice with good view of the ocean. The street leading to it is full of shops and and famous brands. A good place for some nice pictures, a couple of new t-shirts and a snack.

Beautiful square with views to the Tagus river. Probably one of the most beautiful squares in Europe. Mainly because one of the sides of the square is opened directly to Tagus River. It's the city's most beautiful welcome entrance, but you'd have to come by boat for that (which is not very usual).

One of the most beautiful and monumental squares in the world! Please don't miss it!. Every visitor must see Praça do Comércio or Terreiro do Paço (Palace Square), as the Royal House was located here from the 16th century to the 1755 earthquake. The square stands out for the triumphal Arch of Rua Augusta, from where you can get an aerial view of Lisboa.It is the city centre where you can find trams, buses, the underground, shops, cafes,restaurants, museums, old buildings full of history. Take a guided tour!

Can't imagine a tourist missing this amazing square. One of the best of all Europe.. One of the most beautiful squares of Europe. Set along the Tagus river and outdoor cafes. Free concerts are often held here.

Aerial view of praco do comercio. A good spot to see an aerial view or take aerial photos of praco do comercio. They charge you €2.50 to go up and see the back of the king Jose 1 statue. Wish they would let you go up to the east tower to see a better view of the statue.
Wonderful city centre. This is the city centre and the hub of all the trams and transport.Nice waterfront and leads to a long pedestrian passage with wonderful cafes and souvenir shops.

An amazing light show. Arrived last Thursday and saw an amazing light projection show on Friday evening (7th). A story in film was projected on to the old buildings on the square and dj's played music to fit the story. They were showing it 3 times during the evening, we watched the 1st one and the kids loved it so much they wanted to stay and watch it all over again. We just love these outdoor film/light shows, wish they did more back home in UK.
Must see. Great wies on the sea and the nearby streets. Worth to pay 2 euros for the entry to the arch. View you get from there beats every other spot in the city.
take a stroll. quite active but sedate walking allows you to enjoy historical buildings and plazas an =d access to a variety of rstaurants

Next to the Tagus. Large cafe edged square, with a large arch way, next to the river Tagus. Not very exciting, but a good place to sit and while away some time at one of the cafes, just watching the world go by.

Lovely place for a walk. A nice place to walk, majestic but yet aproacheble, full of present life and history, as well.Is one of the bigest square in Europe, here was the king residence till the big earthquake distroied it and the famouse carnations' revolution hapened there.Very large space, bordered with cafes (the nicest cafe shop for me was the second from the corner, where I had a mojito ice cream- very good) shops where you could try wines (we went there early in the morning, so it was not apropriate ), pastelarias- but I didn't tried them, so I can not recomend one particulary, The river Tagus can be admired, in one part, the Arch of Augusta street is in the oposite side and in the middle is a statue representing king Iosif I and Martinho da Arcada
The Grand Commercial Square..... the Busy Bustling Commercial Square, on the river side, it is magnificent, and ample, the BEER museum near this place is a MUST visit place, do not miss it...

Lively commercial space in Lisbon. Praça do Comércio is a large comercial square in Lisbon that boasts lanes of cafes, shops and pastelarias. The square is also space for street artists to flaunt their artistic abilities such as lives statues.
Make sure to catch tram 28 from the praça around the narrow lanes of older Lisbon.
Nice area.. Good for a walk anytime of the day or evening. Watch out for the buskers and pickpockets as per usual.
Shopping in Lisbon. Great selection of shops, we were on a hen weekend so needed bits for main night out and found all we needed. Nice clothes and shoe shops too.

Toursitic place, a nice walk.. A crowded and a very touristic place. A must see but try to avoid the restaurants in the main street (expensive and mainly try to rip you off). There are many restaurants close to the main street that are cheaper with a good quality
Pretty square.. Pretty square, loved the marble tiled paving, lots of life and activity. Always something happening here, buskers, restaurants, bars, shopping....
Beautifull. Beautiful,lot of goods in thisstreet. Direct fro the sea you coming in walking area. Restaurants and shops. Great.

A must place to visit in Lisbon. This place is great for shopping and has some nice places to eat or have a coffee. It's a central meeting place and offered some local flavor. Near the arch is a good place to rent some Tuk Tuks to go on tour.

Walk, absorb and enjoy. As you walk throughout the downtown you will notice several streets that run perpendicular to the waterfront and bring you to the public square ,Praca do Comercio, On the way and once there, marvel at the various restaurants, boutiques and wonderful architecture. On a hot day you will be sure to enjoy the cool breeze, open vista and the many gateways to other yet unexplored parts of Lisbon.
spectacular. Majestic boulevard in the center of this city. Full of shops, street performers (some annoying) because they block the entire street. .

interesting and nostalgic. street full of vendors and resturants . in the end arrive to an arch that seems georges and facing the water . when you are under it you fell history. like this place after old town area oflisbon.

Welcome to Lisbon and . . . make yourself at home !. This huge square is no doubt 'The' Entrance Hall to Lisbon !Once the main yard of the Royal Court, it's now welcoming you to get acquainted and know this town, either on foot or choosing one of the many options you have around and on offer !Nice restaurants, cafeterias, outdoor cafés and souvenir shops all around the Square . . .It's a must see ! You'll be impressed with the grandeur of its classical yellow and stone façade !

spend a day here. buzzing with people and activity, everything going through and fast. safe with police presence, little scammers also. tasty, fresh and plateful of local dishes at cheapest prices. stay some time and feel like locals

beautiful square. For me this is one of the most lovely parts of Lisbon. Full of old majesty and grandeur,but being utilised in a modern bar restaurant style. Lovely buildings, waterfront, great statues and a magnificent archway. What more could you want in an old noble square.

Waterfront center of town. There is always something going on here. A concert when we arrived, ending with fireworks. Groups of musicians, drummers, african dancers etc. Many possibilities to sit down for a vino verde ... but typical tourist attitude, quality and prices.
The heart of Lisbon. You cannot leave Lisbon without coming here. The most emblematic square of the city will give the perfect souvenir, an awesome photo
loved it. beautiful during the day amazing at night, lots of dinning options, near shopping areas, great meeting point to start the night.

The meeting place of Portugal.. Portugal is full of squares but Praca do Comercio seems to be where everyone likes to meet. The nautical tile work in its centre is beautiful and the statue looking outward to the river is beautiful. You can get ferries, trams and buses easily from here.

Starting point of your Lisbon Tour. Central plaza of Lisbon, with amazing view of the Atlantic Ocean at the edge of the Tagus River. Restaurants and landmarks like the arch and the statue abound in the vicinity.

wow!. We'd been walking around all day when we passed through the arches and came to this big, open space with a cool statue (according to the kids). It felt like a fresh breath of air and it was easy to recognize later and helped us figure out directions and Lisbon in general (this was our first day there).

Great place to visit and have a coffee. Always busy, facing the river, this huge plaza is surrounded by great historic buildings. Recently refurbished now offers restaurants with nice outdoor seating. From there distant from a nice walk on an exclusive pedestrian street is Rossio another great square with historic restaurants buildings and restaurants.

Wonderful to wander. We visited several times during our few days in Lisbon and enjoyed simply people-watching in this delightful and magnificent square close to the river. Walking through the grand arch you will find an avenue of many local and international shops as well as plenty of opportunities to stop for a snack or light lunch in a very pleasant setting.Nearby tours are available by bus, tram or tuk tuks but we chose to wander and enjoy.

Great site. The terreiro do Paco has today many good restaurantes and also coffee shops. The square during the summer is known for many concerts. Tuk Tuks are parked and the classic antique tram strolls by. The building surrounding the square are government office bldgs which use to be part of the kings palace. Its a great place to be

A theatre wide open on the Tagus. This huge square looks like a theatre or a temple opening on the Tagus river. Terraces are very pleasant in the late afternoon or at night for a drink. The museum of beer is not Worth it but the feeling of freedom, the ocean breeze at night are very pleasant. Just go wandering about, like the portugueses do, it's very nice.
Gorgeous. Apparently it was the former Royal Court of Portugal, and you can see why. Gorgeous buildings, venue for free concerts, restaurants and amazing views of the Tagus.

The great Palace Square. Because the convenient location of the Tagus river, this huge open space was the site of the royal palace for 400 years. After 1755 earthquake destroyed the first palace, the new palace occupied the three sides of the square, one side open to the river. After 1910 revolution, these building were converted to government buildings. Cruise ship landing close by, the location is convenience for tourist, some attractions and restaurants are close by.
Entertaining, colorful main street. Very colorful, sit some cafe and watch, you can watch at least one hour, by the way amorano ice cream shop is a must when you go to this street.
The square. It has a great view, restaurants and a beach where you can enjoy one of the most beautiful views in Lisbon.It was from here that Portuguese boats went to sea to discover new lands.

Lisboa/Fatima Portugal Trip. This is one of the tourist attraction in Lisboa Portugal,we went in this area before we proceed to one of the famous cathedral in Lisboa which is very close in this area.just make more walk down in this street and you will see the beautiful view along the sea,the beautiful restaurant,the arc the triump in Lisboa and a lot more.nice place and the weather that time was so good and of course people here are friendly almost all of them speak english.

Central place. Last remains of royal palace from the 1755 earthquake, this is now a good starting point for Afalma (tram 28 towards Graca) and Belem (tram 15). Still holds one of the oldest Café in Lisbo (1782), rendezvous point of many important local figures through Time, poets, etc...

Your First Stop in Lisbon. Lisbon's biggest square and site of the royal palace until an earthquake leveled the area in 1755, the Praca do Comercio is a good place to begin your visit to the Portuguese capital. Formerly a huge parking lot (fortunately no longer the case), the square sits on the edge of the Tagus and anchors what is possibly the only significant stretch of flat land in the city (no small thing if, like my wife and me, your knees aren't what they used to be). You can find the main visitor information center in the northwest corner, the best reason this should be your first stop. Inside, a very helpful lady named Sandra gave us some spot on advice about what to see--and not see--in Lisbon.The praca (the word is the Portuguese equivalent of piazza, place, platz, plaza, etc) is also a transportion terminus where several bus and tram lines converge.Pass under the arch to the rua Augusta, a very nice pedestrian-only street of shops and restaurants.

A glamorous gateway to the pulse of downtown Lisbon .... Of our two weeks in Lisbon (although we spent a night Porto, another lovely city), not many (if any) days went by without a walk through Praca do Comercio (Terreiro do Paco) as we began exploring the city's shops, historic buildings, and restaurants ... indeed, we stepped so often under the arch that we purchased a replica paving stone (each sector of Lisbon has a distinctive paving stone pattern) so that we could rekindle our memories. The riverfront backdrop and the historic foreground of the square is marvelous also!

Well worth a visit. A number of long streets lead to this beautiful square which is a must during your visit to Lisbon. The sea is at the front of the square. The square itself is surrounded by beautiful old buildings, restaurants. In the middle there is a large statue.
Open and lovely space. I love the place. It's big, with the river in front of you and restaurants ans sortes behind you. Along the year you can find some events in Terreiro do Paço!
A must see square. Beautiful square, a must visit. Lovely old buildings and statues. nice restaurants around the square too

Prefer event season starting early summer.... It is a must to visit while in Lisbon. Especially, during festival or event season when they have different themes going on in the near surrounding area: local kiosks for local tastes (ham, cheese, wines, beers, sangrias etc). There are nice choices for everyone's budget. Walking around is also a pleasure, There are several attraction "elevators" to reach the surrounding hill tops as well as their famous uphill trams.

Beautiful streets.. An elegant area with a wide variety of shops, many traditional with some modern outlets. It is busy during the day with tourists and overpriced, pushy restaurants. Very quiet at night.

A central must-see in Lisbon. A huge square at the riverside in Lisbon with a main pedestrian area going out from there plus the triumph arch, of course. Nice restaurants at the sides with food and drinks for you to enjoy. Right at the river often musician gather to make mood.
Don't miss the "beach" at the end!!. Beside the beautiful the plaza is, don't miss the sea at the end f it. A perfect and romantic place to take pictures. Really beautiful!
Good walk. A pedestrian mall in Lisbon that leads down to the river. I am sure all that visit Liabon will end up walking down here. Full of shops and restaurants

Visit. This place is nice to stroll and go around and spend whole day shopping, dine and take photos. The hop on hop off tour bus stops here every 30 minutes. The last trip is 7 pm each day. The bus main station is located at Marques de Pombal. There are four lines that costs 26 euro and can be used for 48 hours which U.S. A good deal instead of taking the red or blue bus that codt 19 euro each tour.

Fantastic main square. 'The Gateway to Lisbon' as our guidebook put it. Fantastic open space, right on the river front, great views over the docks area and the bridge to the west. Impressive at night as well, all lit up at night and plenty of restaurants for drinks and food. Not far from a lot of main attractions as well. Must visit.

nice walk. Main square and Ribeira Palace is a pleasant place. You do not have to spend to much time there, just see monumental buildings and have a walk along the river. If you have some time sit and enjoy this place it is worth to visit even for a while.

Excellence in its finest form. Of all the European cities I visited Lisbon has the most vibrant and beautiful main square. The architecture and the aliveness alone is already a great reason to visit this city that I complety fell in love with.
Great entrance to Lisbon. Great scenery around. Its like an official entrance to the city. Full of life and nice restaurants with an amazing gate

City Break . Relaxing place to have something to eat and drink..
Trams and buses to plenty destinations..
Plenty shops and restaurants to choose from..
Restaurants are reasonably priced..

Impressive. A massive open plaza on the Lisbon waterfront that symbolizes the country's proud maritime heritage. There are streets leading up from the Praca do Comercio that are packed with shops and restaurants. A great place to begin your tour of the city.

Before dinner, spend some time on the bank of the Tagus.... Watch the boats come in...listen to the street musicians as night falls...have a drink or two before dinner, just chilling in this beautiful setting...Praça do Comèrcio and Terreiro do Paço...magical...
Worth it. Beautiful area fu of restaurants and shoppes. Walking steet (augusta) is the nicest for chilling out. In my opinion best in Lisbon

Lisbon on foot. This is a main street from the water up a steep hill (as are all streets in Lisbon). It leads to several plaza for street entertainmnet, veryy old churches, train stations with links to nearby towns, and the main fashion shopping street. As you fatigue there are many cafes to choose from (coffee is hot and flavourersome and only half the Australian price!We walked abut 6-7 hours each day. The best way to expereince Lisbon, Sintra and Casais. Whatever you do don't miss the

Sort of your Entrance into the city.. The plaza is huge and impressive and makes a grand entrance into the heart of Lisbon (with the river on the other side). Walk through the gates into shopping districts, old town, great cafes and restaurants, museums, the heart of Lisbon. Sometimes they have art exhibitions in the plaza with is really a treat. Close to the train station and metro. Parking is a struggle, but so is all of Lisbon. :)

Huge square. The square is one of the biggest most probably in Europa. There are no shops around , but beautiful buildings with arcades. On one side thre is the Tagus rives, on the other side the Victory Arch. Plenty of restaurants. In the middle the statue of I. José king.
Nice. Very nice shopping area. Many restaurants nearby and totally a touristic place. Located near sea shore and perfect place to visit.

Nice part Lisbon and easily accessible. By most European capital standard, Lisbon is fairly easy to get around for tourists. You can get from most part of the city to Praca do Comercio by taking the metro blue line and getting off at Baixa-Chiado station. This square, however, is unlike other European squares in that it's not a 'commercial' in the sense of having a lot of shops, restaurants and cafe. One one side is the Targus river, the opposite side of the square is dominated by the Victory Gate. The remaining two sides have tourist information office and cafes on one side and the newish Lisboa Story Centre on the other. Smack in the middle of the square is a stature of a former king astride a horse. If you come to this square, you should visit the Lisboa Story Centre to get a historical perspective of the city. One can get a real feel for the 1775 earthquake which decimated the city and most of its population in this museum. For an extra Euro, you can also get a ticket to the top of the Victory Gate. The latter provides an expansive view of the river and the city. From here you can observe the grid pattern of the surrounding streets, rebuilt from scratch after the devastation of the earthquake. I would not make this a 'must see' destination in Lisbon if I have only 1 or 2 days in the city. However, for any stays longer than 2 days, it's definitely worth a visit.

Character Buildings. Our hotel was just off this grand avenue and every time we strolled up and down we enjoyed it more and more.There are many excellent shops and cafes here and the view down towards river are great.When in this beautiful city do not miss this.

Big Sterile Plaza. From the name of the thing, you'd think it was the main, humming heart of town full of fairs, exhibits, markets & music. No, there is a huge, heroic statue surrounded by government civil-service buildings. No innate life force there, other than tourists taking selfies.I visited once at sunset, which was nice with some pretty photogenic light and once with the wind blowing up the sand between the cobblestones, which was very unpleasant.

A square near he river Tagus. If you are visiting Lisbon you shouldn't miss,but please don´t have a bath in the river as many tourist do,the waters are polluted and.there many fine beaches if you cross the bridge over the river

Impressive square. It is big, open and impressive and leading up to some big touristy streets. We found it to be the nicest of the squares that we saw.But it is not a place where you sit and enjoy a coffee or so, it is just big and open.
Center of Lisbon. A beautiful street which shows you the beaty of Lisbon nfortuanetly to many panhandlers and Pizza places. The city should preserve the beauty and get rid of the rif raf.

People Watch. Great area to people watch. There are the steps by ferry terminal to soak up the sun by the water or cross under that arch and enjoy the shops, bars and restaurants. It is so clean. Try the local food and drink. It remains quite busy throughout the evening. There are 2 trans stops and several bus stops within a block.

My favourite Capital in all the World.. A beautiful but compact city built in the style of Venice I suppose. This street leads to a grand square overlooking the river and it's top quality. The square (Praca Commercial I think) has about 10 good quality, good value restaurants and the sexiest toilets in the World LOL - yes really! (At the far end on the left hand side near the river).The square also contains various tram stops both ancient and modern to all over Lisbon and a stroll along the river in either direction is very pretty and interesting. All in all this is a "must do" in Lisbon.
Quiet. As far as town squares go this has to be one of the quietest albeit it has some of the best views onto the river and riverside attractions.
Beautiful just beautiful. This is again one of Lisbons most beautiful scenes ,look beyond and you find the water,street sellers and little eateries and coffee shops,a jewel

Beautiful Plaza, beautiful buildings!. The size of this plaza is amazing! The statuary and the buildings are quite impressive and you have a great view of the water. There are different functions that go on in the large plaza and you can pick up quite a few of the different modes of transportation here also. This is certainly a great place for beautiful pictures.

One of the finest places to take a walk in Lisbon. By knowing Praça do Comércio, you will be shown to a lot of the best Lisbon has to offer you as a visitor.It provides you with wide spaces, beautiful terraces, perfect for a couple or family afternoon tea or coffee; it shows you the river as close and clean as you can see it; it brings you close to Alfama and Baixa (downtown), it invites you to enter at some of the finest museums and theatres and puts you among street performers of many kinds. To start a visit to Lisbon from Praça do Comércio is the way to best encounter a much alive and colourful city. One of world's most beautiful ones, for sure.

Pretty pedestrianized street in the center of old Lisbon. This is a very pretty pedestrianized street in the center of old Lisbon. It leads to the bank of the river. Unfortunately it is populated by people trying to sell illegal substances.

Just accept that the restaurants are tourist traps. I suppose for those with limited mobility this will be the area they gravitate to - it's flat(ish). Obviously everyone ends up here sooner or later but remember the restaurants are pricey and there is better food elsewhere in the city, but you have to know where you are going (helpful if you have friends locally or can talk to the students). However, there are some very good shops as long as you are selective. What else can one say about the main shopping area - there are others but they tend to be up the hillsides!

Lively street. Located in Downtown Lisbon, waterfront with great views of Lisbon. Lively, large square with a huge Statue and many Restaurants in the area. This square is a MUST if you visit Lisbon. Beautiful, well kept and access to Train Station (Cascais), Buses, Taxis, tuk-tuk, etc. nearby. Nice place to stroll around, take pictures, eat at the Restaurants located nearby. In the square the Lisbon Story Museum is located and it is a good spot to start your Lisbon visit.
Vibrant and historical square. This square is the entry from the river to the city of lisbon. It is busy and vibrant and has great views of the river and the south side.

Lots To Do,and See. Great area for eating, shopping and people watching. So many things to do and experience. Lots of tourists, but that adds to the fun. Many entertainers, which are exciting for the young and old. It was sad to see so many beggars, some terribly deformed. You want to help them all! You can find foods and drinks that are on,y found I. Lusbon, which makes it special to come with an empty tummy!

The best view in Lisbon. This square is right in the center of the city and offers the most stunning view in Lisbon (and that's saying a lot!). If you go to Lisbon, you will certainly stop here. It's an obvious attraction to see. Make sure you see it at both day and night to capture the full glory.

Fun, Busy, and pedestrian friendly. I just spent 3 delightful, sunny days in central Lisbon. We walked the city and this busy pedestrian street was a fun corridor to go to the big square on the waterfront. There are countless nice stores, tourist souvenier shops, and many sidewalk cafes and other restaurants. The people watching is great ! I walked it 7 or 8 times .

Lisbon Main Square. Located in Downtown Lisbon, waterfront with great views of Lisbon. Lively, large square with a huge Statue and many Restaurants in the area. This square is a MUST if you visit Lisbon. Beautiful, well kept and access to Train Station(Cascais), Buses, Taxis, tuk-tuk, etc. nearby. Nice place to stroll around, take pictures, eat at the Restaurants located nearby. In the square the Lisbon Story Museum is located and it is a good spot to start your Lisbon visit.

lively square filled with tourists and locals!. What a fun place to be! high end stores, tourist traps, cafes, restaurants, locals enjoying their city, tourists shopping, picture taking and enjoying lisbon!

Busy, bustling and lots of fun!. There are plenty of street performers here to entertain you with many shops to peruse as well. We explored, walking up and down side streets and loved every minute of it. There are entertaining shops as well as the usual clothing and apparel ones too so this is the perfect shopping place whether you're looking for souvenirs or something more.

One of my favorite places in Lisbon!. It's true that this place doesn't have stuff to see, but a beach is nearby, and it's very relaxing to sit around and spend your time. This place also has lots of shops like H&M, and Pull & Bear, and sometimes, there are street performers, so you will never really get bored here.
great for people watching. great place to sit and watch the world go by. bustling and busy with great bars and cafes. easy access to shopping area and tram stops for exploring other districts

Used to be a car park. Nice and large. The sea to the front, the arch to the rear. A huge statue of the king. No crown, looking away from the town, escaping the earthquake perhaps as snakes come above the ground when a quake is about to happen, and the horse has snakes underfoot which may keep away the pidgeons.

Busy square but not a lot to see. It is an attractive square with a few street performers and restaurants around but there is not a lot to do or see.Be warned, if you are a young male be prepared to be offered a lot of drugs. It's no exaggeration to say that I was approached at least 10 times a day and they just target any younger looking male adults. It was a lot worse than Prague and I thought Prague was bad doe that! If you are a family or slightly more mature they will not bother you though.

The Praca is the essence of Lisbon. Must see... This is the heart of Lisbon and one should spend at least part of a day strolling the area, stopping at one of the many cafe's, and watching the people. The arch, the statue, and the open square are seen as you walk the pedestrian street down to the river. This is the essence of Lisbon. Talk a few hours and join the tourists and locals as they enjoy this great area.

The doors of Lisbon. This place used to be the official "entry" of Lisbon. Where the boats arrived, where people moved around and goods were traded. Now renewed, it's one of the most beautiful places in town, with several (great) restaurants, discotecs, flower shops, museums, etc. The view is magnificent: river Tejo and seagulls all around. Sometimes there is also live music and other festivities happening there. A must see in Lisbon.
Very nice square. Very nice square next to the river. We stopped here to have a drink and it was very nice. Big statue in the middle.

Beautiful square. Great square right on the water - great restaurants all around, but would highly suggest grabbing a beer at the Beer Museum and then walking a block to Alfama to eat in that neighbourhood.

Very cool area with lots of Kodak moments. We were here on a week day day when it was raining off and on and the weather was miserable, so I believe we were able to avoid the crowds. It is a very cool area with the river in the background beyond the plaza. The architect is beautiful and one can sit all day in a sidewalk cafe and people watch. You can see the tide moving in and out down by the water and just imagine what it must have been like hundreds and hundreds of years ago when ships docked. There were some very awesome Africian street dancers performing in the plaza and they were the best I have ever seen - they seemed to be performing just for their self enjoyment as no one passed a collection hat around. Without the crowds, we had the luxury of taking some great pictures.
Crazy yet oh so beautiful. Definitely the most beautiful place full of tourists like me :) the square fills out into the ocean and the architecture is just outstanding A definite must to visit

Big and Bustling with Great Views.. This is a great place to survey the waterline sights of central Lisboa. The adjacent buildings and statues, people watching and transportation options for further exploring Lisbon are numerous. Look for "The World/s Sexiest Water Closets" on the east side of the plaza. And, a few blocks away toward the Castle in the Lago de Se' area is a wonderful Wine and Cheese Bar.

excellent. Really nice way to spend the day.I do like my shopping!We spent the afternoon sat with some beers and people watching all afternoon, A large beer will cost you between 3 and 5 euros depending on where you decided to go.Good quality shops with some names you'll know from home. I however prefer the independent boutiques for some original items.

Pleasant Open Square. This is striking because it's so imposing-not because of the quality of the commercial enterprises. There are a few restaurants, a few not-so-interesting museums, and a dozen street hawkers all selling the same stuff. There's a great view of the river and it's on the way to almost everywhere so you can't miss it.

Amazing huge square. In a city with many narrow streets, this Praça lets you breathe and walk without fear of punching someone in the stomach with your bag. It's surrounded by interesting old buildings from three sides and one side leaves open view on the river Tajo. Also, there's a tourist information centre on this square, so if you have any questions about the city, they might be able to help you.

Beautiful surroundings. This is a lovely European square, one of the largest with a grand statue of Dom Jose I on horseback. The square is surrounded by restaurants and shops. The bright white Arco da Victoria is another dominant feature you cannot miss seeing. It is a great place to stroll, take photos and then wander to the sea view. Be wary of questionable characters strolling about watching for unwary tourists. Busses and trams stop out front, street side. You can carry on through the arches, heading uphill through a major shopping area.

Secular square in Lisbon. Secular square in Lisbon where you can take nice pictures with buildings as backgrounds. Former king's palace from the 1500's. Now those buildings are used by the Portuguese Government. River front and some cafés and restaurants where you can taste the amazing Portuguese fresh fish.

Very nice!. Nice photo opportunities overlooking the Tagus River. Go under the archway, and you will find a pedestrian shopping area, including restaurants. There are street musicians. On the day we were there, a young boy was playing the cello and he was good. The metro station is at one corner of the square.
Nice. Very nice place to walk in a wonderful traditional site in Lisbon. Go from this place to camoes square. Not to miss

Typical European Square. If you have been to other main squares in other European cities, this is no different - restaurants, bars, shops, tourist traps etc, also people offering drugs in broad daylight - they are not aggressive once you say no - it is the main meeting point in Lisbon and offers a nice view of the river and Vasco De Gama Bridge. Also central point for metro and tourist buses etc.

Beautiful square. Large square overlooking the estuary (the mouth) of Tagus into the Atlantic. Beautiful buildings all around, one of the main commercial streets ending there, and most importantly the Beer Museum. Go to the Beer Museum not just for the Museum but for the bar, the restaurant (in the same area), and the excellent drinks (not just the beer)!

Perfect city square or plaza!. Great place for strolling, shopping and looking at architecture. Close to the waterfront, the view is great and there is always something happening along the pedestrian walkway. There are restaurants galore, some touristy and some not. It does tend to get crowed when cruise ships are in town, but otherwise, it is worth taking some time and soaking in the ambience!

A grand place for a stroll. This is a lovely place to just take a romantic walk. There is easy access to the water, so one can just sit and view the river for a while if you need a rest. It is a good place to enjoy a cold drink or an ice cream, and relax. Also good for people-watching, and pet-watching. I enjoyed walking there with my husband. You shouldn't miss this area if you are in Lisbon.

Grand Square not to miss. This was once the door of the city of Lisbon for those who came by the river. It is an open square to the riverside where you may spend a few moments living the Tagus river, admiring and taking photos of the view to the 25th April Bridge and Cristo-Rei. It is beautiful specially at sunset. And it's fun to see the cruises leaving the town and saying goodbye here.Turning your back to the river you can admire the enormous yellow buildings around the square with their arcades and the Rua Augusta Arc that imposes its presence. In the middle you have Dom José Statue, one of Portugal kings.Behind the square you have a beautiful view of the city erasing where you may see the Sé, Saint George Castle, Carmo Convent among others.In the arcades sometimes, on the weekend, there is an handicraft fair. And by the sides there is restaurants with lovely esplanades to enjoy.(There's also here a public wc that you can use for 1€ - The best wc in town :-)In August there is a light show projected in the buildings and Arc at night (dates are not the same from year to year). The square fills up with people to see it and it's wonderful.Don't miss the ginginha! And don't miss Martinho da Arcada, which is a green restaurant in one of the corners. It is one of the oldest restaurants in town and it is filled with history of poets and politicians.

Majestic buildings, large square by the river. This is the meeting point for most tourist buses and trams etc. There is a large square overlooking the riverfront and there are beautiful buildings with white arched corridors to shield from the sun. Lovely place for a photograph.

Grand in every way. This place is awesome! In scale, location and ambience. The spring weather added to the enjoyment of strolling on the vast square and watching several street performers in action. The breeze from the sea under a bright sun was too good to be missed. One can spend hours there just lazing around. A great way to unwind.
Nice square. On one side is the river.. Nice square with some cafés and restaurants. Very big so not very cosy. No traffic allowed. Awalk across the square to the river is recommended.
very nice. the atmosphere is very nice, the building is well manteined and you are very near the Tajo river, very nice place to stop and have lunch in one of the restorants located there.

An average site with a good river view. Nothing special to mention about this place.
It is clear that it's history is more interesting than its present. However, a must see point when in Lisbon.

beautiful!. A beautiful square with nice (but expensive) restaurants. The museum of beer has very good codfish-cakes filled with Portuguese cheese. Mmmm. Funny is the public toilet on the square which you can find as 'the most sexy toilet in the world'. They ask an admittance of one Euro, but it's worth it...

Lovely area with some poor restaurants. The restaurants are overpriced and the food ranges from good to dreadful. I had a cheese and tomato roll - one half had no tomato, the other had four thin strips! First restaurant on the right facing the river! avoid! Museum of Beer is fun, the staff were friendly - but pizza with banana??
Lovely place for lunch.. Sit out and enjoy people watching at one of the nice restaurants. Or just enjoy an ice cream down by the river.
Lisbon square.. The big square in the center of Lisbon. You can't visit Lisbon and you don't go there. Nice architecture.

Open air and river view spot.. Nice open plaza open to the river and a few restaurants at the galleries of the side buildings. Be aware of the guys selling sunglasses during day and hashish during night.
Nice place to walk. Terreiro do Paco is a pretty good place to visit as it has shops and restaurants all around. It is nearby the river Tejo and is a nice place to take pictures.

A beautiful area. Just sit in a bar, enjoy a glass of wine, people watch and listen to the street music. Don't forget to look at the lovely arch. I love this area of Lisbon where you will see tourists and locals side by side.
Must see!. I mean, you're in Lisbon. You must stop, see, take a few pics and maybe grab lunch. It's even better if you know the history!

An impressive plaza. A very nice, colorful and vast square fronting the Tagus river, full of people and activity. Probably the heart and soul of the city. There is an equestrian statue of Dom Jose in the center. There are many eateries on the sides where you could just sit at a table and watch.

Glorious terraces to enjoy sun, food and drinks. One of the places to be in Lisboa to enjoy the sun on the terraces (choose wisely though to ensure an afternoon-filling experience), food and drinks.
See locals and tourists stroll past your table and get into all sorts of discussions with your terrace companions.
Lively!. Full of hustle and bustle. Lot's of stores and restaurants. Love sitting on a patio here and watching the people!
good sights and food. very large square with a huge bronze statue , good to walk around , good river view and nice places on the square to eat and drink

Lovely shopping and dining area of Lisbon. Very pretty, iconic and interesting. Lovely old streets leading to the fabulous Commercial Square, with its bars, restaurants, trams and access to the river. Very much worth a visit and a highlight of any trip to Lisbon. Lots of lovely pastelerias to taste the famous Natas and lots of nice places to get a cool beer on a hot day. Worth the trip for sure, make the effort - you won't regret it.
great piazza. During the day is incredible, amazing, really unbelievable. We've spend some time in there and was waw. In the evening be aware of the different sellers of everything.

Great pedestrian zone for shopping and wandering.... We wound up here several times, sometimes by accident and sometimes by design. Plenty to do and see... Shops, stalls, street performers, bars, and restaurants... and statues, and the waterfront, and...oh well, you get the idea! Never boring, that's for sure!
very large square with monuments and restaurants by the ocean. tfantastic weather (lucky), mittle wind, glass of beer on the museum of the portugese beer. ideal place to relax
Very beautiful. This square is very beautiful, it is next to the sea so it's quite windy, but it's really beautiful. We went there at least 3 times and it's majestic.

beautiful. definitely worth visiting in Lisbon, gorgeous place. I also recommend the cafe, which is apparently the oldest Cafe in Lisbon, and to eat the pastel de nata there, a typical portuguese pastry
former royal grandeur now a place for public protest. a (small) protest by prison workers was in swing when we entered the square - democracy in action in a great setting.

Praca do Comercio. Beautiful spacious square open to Tagus river at one side; on the other side, you will step through the arch and find yourself in a nice street (pedestrian zone) with many little cafes, restaurants... Take your time to walk around, explore, enjoy amazing architecture and of course - people.
wow. Vibrant, naturally beautiful, elegant and right by the water. Atmosphere was great, so light hearted and relaxed. The rea is so clean too.

Beautiful Square. A truly majestic space right by the river. A must if you are in Lisbon. It's large and lined with stunning bright yellow buildings as you enter by the stunning Arc de Triumph. You can stop off at the restaurants there and dine al fresco if the sun is out before heading off somewhere else for more sumptuous sightseeing in this charming city.

Beautiful Plaza. This big, open plaza facing the Tagus and the sea is a great place to sit and enjoy the shoreline. The first time we went was early morning--just as the city was starting to wake up--and it was beautiful. So peaceful! There are several places to eat around the square, but it's also the perfect place for a picnic. A must-see in Lisbon.

The heart of it all. Beautiful, though touristy part of Lisboa. Definitely should be part of your itinerary, with a stop for lunch or dinner at any of the cafes or restaurants in the area. A taxi stand makes this a good place to be dropped and go exploring in any direction. We toured with a toddler in a stroller--a little tough on some of the narrow cobblestone streets, but doable. The hop-on-hop-off bus drops off here.

Spacious!. Nest to the river. Again there is a very nice view. It's usually very sunny and it's always a good starting point of a long walk along the river or inside the city center. There is a museum of beer and other really nice places to have something to eat or drink. A lot of people pass through the square daily!

Good for people watching. Great place for many things - people watching, drinking coffee, meeting others. Wide open space by the water. Saw a military ship in the harbour and then a submarine coming up the harbour the next day. All different ages of people milling around. Lovely atmosphere and a great place to watch the sun set.
Beautiful. Many history in this square. Got the free tour there and we were told many things about the place. Touristic, ideal for eating out or just chilling out!

A Wonderful Stroll. Lots of sidewalk cafes and boutiques to browse along this alleyway. If you're planning your day, put this stop on your list for lunch or dinner. A great place to have a drink, grab a bite to eat and people watch at the same time!
Fun. Great area to sit at one of the cafes, watching people or enjoying the mild weather. Easy access to shopping & street vendors, there is a cab stand, & all buses pass thru this area.
Huge and beautiful square. Bursting with tourists and locals alike this is a beautiful square. If you're in Lisbon this is one of the "must see".

most beautiful square in Lisbon. Don't let the guys trying to sell you sunglasses, or even worse, drugs, throw you off and enjoy the beauty of this square. It is magnificent, especially at sunset. We had dinner here and even though it's a very touristy place, prices were not that bad!

Place to be. We came to Lisbon for Christmas - and the holiday festivities, ice rink and booths of local artisans were on the square through the first week of January 2015, while in Germany everything was closed about Dec. 22. Several restaurants left and right, all targeted the tourists, therefore overpriced and with poor service. If you walk one block under the arch, you can find small eateries for locals with good food/ service and reasonable prices.

Old Town. Hello Travellers here´s a good place to go shopping, eat, drink, walk, you can choose many thing to do starting in downtown. This is a Excellent starting point to go to St George Castle, Alfama, Chiado etc.Go and explore it Recomend it!!

Huge square. It is huge but not too much to do here. You have a huge square with open front and loads of restaurants, bar around. We took tuck tuck around Lisbon viewpoints from there, it was nice but street are very uneven so not really comfortable. I prefer Belem or Parque Das Nacoes area.

Utterly Charming..... This square is must stop visit...............a massive expanse of a square with the River Tagus lapping at its edge on one side.You have delightful cafe/restaurants on two sides and the best time to visit is late afternoon when the sun is setting. It gives you a sense of well being just being there.In the middle stands King Jose 1st and he proudly sits in all his glory surveying all before him.Look for the Tram 28...that gets you there wherever you are on its route.

Hidden pleasures. The East side of the square was lined with open-air restaurants and bars, and we had ...an interesting lunch in one of them. Was expecting a steak and fries, and got a steak and crisps. Never can tell if patatas fritas means french fries or potato chips.We went during the 2014 World Cup. England went out pretty quickly, and Portugal weren't far behind them. Nevertheless the Lisbanos were determined to party. There had been a music festival outside our hotel the night before, in Martim Moniz, and this day they were setting up a giant outdoor TV screen in Comercio for a football match and another pop concert.Behind the restaurants and quite hidden are a couple of museums. The Lisbon Story was an entertaining couple of hours, with headphones and dioramas, and a little movie of the earthquake, which really set up another day when we saw the view from the Law Courts down through the Parque Eduardo VII, across Marques Pombal and down Av. de Liberdade to the Baixa, and we could imagine what the earthquake would have been like.There is also a Beer museum next to the Lisbon Story, and I was sorry we didn't have time for it. Still, have to leave some things for our next visit.

Love this square. When you visit Arco Triumphal da Rua Augusta, you are already in Commerce Square. The square is surrounded by symmetrical buildings, that make it so grand. The statue of King Jose I on his horse set proudly on the square facing the River Tagus. We had a nice stroll at the river bend, they plan the trees in the colourful concrete bowl. That’s a good idea.You don’t have any trouble to find cafés and souvenirs in this area.Happy Travelling!

Nice square. Not much to see or do here but it is an iconic view of Lisbon and so a 'must go to' place on a visit to the city. There are several places to have drinks or food and sit in the sunshine, people watching.

One of the main Square in Baixa. Our hotel is just located within walking distance to here and we had to pass by here almost everyday. The monument in the square was stunning and the Arch was beautifully crafted. Tagus river is just opposite the square. There are a few cafes/restaurants around the square. You can also find a lot of shops and restaurants along Rua Agusta that is link to Praca do Comercio.

Easy way to get everywhere. Beautiful square, close to the river and with one of the most beautifuls sunsets you can get in Lisbon. Also lot of restaurants and diferent options of public transportation to everywhere.

Beautiful old buildings and boulevard. This area starts down on the river and goes up hill from there. (everything in Lisbon is either up hill or down!) The entrance is a wonderful old yellow building that used to be a palace with an archway that you walk under...lots of shops and tourists...get a few blocks off the beaten path and that is fun too.

Stunningly Beautiful. One of the biggest squares in Europe... Even though there are a lot of people you can keep feel the spaces that surrounds you... Is the central square of Lisbon on the Tejo River surrounded by the Republican palaces...

Shopping place. This area is very close to the shopping stores in Lisbon.The plaza itself is surrounded by typical old buildings that made it impressive.Surrounding the plaza there are a lot of restaurant around.Across the plaza, there is a long street contains many famous brand stores.

beautiful place but with many tourists. beautiful place and absolutely typical. whether at night or in the day, there is always nice. here is ideal for enjoying in small bars or restaurants, but with many tourists . But watch out!

Fabulous European Square. This ranks with the other squares in Europe for a must go visit. Right off the water, full of cafes and performers, the Lisbon story Center and Lisbon Shop..Go to a cafe and watch the people...

be vigilant and aware of drug dealers and avoid worthless souvenirs. Although the area is worth a visit and Lisbon is great, I had the feeling that I was wandering through a suburb in the tenth biggest city of France/Spain/Italy. The streets were dull with just uninteresting shops, restaurants and hotels. And not to forget, gift shops with countless useless rubbish. I hate to say this, but after seeing a few you have seen them all because they all seem to sell the same rooster statues, plates and magnets. I hardly didn't get a chance to get a glimpse on the magnets that were usually displayed outside because the vendors jump you immediately and harass you with pushy remarks. If that wasn't bad enough, the merchandise is overpriced and hardly what you are looking for. I have tried to buy a souvenir oven glove and it was poor quality, probably fake too, I could still feel oven heat when I used it. T-shirts and football jerseys were poor imitations and never the real sizes it claimed to be. Large sizes never fit me and even the XXL were tight. I am not even a hulking or chubby tall man, so if I can't fit a XXL then who can? Is this a prank? Not to mention the very aggressive waiters that lurk in streets to harass virtually every passer-by they can see. I have spend an unusual amount of time in Lisbon and in 45 days I was almost harassed at least ten times. Inevitably it began to become such an ordeal that I started to avoid walking slash staying there. Watch out for beggars who are also on the alcantara viewpoint, but it has occurred to me a couple of times that they hang around Rossio station with nonsense made up stories. Walking around in the streets of Lisbon is quite a bit of chore on your feet because all of the city seems to have cobble-tiled sidewalks which are bumpy and have a lot of dips and sometimes cobbles missing. After a while I was starting to get blisters and then even extra socks or insoles didn't help anymore. Although Lisbon drivers are very patient and nice to pedestrians, the traffic is intense and it doesn't help a lot that most streets in this area are still made of brick which amplifies the loud noise of rolling rubber. If I may give you one last tip, don't try to remember any names of the streets, forget about it. The street signs are usually high on the walls and for some inconceivable reason have white boards with white letters on them, which to me are very difficult to read. And why is it always names like Rua Santo Antonia dos Capouchos or R.Antonio Maria Cordosa. Try to get familiar with the area to get around, that is way better than trying to search for the street names.

Expansive. We got down here a couple of time during our stay-- at sunset for some great pictures, on a Saturday to see everyone out for a promenade. It is on the way or near to so many places, that it is easy to pass more than once.
A Beautiful Square. A beautiful square next to the river. There are some cafe and restaurants. You should go to the square at sunset. There are amazing views.

Shops, restaurants, bars, river. It's a lovely place, a huge square on the waterfront comes the entrance under the enormous arch. There are several streets of shops, restaurants and bars, and it's a very good way to spend an afternoon :)

Sweeping. At the foot of the city with grand architecture on all sides and a dominant statue on formidable plinth in the center this plaza is an attraction for everyone coming to Lisbon. From this place the city fans out in all directions. Come here first.

Interesting architecture spoiled by criminals. Like most of Lisbon this area is quite beautiful with great views of the river, VdG bridge, plenty of restaurants and stunning architecture, goof for a stroll and photo opportunity.However any visit is spoiled by the continual harassment received from drug-pushers, street-vendors and beggars. The local police seem unable or unwilling to deal with these criminals and as a result you never feel very safe walking the streets here.Worth visiting but be very wary of anyone approaching you and maintain plenty of personal space!

Lovely Square. A beautiful square by the river . restaurants to sit and watch the world go by . Most tours can be joined from here and metro and tram stops also in the square. Pedestrian shopping are nearby with great value to be had .
Great place for lunch. Several cafes where you can have lunch over-looking the river. Great views! We stopped off here when we were on the sightseeing bus.
the biggest in Europ ?. splendid, big and beautifull Around world only a few are so big and harmoniouse The hart of Lisbon From here you can see the castle and put the feets on the Tajo river

Triumph arch. The aquare made to glorify the reconstruction of Lisbon after the earthquake 1755. Go up the elevator, it is worthy. In the middle you have king Joseph I, riding his horse, actualy better looking than the king himself.
Beautiful square on the banks of the Tagus. Beautiful square on the banks of the Tagus river. Great views of the river and through the Arch Rua Augusta

Hub of the post-earthquake Lisbon. Built on the designs of the Marquis de Pombal when Lisbon was rebuilt after the 1755 earthquake, it is I think one of the great squares in the world. Open on one side to the Tagus estuary, it is an immense square in a sober late baroque style, crowned by a triumphal arch. It is surrounded by the hills to which Lisbon climbs. The Sao Jorge fortress and the cathedral are on its Eastern side.Coloured in egg yolk yellow and blonde sandstone, it changes looks all day long, and it is a wonderful place at sunset. Lots of nice bars and restaurants.
Great place to visit. Easy to get to by metro, tram or tour bus. A few cafes to choose in the square from where you can watch the world go by. Easy access to shops from here too.
wow. when you arrive here for the first time,you see this huge square -you think 600 years ago all the sailors and vendors were arriving here and you just can say wow!
Nice square.. but..... It is a very nice place in front of the lake, you can start from here your visit to the city. The negative aspect is related to the many drugs dealers...
Beautiful City. Defiantly a regularly visited area on our trip. Beauitful architecture all around and some great food around here. Day or Night it is must go see.

Nice place for people watching. Nice arch, symetric buildings and a view of the river. Lots of restaurants and cafés great for people watching makes this a nice place to drop by. Close to several metro stations and thus easy to find.

Pleasant Plaza. We visited Praca do Comercio twice on our seven day trip to Lisbon. The square is on the river with a very impressive arch. The d'Agua restaurant on the south side is very good. The square is also where the trams stop so it is convenient for multiple reasons.
Very pleasant area. Great to stop for coffee or eat. Very well kept and clean area. Easy to get to other areas of the city from here

go there.. It is a nice warm square...reflect the soul of Lisbon , there in that huge wide square you will find tourists riding the segway...people around shoot photos , the stand of hand crafts and the famous shopping street for pedesterians only with lots of cafes and restaurants in the middle....you will enjoy your time there..no doubt.

Glass of wine in the sun. This is the ideal place to sit in one of the many cafes and have a glass of wine in the sun as you watch the world go by. Really gorgeous square and the main place to catch the bus or tram elsewhere.

Good place to spend the day. There are alot of bars, cafes and retail and souvenir shops along the way leading up to the square. There are restaurants bordering the square and there is just really nice arhitectually sounds buildings and monuments that makes this place great to take photos

The end. It was late September night and we just grabbed a few beers and strolled down this very empty street where all shops and restaurants were long closed and we ended up at Tejo river at the square that seemed like the end of whole Lisbon. The river was all black in pitch black night and we only heard it and felt it from the wind chill coming from it. Street lamps beautifully illuminated the square, triumphal arch and us. The caps sizzled, glasses clinked and it was a great night!

Delightful Place to View the Water. My wife and I visited this square many time on our recent visit to Lisbon. It is a great starting place for many of the local attractions and shopping areas. The Castelo do Sao Jorge overlooks this entire area.There are a number of outdoor restaurants surrounding the square. We had a beer at one of these outside the Museum of Beer.

Perfect for sunny days. Right after I dropped my bags off at the hotel, I walked to Chiado until I reached the praça. The sun was out, the Tejo was glimmering in the sunlight and the bars around were filled with people having coffee. It was lovely. The next day I passed through the praça on my way to Alfama but the sky was gloomy and it rained a bit so it was quite empty.

Lovely photo spot with lots of bars. Loads of bars and shops on the way down to the square then a nice large square with restaurants and bars lining it. Great photo opportunities here with the water one side and beautiful architecture all around! Worth a visit and a great area to explore from as it's near alfalma.

Excellent area of Lisbon . The arch leading to this part of Lisbon is very imposing and certainly once you cross under it, you come upon an area that is a true delight to walk around in. The arch itself is great for photophiles and the water lies just in the distance. I would definitely not skip this area during a visit to Lisbon!

A stately neoclassical square facing the shimmering Tejo. Take a walk through this pedestrian walkway known as the Baixa.The architecture of the arch is ornate and known as an entrance ti the walkway or the river.Lots of shopsmvendors, artists restaurants and tourism. You can also pick up many arranged tours here if you prefer.Historic and central and once through tge arch, many shops under the arches ti explore as well as the bronze 18th century staue ar the center overlooking the river.

The remaining splendor of the Empire. A place tha reminds us tha Portuguese was once a mighty empire, filled with Glory and riches. During the Golden age a main port for ships of the merchant fleet a place of trading. Now a reminder of the former Glory. Worth the visit and nice to take photos. You wont regret it.

Cant be missed. You will eventually walk into the Praca do Comercio while in Lisbon. Take your time and walk the square to see whats on offer, you wont be disappointed.

Really nice street square. This is a really nice spot. Long straight street leading through an elaborate archway into a wide open square with sea lapping on one side.Looking back up the street you can catch sight of the street trams crossing from left & right.On the square side of the arch you have the picturesque querky taxis looking a big like mechanised tuk - tuks
historical place. nice square and important place for Portugal history. there are restaurants around as well as shops. beautiful place

Another must see in Lisbon. This attraction is the end of Baixa Pombalina, faces the river towards Cais das Colunas. Also part of it, the Arco da Rua Augusta worths a visit. Full of movida with cafés and restaurants facing the river.

No, I Don't Want Cocaine.. This street, while beautiful in terms of architecture, is not a very pleasant place to explore. Strolling around midday as a solo male, I was asked on five different occasions by different people if I wanted to buy cocaine or marijuana. The first time was just surprising, but after five times it just got annoying. On top of this nearly all of the shops are overpriced, as are the restaurants. Many of the cafés advertise wifi, when they actually don't have it. This area is worth a look for the architecture, but you're likely to pass through here just going from one place to another. Walk under the arch at the end to the plaza on the Tagus, take some pictures and then eat, drink and shop elsewhere.

Skip Lisbon. Lisbon was an absolute disappointment. Dirty with loads of "unsavories". It's a port city so I understand that it would attract wanderers. But it felt super unsafe even in the commercial tourist district. It could be so nice it the government put some money into cleaning up the area.
Nothing much. It`s a pretty place with some history and a big archway that looks down to the river but there`s nothing much to see or do there.

Imposing.... A spacious square on the water with a massive statue of Dom Jose1 who was later executed in the square.

Good photo opportunity.

Here visitors can get information about the city or shop at a store for traditional Portuguese products.For those arriving on a cruise ship and docking at the city pier, the square is a 10 minute walk from the city cruise terminal.
Nice Plaça. The Praça do Comércio situated near the Tagus river. Nice to take some photos, eat an icecream, walk or just relax from your tour in Lisbon.
Amazing space. This square is huge, and has a very refined feel to it. Designed after the 1755 earthquake razed the city, it is grand in nature and leads to the main commercial area from the river.

Right on the River Tagus. Wonderful open space and gateway to the City. Good restaurants around the edges outside historic custom house buildings. Many buses/trams stop at the edge. Or walk along the waterfront broadwalk to Belem Tower.

fantastic time. visited the Praca during the world cup, it was brilliant. great atmosphere and excellent set out to enjoy the games. Still managed to take in the beatiful buildings and statues in the square. Excellent memory.

Excellent!. I love this square. When I arrive at Lisbon the first thing I do is go down the Avenida da Liberdade and only stop at praça do comércio...it is sunny, fresh, beatifull...words are not sufficient to describe this place. just love it.
