Kind of sad. It's obvious this was once a hub of Lisbon and is definitely worth a stop on any trip through the city. But these days, it's kind of a sad place. Praca do Comercio is not really on its way to any other attractions and doesn't have much to offer other than a nice arch, a large statue, and a decent view of the river and bridge. Mostly there are a bunch of overpriced restaurants and little people-watching (no one seems to come here except tourists). There is a tourist information here, but the one by Restauradores is much more conveniently located for sightseeing purposes. You'll probably end up in Praca do Comercio at some point, but if you don't, you're not missing much.*if you like my review, I hope you'll click the 'helpful' button; those of us who write reviews live for those and it motivates us to do more :) *

Gigantic. We visited Lisbon just after the Champion's League final and unfortunately the entrance in the square was prohibited, hence we couldn't experience first hand what this gigantic square looks like when it is full of people. However, you could easily walk around the square and imagine its daily magnificence. Impressive and glorious with a really nice view of the sea.

Beautiful arch. This is in a commercial or shopping street of Lisbon where you will see this beautiful big arch. You will never miss this as most tourists are clinging around here. You will pass through this to get to the other end of the street.
Nice place for a beer. It's a good place for tourists to drink a beer, after a long walk, but it doesn't represent the true charm of Lisboa.

Huge Plaza. This plaza use to be the main market place for the city and is massive. The real draw is the Arch that leads into the Baixa neighborhood. You can get some really lovely photos on this square and is definitely worth a stop.

One of the most beautiful squares in Europe. Finally you can view this beautiful square without scaffolding obscuring the surrounding buildings or the statue in the center, now that the seemingly endless construction work is actually finished (I hope). It is one of the most elegant public spaces in Europe, with the river on one side, a triumphal arch opposite and elegant classical buildings forming the sides of the square.
The place to be. This is a great square with one, if not the best location in Lisbon. Take the 28 tram (in front of the Parca) and tour around the city, fun a cheap way to see Lisbon.

Great view by the River side. The river front area is a great place to relax and enjoy the wind in lisboa. You also get a view of the Vasco Da Gama bridge from the square as well as numerous historical and government buildings. The place is buzzing with cafes, restaurants and shopping boutiques. Live performances including music, dance and mimicry keep happening at the square.A must visit when you are in lisbon

A must do but beware drug dealers & thief's. A must do when you are in Lisbon!The prace do comercio;the yellow square with the arch, with a direct view on the Taag... A must see when you are in Lisbon.Only 1 BIG problem; the place is full with drugs dealers & people who are after your money. Take pictures, ignore people who want to speak with you & go somewhere else.We where there for 30 minutes: 3 drug dealers approached us & 1 person aggressively asked us for money...
A to do in Lisbao. Also a do is Rua Augusto, just next. Big and nice, facing seafront. Recommend from there walk to Rocio, close by.

Great place for people watching. This river front area is always lively and buzzing, and popular with tourists and locals alike. Street musicians always seem to be playing, and there vendors will sell you anything from an umbrella to sunglasses - one enterprising vendor noted that I was wearing prescription glasses, and immediately produced a pair of clip-on glasses to tempt me to buy!!You can catch a tram or bus at the top of the square, and there's a metro stop close by, on the river front. You can also go up to the top of the monumental archway for great views out over the river. The shopping centre is just behind the square, through the archway and is a mixture of pedestrian streets, and those allowing traffic. This area is popular with "living statues" which I find fascinating - how do they manage to stay so still and balance without wobbles?!Just a word of warning, it's a busy place and pick-pockets are known to operate here - keep valuables out of sight and hold tight to your bags. You'll also find quite a few beggars, some of whom pretend to be physically handicapped, we saw one of them walking normally until he saw a potential donor. I'm sure some of them are genuine but just be aware what happens.This is one of the first places you will see if you arrive by cruise ship and walk up from the cruise terminal - don't bother with the shuttle bus, just head along the river front, it's quicker than the bus and a great introduction to a very vibrant city!

At Lisbon's monumental Plaza Mayor. "Praça do Comércio" is more commonly known by the "Alfacinhas" (all those born in Lisbon) as "Terreiro do Paço". This is a historical reference, as between the 16th and the 18th centuries, it housed the Portuguese crown's royal palace, known as "Paço da Ribeira". The 1755 earthquake destroyed completely the palace and its famous library. "Praça do Comércio", with its yellow buildings and beautiful arcades, was built shortly after the earthquake, as part of the heroic efforts of the Marquis of Pombal to reconstruct the city. This magnificent square, considered one of the largest "plazas" of Europe, is sided by the "Rio Tejo" (Tagus River) and its iconic and noble "Cais das Colunas" (Columns Quay), where all important guests disembarked from their vessels. On the northern side, the fantastic "Arco Triunfal da Rua Augusta", an imposing arch meaning the entrance of the so called quarter of "Baixa Pombalina". At the center of "Praça do Comércio", an equestrian statue of King D. José I, who commanded its construction. Its name - "Praça do Comércio" - was chosen in order to honor those that heavily contributed to Lisbon's rebirth after the earthquake: the traders! Today, department offices occupy the yellow buildings and, under the arcades, restaurants, cafés and souvenir shops are tourist's deligths. The "Praça do Comércio" is indeed Lisbon's "Plaza Mayor"! A monumental square complex that cannot be missed by all those visiting Lisbon! One last remark: evening visits at your own risk. Enjoy!

a crowded landmark. I have visited Lisbon the first time in 2008 and in one evening we arrived at Praca do Comercio and been approached twice by drug dealers. This weel we have been again in Lisbon and the number of tourist has exponentially grown, and as well the number of drug dealers that approach anyone there and don't even bother be carefull when they are trying to sell the stuff. so be aware who is next to you and who approaches. you.
view from the top of the Arco da Vitoria. Great views of the square & all that's going on. On the way there, have a look at the gallery decorated with surf-boards!! Quirky!

Another must see attraction in Lisbon. Praco do Comercio is an expansive square right along the Tagus River. We made several visits over 3 days and there was always something going on in the square. It is not to be missed.

Beautiful square with terraces. Loved the triumpharc and the galleries ... and the terraces. So nice and lovely at night with the lights. A small drawback was the unwanted offering of marihuana not once but three times we crosses the square.
Beautiful place. Very large, excellent situated (right beside the Tejo), a real marvel of the great city of Lisbon. Go there, its a must.

Spacious. Beautiful spacious square surrounded by historical buildings. Take a sit at the statue in the center to watch mostly tourists drift by. The always present dope-pushers are a bit of a annoyance, though.

Amazing Place. We walked through it and admired the cruise ships coming and all the people come out to walk and site seeing in Lisbon.other ships leaving and saying goodby,we sat near the water with so many other people looking at all restaurants and many stores around that large place ,very peaceful,relaxing and enjoying many goodies that we could buy around.we could the Statue of Cristin Rei,the Beautiful Bridge full of cars coming and going the beautiful StatueThe restaurants are so many we could not count,the food they serve is excellent there is never a disappointed meal.

One of the largest squares in Europe. Is a square in downtown Lisbon situated beside the Tagus river, in the area that was the site of the palace of the kings of Portugal for nearly two centuries. It is one of the largest squares in Europe, with some 36 000 m² (180m x 200m). It is the center of Lisbon, as well as its main square. There´s a lot of good restaurants with terrace there.

Must see bit of Lisbon's history. Large waterfront square facing Tagus river with view of the Christo Rei. Also near the Triumphal Arch entering into the Baixa/Chiado area. You will see a little piece of Lisbon's beach area and entrance to ferries across the river. Nearby are cafes and places to rest.

Enjoy!. Now that the square is recovered and only for walking it is a beautiful place to be, to appreciate the buildings around, to go up the Arch, or to seat and enjoy a drink in one of the restaurants while watching the sunset over the Tagus River, looking at 25th April Bridge and Cristo Rei statue.
The sunlight is unforgetable. You must see to feel and know what the real sunlight means. It's kinda magic. And the buildings that surrounds the square are just magnificent.

Very grand and very festive place. It was build after the earthquake, so they had an intention to make some grand entrance from the sea and did it well. It does look like a facade of a great empire. It's also filled with shops, people, music, dining tables right in the middle of the street (which makes it even more lively and welcoming). There are a couple disturbing things going on. One they have a lot of people begging money, some are missing limbs or having some other conditions. Second, there are a lot of guys offering to sell you drugs on the street. After talking to the locals, it appears that a lot of these "drugs" are actually fake or the dealers will report you to police so they can extract some money from the people who decide to try to buy. So it's an enjoyable place, just use your common sense and stay away from the troubles.
Super. It is located in the heart of Lisbon. We had some great photos taken there. Lovely walk during the day with a lot of shops and cafés to get some rest.

The holiday starts here. Arriving at the Lisbon airport is nice. Taking the metro into the city and then submerge at the Rossio square is good. Walking through the Rua Augusta is great. But your holiday really start when you enter this marvelous square and overlook the river, the 25th April bridge and the Cristo Rei statue.

Great. The Praça do Comércio (commerce square) was the centerpiece of the reconstruction after the earthquake of 1755. Its main attraction is a monumental equestrian statue of king José I.
A place worth visiting!
Greatest square of Europe!. This very very big square at the river side. You might wanna avoid the square late at night cuz of the various offers of drugs.

You're bound to come here anyway. If you go strolling around town (which you will), you will inevitably make your way here ... and you'll inevitably enjoy the atmosphere and the architecture. Nothing in particular will jump out and make you go "wow" but you'll still have a lovely stroll.
fantastic. closed to the river and very big starting with Arco Rua Augusta is an icon of Lisbon . A lot of terrazas and restaurants surrounding it . A little windy , in anyway for terrazas
MAgnificent historical center. One of the most beatiful landscapes towards the river. This place sounds and feels like history, when lisbon was the center of the world

Truly Lisbon.. Spend some time wandering up and down it really is nice. The bustle of the street is great, walk off the street to take a break and get a drink or something to eat. There's some lovely shops and some amazing cake shops.

A nice place to have a drink. This place is in front of the sea and around it there is a lot of cafes and bars to chill out, it is also close to a very comercial area. Great place to have a drink. I am not rating as great because the service in this places are not fantastic but it is ok.

A has-to-be-seen place by the river. An impressive view. I first saw this on my early morning walk then in the evening.In the morning no one was around and it was nice but in the evening the area had colour and many people sitting around enjoying the area.We'll worth the visit if only to sit and enjoy the experience.

Very Attractive. If you are in the city for a few days this becomes a good way to orientate yourself. The square his huge and never felt overcrowded. Walking along the front to the train station if you are heading along the coast is far more pleasant than through the city.  The architecture is grand and impressive with the sun shining off the polished floor, a must if you are wandering around the city.

Nice Area of Lisbon. Nice area to have a walk around and stop for a few drinks. Very busy with tourists. We got our first tram from this area and once we worked out which direction to go in, it was an easy trip. Nice to go and sit in front of the river and soak in the atmosphere. Also a few people begging for money, they can be a bit pushy, but you'll get used to it.Worth a visit here though. Nice photo opportunities.

Great place to stop and relax. Beautiful square that opens up on to the Tagus River, there are lots of bars surrounding the square which offer beer, wine, sangria etc and food at reasonable prices. Quick visit, good for photos. Best suggestion is to walk down Rua Augusta -- through the giant arch -- towards to Praca do Comercio waterfront plaza area and the waterfront Tagus River vista. The reality is that this area makes for some good pictures (giant imposing structures, wide open plazas, nice colors, and waterfront views). But that is about it. There is nothing really to do here except stroll around, look at the few statutes, and take pictures.

amazing scenery onto the atlantic and Rua Augusta. This is where you will get to see the atlantic as its at the end of Rua Augusta.Went there for breakfast. Average restaurants all around.Watch as there are some people out there who would offer you drugs (hashish and marijuana)
Nice way to get a feel for Lisbon. We walked about 8 blocks down to the Tagus River through Edward VII Park. Nice views of the river, 23 April Bridge and Christ the Redeemer statue and it's free.

PARTY IN PORTUGAL. Hello I will share my experience here in Praca do Comerci, a place we can enjoy and relax. i love the place the buildings. I love to share with my friends here in my country, i am a photographer. i uploaded photos in Portugal. My friends were amazed about my photographs. They planning to visit and also enjoy :) Have a nice day Whely

Shopping, drinking, and eating.. Tons of places to shop and eat and drink. Big, lots of construction, lots of people, restaurants seemed all alike and the ones I tried were mediocre and overpriced for what u get. It is a decent way to spend an afternoon but if you are not into shopping you could skip it.
Beautiful!. Nice square down by the seaside. Here you can enjoy strolling around seeing the sights, relax by some of the restaurants thats here or just sit and watch the ocean from the promenade.

GIANT SQUARE with a great Tejo view. i stay here a lot of times... every time i have time to come here...i do it!Here you can get fabulous photos... this have a light that you can't explain to your friends without photos... but, i thonk you just can explain it in the site...SO LET'S GO THERE!!!!!!

HAVE A DRINK.. Great place to chill out and have a drink wonderful atmosphere and plenty going on was there on their holiday in April and it was buzzing plenty of music and a carnival like feeling about the place. Great place to take in the sights with the hustle and bustle of the town on one side of the archway and the tranquility of the sea on the other side a must see on your visit to Lisbon.

great city to visit. during a long stop-over at Lisbon airport I got the Metro (6.50 Euro) to head to town.easy, clean and safe metro system gets you around very easy.i really liked the old city with the big squares and impressing buildings.also the old city with tram lines and narrow streets can be highly recommended.great city for a few days trip
The Sound of Opportunity. Open space, relaxed atmosphere - and the pull of the sea beckoning you to travel more; what a great place to chill out with a drink after a day traipsing around Lisbon

must see in Lisbon. This should be something equivalent to Times Square in NYC or Big Ben in London, it's mandatory! If you go to Lisbon, you have to go to Praca do Comercio and it's well worth it! enjoy the architecture and the river views!

The first place to go when you visit Lisbon. As a first impression, it's exceptional. If you've already seen some of the other wonders of Lisboa, it doesn't maintain the strong impact on a tourist.You can actually sit around for a while on the waterfront and simply take in the whole surroundings and the size of Lisboa. For some very narrow stretches, there's even some sand to sunbathe, if you fancy a bit of suntan.Anyway, it's well worth the visit.

Nice place to people watch. Watched the Brazil v Germany world cup game and it was a great spot to soak up the atmosphere! The Beer Museum was cute and the 'Sexiest WC on Earth' was worth a look but didnt really live up to its billing ;-) Attractive architecture and easy to get a cab

....too empty!. although in the best part of the city.... the square is ... too empty!. Only some shops but it looks like a lot more can be done. Of course you can have a look at the river-sea and do some shopping to the famous streets nearby!

amazing. I've learned this is the biggest "plaza" in Europe, its quite impressive, the square is sided with the Tagus river and has lots outdoor restaurants and bars. This was the place where the ministers decided Portugal's policy for centuries

Vast square. This square is soooo vast! And its location near water is great. You can sit there and let the wind play with your hair while seagulls are flying around you. You can see nice yellow buildings, statue, arc, historical trams. Nice place to relax for a while.
Great open space to enjoy the ocean view. It was crowded that day, but when you take a seat with the ocean view you can really feel the contrast of busy city life and calming waves of the ocean.

Biggest open space in downtown Lisbon. The square is surrounded with shops and bars. Definitely worth a visit. There is a beautiful arch (Arco da Rua Augusta) with symmetrical buildings on the sides and a bronze statue of the king in the middle. The square leads to the Tagus River. It has a cool Beer Museum and a tourist information facility.

Spot where you can go many times in your trip. It's where you can eat, people watch and relax. The Museum of modern Design and Fashion is free! Lots of restaurants to choose from; entertainers abound; a seaside area where exhausted travellers can relax, rest and enjoy the sea breeze and watch people doing all sorts of things around. The statue with its buildings are the best quality and biggest scale found in Portugal.

Big and calm square near Tejo. Big and calm square near Tejo. Nice to take a walk after dinner and sit near the river for a nice talk if you live near by.Have also a very huge offer of coffee shops but they're very expensive

Great square. We watched the World Cup games from our restaurant seats on the square. Scenic, great restaurants and museums abound. Even though people were able to drink on the street, there was never a hint of trouble. Loved it!

And interesting 360º view. Very nice spot for chilling.There's a nice view from the Augusta Arch, also the Thames River and the Vasco da Gama bridge. A nice thing is have a wine on the bank and just watch people and things happening around.There are a lot of restaurants around, but I haven't tried any. They're a lot expensive because of the touristy area.

Great open space for soaking in the ocean air. The biggest open space in the downtown district, this plaza is perfect for roaming around and enjoying the European architecture while soaking in the fresh ocean breeze. The Arca da Triunfal provides a fitting gateway to this vast expanse of public space, which is used for concerts, flea markets, and merely for people watching. A must-visit if you're in Lisbon.

Lots of nice restaurants and they don't rip you off!. This us the heart of Lisbon, lots of local restaurants, nice walk down to the river and thus us where you can pick up the open top hop on hop off bus

Great place to visit. The square is surrounded with shops and bars. It is a large square with lots happening. At the end is the arch, Arco da Rua Augusta and in the centre is a lovely statue. During our stay the World Cup was on and they have set up a fanzine. We saw the Portugal v Germany game and the atmosphere was great. They had set up a stand and plenty beer booths. The square during both day and night is a great place to be

Maine square. Lots of options of restaurants, nice architecture. Has a cool Beer Museum and a tourist information facility. But the best restaurant option is a 5 minute walk away, the 'João do Grão' at Coureiros St.

Best walking area in Lisbon. Long street with old buildings on both sides, mostly converted into show-rooms ending with a beautiful arch and a beach view. Definitely worth a visit. Late evening walk is quite nice due to lights.

Beware the beach!. A large historic square-plaza in the center of Lisbon. Approaching the square you pass through an arch (Arco da Rua Augusta). In the center of the square us a statue of the king. At the far side of the square is the Tagus River estuary. There is a place called Cais das Colunas where you can sit and look out over the water but beware the beach it is filthy, covered in washed up detritus and dead rats! (see photos) Don't let your children go on to the beach what ever you do. Shame they don't keep this area clean.

Lovely long street. Beautiful view of the sea and the main arch in Lisbon. Shops on either side. Try heading from here to the Avenida Liberado and then dipping off the main drag into the side streets.....very worth while for cheaper restaurants and cafes. Don't eat on the main street unless you have a lot of loose change!

Worth Seeing. Large historic square- commercial plaza.As you approach the square one passes thru this beautiful arch (Arco da Rua Augusta) with symmetrical buildings on the sides. With a bronze statue of the king in the middle.I visited on the a public holiday so the military was on show.One could sit on the steps for hours and stare across the Tagus River.

The place to gather. The commercial plaza and a large, beautiful arch like an entrance to the river is interesting because of a story our guide told us. The city suffered a major earthquake centuries ago on All Saints' Day, and virtually everyone was in one of the many stone churches. Portugal is primarily Catholic. As they fled, stones dropping as the ran, they headed for Commercial Square because it was a large open space with only the arch. But as they stood on the vast plaza, a tsunami formed on the river and most all were swept away. A point to remember: Lisbon is best seen with a native Portugese guide, who is full of stories and legends.
The main square in Lisbon. The main square in Lisbon, face to the river. Some ministeries buildings. In dowtown, lots of restaurants, bars, etc.

Probably the best european capital square. Facing Tagus River, this Lisbon’s historical square is wonderful, and probably one of the best in European capitals.A wide open space surrounded by restaurants, cultural attractions and full of life.This is one of the most visited places in the Portuguese capital.

Stunning location in the city. This square is definitely worth a visit whilst in Lisbon. It looks stunning approaching from Rua Augusta through the arch and from the river.There are a number of cafes and attractions around the square including a wine tasting room (good fun) or a beer museum. The square leads to the water where you can even have a paddle to cool off.The arch itself is amazing. Take the elevator and steps up to the top! The entrance to this is hidden away and not very well advertised - we stumbled on it by accident. There were only 2 other people up there when we were there but the views over the square and the rest of the city are outstanding.

Main square of Lisbon. Lots of options of restaurants, nice architecture. Has a cool Beer Museum and a tourist information facility. But the best restaurant option is a 5 minute walk away, the 'João do Grão' at Coureiros St.

Great place to just hang out and chill after a long day of walking.. We'd just gravitate to this area because it's so great. There are stores, restaurants, bars and of course the water! We'd usually stop here coming back from a long day of walking somewhere just because it's a great area to hang out, have a glass of wine, people watch, or just chill by the water. There is also a ferry nearby you can take for a short trip on the water.

Nice spot on the river. The area around the river is the best. See the statue, the square, the gate.. All great. This is a transportation hub too... All the hop on/hop offs have stops here. Lots of souvenir shops.. All the cheap stuff that fills a purpose.. Lots of people around, people with menus in your face... Be careful here.. Worth a visit..
A great space. The square is on the water, reminding you of St. Petersburg, Rome, squares in Paris. Wonderful space to people watch.
Great area. Definitely take the time to explore this avenue, great little cafés and bakeries. There are several restaurants as well, reminds me of la rambla in Barcelona without trees.

Large open area. This large open square on the banks of the River Tagus has a number of cafe's around it's edge with a large imposing statue in it's centre and is very well worth seeing for it's architecture alone.

Beautiful old mosaics. Lisbon was our last port of call on a P and O cruise.On our way in,we went under the Tagus Bridge and because the bridge is made of metalwork,it enables ships passengers,to see the underside of any cars going over the bridge,and also hear a strange buzzing noise as it passes under.At the end of the bridge is a vast statue of Christ,similar to the one in Rio deJanerio.We got a shuttle bus, which dropped us off at the main shopping square and walked down towards the Triumphal Arch.Here leads through to a massive square ,where you can get buses or trams,and also there is a large black horse statue here, also refreshments. Back up the shopping area,where we saw street sellers,huge bubble blowers,beggars,men trying to sell you sunglasses,and an old lady that was blind, sat singing for a pittance. To the left ,going upwards, on a side street is the very old iron lift, which takes you to the upper level, where all the restuarants are.What i liked best ,was the old mosaics on the front of most of the buildings,some of them were stunning. Also the pavements were made of black and white patterned mosaics.At the top of the hill is St. George Castle,where you can walk round the walls and see cannons and telescopes for views over the city.Really liked Lisbon and would like to return.

A lovely open space before the crowded Alfama ascend. I stumbled across this big pocket of an open planned brilliant white stoned floor which magnificently reflected the sun’s rays right back at me. Walking through Alfama, this area is located on the straight road that runs by the harbour and what a gem it is. The huge square (Patio da Gale) has a centre piece with a tall statue however the steps located right under it are not clean and actually very dirty, so wouldn’t recommend sitting there. There were a few large groups enjoying the open space and restaurants that are lined on the perimeter of this square. The best part however is the steps located near the ocean that allows people to sit and look at the waves right by your feet! Casually glaring at the huge cruise liners in the distant waves provides a relaxing chill. I even managed to doze off for a little bit! Obviously, once again be aware of pit-pockets and the street sellers who can be quite aggressive. Otherwise, for a sunny Saturday this was a lovely pit-stop before venturing further into the Alfama district. There is a metro Station located within the perimeter of the square and trams circle around, therefore transport is plentiful. Here is also the building gate that begins the long road of ‘Rua Augusta’. I strongly recommend going from Praca do Comercio through to Rua Augusta, as it sets you up perfectly for the full Alfama experience. ‘Rua Augusta’ is another lively market littered road, with all sorts of food/shops/tourist features so be sure to add this to your itinerary.

Wonderful Area. We were returning to Lisbon for a two day rest before returning home after walking the Camino de Santiago, and walked to the Praça do Comércio. Wonderful shops, cafes, monuments, not to mention the gate ! It was raining the day we went there, but not to worry, there were college initiations going on with singing and upper classmen dressed in capes ! What a wonderful experience. Once again Lisbon delivers in spades !

Oh my god. Its my first time in lisbonYesterday after a long long trip we arrive in lisbon and begin to visit city although so tired ...I dont imagine that lisbon can shock me this waySo so so ... Much beautiful and atractive street and building even in rainy afternoon that completey wet us ...I glad that choose lisbon as part of our new year holiday and recomend to everyone that visit this city

Loved the area.....not the food. We had a brilliant time walking along the Praca do Comercio down to the waterfront. My one complaint is that the food offerings in this area during the day are way too touristy and not in the least bit authentic Portuguese. The waterfront area is brilliant and buzzing, as is the very impressive Santa Justa lift, which is just totally fantastic; you have to go up it.
Nice area. About a 15 minute walk from the train station, this area is great to walk around and do some shopping.

Lovely to walk round and take in the view. Good place to people watch and rest your feet.I can imagine it will be heaving in Summer.The walk down from to here from Heritage Avenida is lovely with all the shops and etc.

Lisbon visit. Arrived in Lisbon by cruise ship in December 2013. I had organised my tours via cruising excursions and there were some passengers from our ship and two other ships. Towards the end of the tour we realised that we would be able to walk back to the ship and walked through this area and saw their modern Christmas trees. For the time of year it was still lovely and warm so all in all, a great day.

Old and traditional Lisbon. Nice walk to enjoy old and traditional Lisbon with some seafood restaurants and cafes. The architecture is quite enjoyable also. It ends in a big square close to the river Tejo.

Nice square . The heart of Lisbon so we were told. A huge square surrounded by restaurants and bars (including a beer "museum"). You can see the triumphal arch and the river on one side. Also the place to catch trams. Great photo opportunities here and there is a free wi-fi hotspot where you catch the trams and buses. See it at different times of day to see its beauty especially at sunset
Great walk. Great for a walk! We visited square several times and there were always a lot of people and something happening.

Not THAT great for New Year's eve celebrations. This is a really magnificent square situated next to the Tagus river.Since we were going to be in Lisbon for New Year's eve we were advised to be right there for the new year's eve celebrations. We were a little disappointed though.. there was no big clock or digital countdown set up and the show provided was not entertaining at all - it was very boring in fact: the presenter was talking too much and some songs were actually sad! The best part was the last set of fireworks.

Great Area of the City. Come and experience the river. The square is huge and opens up to the Tagus river. You can walk down from Rossio here and then along the river either to the left to the Se area or to the right and see a newer addition to the river side of lisbon. On a sunny day it is a great spot to visit.

Amazing statue . We visited the square several times during our visit to Lisbon. It is with at least one visit to see the amazing statue in the center. We also spent New Years here for the count down with now issue. Everyone from teens, families, tourists and older people were in attendance. We stayed to the edges of the crowd and near the water and had no problems. Remember to bring some beer or sparkling wine to really enjoy the night!

One of Europes great squares. I had visited Lisbon many years previously and when i knew we were coming back this square was the first thing that came to mind - it was the most memorable and Iconic sight from our last visit.The square is huge - one side is open to the riverfront (quite unusual - bit like the City Square in Trieste in that respect) with a large statue in the middle. Three sides of the square have collonaded buildings. As a photo opportunity it's first rate. As a piece of history it certainly evokes the glorious days of Portugal's Colonial heyday. Unlike most of the squares in Madrid (or Spain as a whole) this is not blighted by immigrants setting out blankets and selling fake handbags etc so credit to the Portugese for cracking down on this.One of the must sees in Lisobn and rightly so

You can't miss it. Even if you wanted you, you pretty much can't miss this. It's central and huge and definitely worth it. Beautiful architecture, very nice views on both sides of the arch, a few restaurants and stops for trams and buses. Great meeting point, good for people watching and photos. It's right at the beginning of the pedestrian Rua Augusta, and the rest of the Chiado where you will find shops and restaurants.
A lovely place. You should definitely visit this huge (better if in a sunny day) and take some pictures along the Tejo. The landscape is beautiful.

Impressive. This is a huge square, featuring some magnificent views. It's also a good place to pick up the Yellow Bus trolley to the Castle of St George. However, because it attracts tourists, it also attracts those who prey on them or who see them as a market for illicit items. There are bathrooms in the stores around the Square, but none are without fee.

Great people watching. Huge square surrounded by restaurants and on weekends a small market of local artists selling their creations. You can enjoy breakfast, lunch and dinner in any of the many restaurants and get a suntan on one side of the square in the morning and on the other in the afternoon. The statues and the arch to Rua Augusta are beautiful.
Lovely stroll. This is another example of excellent architecture of lisbon, a lovely stroll around and the great views through the arches are a delight.

A huge and lovely square.. This is a huge square, which is also called "Palace square" by the locals, as the royal palace was located here once.Nowadays, it's a vast square with a lovely statue of King José I in the middle and a stunning triumphal arch in the north.There are several cafés and restaurants in the square and it also offers numerous public transportation options (trams, buses and metro).There are numerous photo-ops in the square, especially when it is dramatically lit in the evenings.
A lovely part of town. We walked around,and had a few drinks. It was raining cats and dogs sadly, but we still enjoyed it. Go and have a look the city and people are fantastic.

A Big Plaza and it seems like the place people want to sell drugs in. A big, open plaza that looks nice but was empty and nothing going on while we were there. Looks really good and a pleasant photo opportunity but no I don't want to buy any drugs thanks! I don't think I look like a druggie but was approached at least 4 times in 30mins asking if I wanted to buy drugs.

Ample square. An ample square in the center of Lisbon, oriented towards to the river with big arcades. Have a drink at one of the bars at the sides of the square or just take a panorama photo of the square. Mostly enjoyable during summer and in warm nights.

The breath of history - Lisboa's lost wealth. You feel the breath of Lisboas history, when at the Praca do Comercio. And its not only the momuments and statues, but also the plinths near the water and the feeling of Lisboa's lost wealth and current economical situation that you sense here. Do go, you wont regret it!

An Impressive Square with a Great History. The history of this area is very interesting, so it is good to see this square as part of a walking tour. The square, arch and pedestrian mall behind the arch are all so beautiful. There are numerous cafes, restaurants and a great patisserie in the area behind the arch, in the mall area. The mall is on the Rua Augusta. This is an amazing place which you really should not miss!

Beautiful pedestrian street. Kind of the avenida Florida or taksim of Lisbon, this beautiful pedestrian street is full of delicious restaurants and shops that runs from the waterfront up north to rossio square. A great cobblestone lined walk with plenty of places to stop for a bite.

pretty little square for a great photo op. That's about it.. A large square in a beautiful historical setting. Excellent photo op, but there's not much else. Pass by take your obligatory photo and keep it moving. Don't get me wrong the place was pretty, but other than that noting of particular interest.

History and beautiful achitecture. A large square in a beautiful historical setting, with lots of cozy restaurations, which all have one thing in common, they aren't cheap (and perhaps a little touristed). It's definitely nice to look at and a great photo opportunity, and a must see in Lisbon. Note it's not particularly interesting for young children. It's easy to get there with a short walk from the Metro and it's a major busstop location as well.
A must in Lissabon. A beautiful square with a couple of restaurants were you can eat or take something to drink. Close to the shopping, buses and trams. The tourist information is located here.

Heart of Lisbon. You can visit the beer museum :), have a wine tasting session, have some good food and it's also a very impressive square, large, home of many events and gatherings. Also a place from where may transport options from Lisbon start. A must see place

Even under construction it is Outstanding ! ! !. Whether you are viewing from aloft in the Castle of King George or walking through and around it this is one of the most outstanding features in Lisbon. The Archecture, shops and eateries enhance the aura this are maintains. Still a must even though portions are draped and covered.

a beautiful view from above. This beautiful square has many names Terreiro do Passo, Praça do Comércio, and so on. Its just a beautiful square, can take good pictures from the corner next to the river, the angle facing the St Jorge castle. Next to the two columns a beautuful picture, unique of Lisbon with the Bridge and the Christ the King monument, if a plane comes better still. Lots of cafés, the several ministeries, some empty.The central black horse monument still covered. But since early August you have a new attraction, you can go up the Rua Augusta Arch for 2,5 euros and see the Praça de Comércio from above, and also the Baixa lisboeta, the Cathedral and other monuments. Its worth a visit.

Center of Lisbon (Beware: Drugs sold on the street). In my opinion, this is the highlight of Lisbon. Truly a beautiful Comercio square which shows Portuguese architecture at its peak. But, BEWARE: while here, we were approached by 3 different local men trying to sell us marihuana, and other drugs!

The only thing a really liked about Lisboa. Is big, you have an amazing view (bridges, rivers, buildings), and also can eat some ice cream (we went in summer and the weather was HOT). Also it's wheelchair friendly.
It's like a nicer Las Ramblas-ish. Touristy,busy but on a summer day - stunning.Worth a look.Lots of shops n cafes.its free to walk down.stunning square at the end.shops here aren't cheap though.

Huge, incredibly huge.. It is one of the undisputed symbols of the city, I have to admit that this place has impressed me very much because of its size, is spectacular, large but after all in addition to a few statues there is not much to see.However, it is one of those places in the city that sooner or later you're going to visit.

Tradition and History. Do not miss Praça do Comércio and search for the history of this beautiful located and well serviced site in Lisbon. In the night it is still without the final lights project, still to be installed (as we were told), so, try to visit during the day.

Renewed and Work in Progress. Went to lunch at Praça do Comércio or Páteo da Galé (the new name).
Beautiful people and nice places around the square.
Beautiful view of Tagus (Tejo in Portuguese) river.
In Lisbon do not miss!

under contruction. a bit disapoint to find this place are under contruction
but the square itself is big and it is a nice view to sit and relex next to the seaside

under renovations June 2013. What a huge disappointment. I was hoping to enjoy the square over a meal with my family but it is entirely under wraps of scaffolding and plastic mesh! Too, too bad - it is usually lovely.

Giant Square. There's really beautifull and so enormous! It makes you feel small (in a good way)
And you can walk into the river if you feel like it!

Presently under renovation, still grand. Since we were spending more than a week in Lisbon, we knew we had to see Praca do Comercio and Lisbon's downtown. The fact that the square is under renovation was a bit of a bummer, but you can still take in the magnificent seascape there - it reminds me very much of Venice's Piazza San Marco in that respect.And while the statue and triumphal arch, two things one would photograph automatically, are the very items under renovation, the placards that cover them give lots of information about the square and the statue's construction, which is very cool.And of course Praca do Comercio is a meeting point of sorts - since were staying in Alfama and wanted to get to Santos and Belem, we came to the Praca to get the #15 tram a couple of times.

Under Construction. I ahd read a lot about Praca do Comercio in the forums and was looking forward to go there. But I was sort of shocked when I reached. Everything was under construction and there were very few people. It is strategically located. I am not in a position to say how good it was but as of May beginning, there is hardly any reason to go there.

A place to start . Is an historical large square of the city. A good place to start your walking tour or take the trans, buses or metro. The place is the main entrance of Lisbon when you look the river with its historical importance, I suggest the city historical museum on the left side.On my last visit (may 2013) the triumph arc of Augusta street and kings statue are covered for restoration.
Nice place near the Tejo's shore. On the edge of Alfama and Baixa one of the most romantic places in Lisbon. This plain and elegant sqere looks like an open cinema with the "screen" to Tejo.

Working in progress. One one the best PRAÇA in Europe.The problem is there are constrution and repairs on progress. I hope they will bfinish before summer...Its a shame that touris our locals can't enjoy this grandious PRAÇA
Under construction. A lot of space. Two important monuments can't be seen (under reconstruction). Take a coffee there and go Rua Augusta

not much here. large square leading to the seafront,essentially empty apart from the expensive<trendy?> eateries housed in the buildings around its perimeter.there is also a metro station for the disappointed and some bus stops

Nice for an afternoon walk... Nice for an afternoon walk: have a snack, take some pics, observe the locals..
Nothing amazing, but still worth visiting. You may also find some nice stalls selling jewels and bags.

I'd rate it better if the statue and entrance arch wouldnt be under construction.... ...but that wasn't a bad thing, of course. We liked it cause from there it's a nice starting point throughout the city and nice yellow colour of the horse shape building is nice to someone who's orientation is rather poor. We can easily imagine how, after Vasco da Gama and other traders came home with spices, huge crowd gathered and bought the stuff to bring to their shops. Being in Lisbon, you'll soon find yourself in that square. Enjoy.

One of the most beautiful squares. Don't miss it! Huge space with nice walking area close to the river!At the side thera are nice terraces. All the time there are some entertaintment- street musicans etc.

Under wraps!. Good location with a great view of the river Tagus. Unfortunately for us we visited at a time of restoration and the much photographed statue and gateway were hidden under scaffolding and polythene
Nice place to be outdoors on the waterfront.. Loved the huge monuments and the open places. Very good to enjoy a beverage with the cool breezes blowing and great view.

Under restoration. When the restoration is completed, I would imagine this plaza will be lovely, but what I imagine are some of the prettiest structures are covered up. Some good cafes, metro stop in the square, probably a lively place when the weather is good.
Must see. We had breakfast there on our first day. Being brazilian I love a breakfast with fruit and toast... definitely recommend going there and walking around that whole area
One of the places to chat and eat. Very good value food and drink especially just off the square. Don't be put off by waiters trying to get your custom, it's how they do it in some places!

Too big. I think my timing was off. There was nothing going on, no light shows as in the review below me, and I was only confronted by people trying to sell me stuff.The square itself is impressive at first, but really it's just too big, just vast empty space, and although there was a monument at the centre, it is currently scaffolded and covered up for restoration. Same goes for the main building of the square.At least I was just walking through, which is fine, but I definitely wouldn't go out of my way to see it.
Wonderful. This is a beautiful place, lots to see the buildings are great, so much heritage. Worth the trip to see it
Biggest square in Lisbon. Worth a walk around - we didn't go in the museum but sat and had a drink at a cafe and watched the world go by!

Sound and Light Show. This Easter there was a free sound and light show in the Praco running intermittently during the evening. The stunning images were displayed on the facades of the buildings accompanied by music telling the story of LIsbon. I am not sure if it is a permanent feature but well worth a visit.

Captivating square. A place to meet up with friends with minor attractions at walking distance i.e. the beer museum and minor museum showing the history of Lisbon in digital format/presentation among others including some interesting/boutique restaurants - seafoods. Occasional flea marketlike atmosphere on a weekend - local artisans selling their items/wares. A walk to the Tagus River reveals a view of Almada and of Feb.25 Bridge and of Cristo Rei - bring some nuts/bread crumbs to feed those doves, a scene stealer and for an interesting photo op. :-)
love it. Very good place to shop and have fun, to walk with friend. There s lots of good monuments to see, to take pictures and eat good food at the restaurants.

Huge but wet and windy. A superb space. It's a shame the weather was against us. The statue and main ornate archway were hidden behind scaffolding for restoration works. Great views across the river. The square is well served by teams, buses and the metro

The Empire lives on. In many ways, Lisbon is a mixture of beauty and ugliness, where the former more than compensates for the latter. Never more so than in this vast square ------ the finest in Portugal and one of the greatest in all of Europe ----- that could only have been conceived in the heart of a major imperial city. It is vast, Apart from serving as a focus for transport and light refreshment, it has a stately Ministry Building (I forget which one) forming one side. Two of the other sides are composed of dignified colonnades giving shelter to cafes and restaurants, but also to street traders so numerous as to meet the definition of a market, giving colour and vibrance to the grayish surroundings. The centre is occupied by a handsome equestrian statue of Jose 1, and there is other triumphal sculpture that visitors will want to convert to digital images. The scale of the place seems to cry out: "It is we who discovered the world!"

Pity about thr restoration of the statue in the middle!. Lovely square with wonderful buildings on 3 sides.On a metro line and has a very good information place on one side.Good river views and plenty of bars/cafes with outdoor tables.
Feast for the eyes and the palate.. Great expanse on River Tago full of history. A must,the Restaurant Martinho de Arcade,meeting place for the Lisbon intelligentsia for ages.

Lovely place. A really nice and impressive place to sit by the water for a while and enjoy the view. There are some nice cafes around the square, some of which are a lot more expensive than others in baixa if you're just looking for a coffee, but a great place to just sit and relax for a while.

Unfortunately undergoing lots of renovation. Lovely public space, but the arch and the statue are covered in scaffolding so couldn't appreciate the square in all its glory. But still a nice place for an espresso and to catch the tram.
big open space. Nice place to stop for a drink or a meal and enjoy the world wandering by and listen to the buskers. Shame the statues and arch were shrouded in scaffolding.
Nothing breathtaking,just typical square. A good place to see the views on the river,good position,but as I've already mentioned,not something breathtaking.Another beautiful typical european square.
Amazing architecture!. Don't miss this place and stay for a coffee and pastry in one of square cafes with life music from local music players! :)
One more square in Europe. A big square, full of tourist and surrounded by restaurants and banks, nothing from other world, but if you are lucky, you can see really good concerts in there.

Very pretty.. Loved just walking around the square watching the people and looking up the river Tagus. There was a local band playing that gave a flavour of the country. Enjoyed the booths that sold jewelry and art.

A square that offers you an access to every part of the city. It is a big square where all the public transport meets. One can get on a bus, the metro, the tram. On the southern side of it is the river. One can take a pause and sit on the river bank. YOu can walk to Bairro Alto and Chiado.

Wonderful place to chill in the sunshine. Immense square, lovely architecture and waterfront view. Lisbon is such a compact city centre, you're never too far away from this, the focal point of the city. We were there in December but it was still a great spot for a bite to eat and a lazy afternoon in the sun, Beer Museum recommended lunch spot.

Perfect place to grab lunch. I have eaten outside here several times. It is touristy but who cares - the atmosphere is so pretty and nice on a sunny day. Plus it's steps from Chiado to shop after you eat.

One of the best city icons. Paris has the Eiffel tower, London has the Big Ben but Lisbon has the beautiful and full of history "Commerce Square".
Full of masonic iconography, it has a mystery waiting at every corner for the lucky visitor.

Historic Center of Lisbon. Great historic location with view on Trejo river surrounded by multiple cafes and restaurants. Do not recommend eating there as it can be more expensive than in other locations but definitely worth getting coffee, dessert or glass of Porto wine. If you have one hour go see the Story Center to learn about Lisbon's history including the earthquake which set grounds for the current downtown street layout.

Incredible buildings. The square is really large and is circumscribed by beautiful yellow buildings on three of its 4 sides. The fourth one overlooks the water. It's a pity the water section is a forgotten backdrop. Just some concrete unattractive structures... completely uninviting.
Immense!. One of the largest in Europe that I have seen.To walk by, and perhaps have a coffee or a beer on one of the terrasses (there is even a beer museum on the east side a beleive!)

Nice square, but not a lot going on. Renovation work going on at present and it really is just an open square. The Lisbon Shop containing selection of Portugese handicrafts is there and some nice cafes, so good for sitting and chilling.

Getting better and better. It's getting better & better with the years (as Porto wine): cars & noise have almost disappeared, there's more space for strolling around, more cafes. Facades were renovated not long time ago and now they are cleaning the statue and the arch.

Shops + Eating + River. Nice to take some pictures with the river on the background or the Arch on the opposite side. Beautiful architecture surrounding the square. Lots of restaurants in the little arches as well as some night clubs. Great to watch the sunset!

nice palce to sit and relax. The monument in the middle of the square was under construction during my visit but this was probably a good thing as the hoarding around the statue gave loads of info on the construction and design which was really interesting. It is a nice place to sit outside and just watch people go by. The museum of beer has nice beers it brews for E2.50 a glass although it really is more a restaurant and bar then a museum! there are trams/buses/metro station in the area so really accesible and also on the city tour bus route.

great view and a place to relax. This charming waterfront square is one of the most beautiful in Europe in my opinion. Even with the construction work that was going on in March you were rewarded with grand views of the castle and Cristo Rei across the Tagus. The triumphal arch is dramatic as the building it graces serves as the perfect frame. People are attracted to the statue in the middle and come to sit and talk. This is probably the 2nd best place to people watch after Rossio Square.

open space (at the time with construction works). pretty square, expensive restaurants, road works, and the little seat next to the water is not that nice since the coastline is not that nice... walk through it but not worth to linger much, combine it with your walk up Alfama.

beautiful and great. It is not the spirit of Lisbon (this is Alfama), but if you want to go to a special place, great, with some good options to have a nice food, try this place! It looks like a "big door to enter the city".

Lovely area to sample some cafe culture. We visited the square a few times during our 3 day stay, whether to use the trams/metro or to have a few drinks in one of the cafes. Lovely ambience and a great place to watch the sun go down!

The centre of the city!. I really LOVE this square and just seating at one of the many bars around it, sipping some wine and seeing the life passing by is in itself a whole experience! Dont miss the Lisbon Story Centre !
Modern place in an old location. Very interesting architectural contrast. Great location, good restaurants and cafés around and a practical and new metro station.

Praca do Comercio where Lisbon meets the waterfront. The Praca do Comercio is a huge square surrounded by old buildings common to all European town squares. The buildings are now home to shops and restaurants including the Vini Portugal wine venue and the Museum of Cervesa. The square is bordered by the Rua Augusto Arch, the gateway to the shopping thoroughfare. Trams, busses and the metro are all located nearby and will take you to just about anywhere you need to go in the city.

Beautiful open square with steps down into the water. There is a grand entrance into the square and its very spacious in the square itself. There is even enough room for a stage, which was set up when we were there. The square ends with steps right down into the water. It was great just to lounge on the steps and watch the sun go down. There are shops and cafes all along the sides of the square.

Stunning!!. Once in Lisbon you must visit this square, 'cause it's one of the most beautiful and emblematic places of the city. I advise you to leave the subway in "Restauradores" and walk from there to Terreiro do Paço, because the streets that you will see in the way have that atmosphere that you really don't wanna miss. Once you get to the river, sit for a little bit on the steps and enjoy the view of the bridge and (possibly) the sunset, while you feel the magic of a place that saw so many important people arrive and leave the city, over the centuries.

An amazing experience. Pracio del Comercio was one of our stops we made while in Lisbon. We are so happy we made a stop here. The structures were simply amazing, beyond words. We don’t have anything like this in Toronto Canada. This is one of the reasons why I love travelling in Europe. I get to see things I don’t normally get to see back home. Pracio del Comercio also has an excellent view of the water. An amazing experience to say the least!

900 square meters of light. Inaugurated during the reign of King Joseph I of Portugal and under the government of the Marquis de Pombal, on 07/06/1775, this plaza called the trade, because it is the place where you would trasações the commercial, which besides being the place where the customs, joins tobacco and still others "ministerial offices" of that time, the center has ample space only statue to the monarch to whom they wanted laurear. an impressive statue more than 14 meters high. the true port of Lisbon who arrives in town by the river Tagus

Near the water. This square makes you feel like the ships will be coming soon. The ark on the entrance and the monument in the centre are very beautiful. Try sitting at the stone seats near the water for a while. Very pleasant.
Beautiful at night. Pracio del Comercio is the most beautiful square in Lisbon. An amazing view over the river and the architecture is beautiful.
Beautiful Square. It is a must visit in Lisbon. From the park you can see the 25 April Bridge and you can walk to the Rossio area.
Beautiful Square. The architecture of the Pracio del Comercio is very good. The Arch of Triumph is beautiful. So is the bronze equestrian statue of King Dom Jose I.

A pool of light. Built over where once stood the inquisition fires Terreiro do Paço is an Illuminist creation of light and splendor. Marquês de Pombal tried to cut off completely with the memory of what had happened there, and create a beautiful place to be in contact with the river and it's natural essence.

A great, beautiful square!. Lisbon's major square was recently redone and restored. Opening onto the river Tagus, the beautiful square provides wonderful views of the river, and of the city itself. Framed by the beautiful yellow buildings, which constitute Ministeries and the Supreme Court of Justice, you can find many places of inetrest: there are now cafés, restaurants and discotheques along it's archades, and most significantly the famous Martinho da Arcada, Lisbon's oldest restaurant, of which one of Portugal's paramount poets, Fernando Pessoa, was an habitué. Hi table is still an almost sacred place, being the last to be occupied and only when necessary.
must go, but just for a fast visit. Good square but nothing special, take your time to have a drink looking at the tourist taking pictures, nothing else to do
Beautiful European Square. This was a beautiful european square to walk around.

Busy bustling plaza. We went to this Praca do Commercio several times. Once we met our Lisbon Walker tour here. Once we went to visit the vendors under the arched column halls around the outside edge. One because we knew there was a clean bathroom- although one does have to pay .50 E, I think. But, one can not complain when it is open and clean at all times. And, once to watch the beginning of the segway tours. We have taken segway tours in the past so we know about the learning curve. it was a hoot watching others get the hang of it. There are also a couple of cafes on the Praca with tables and umbrellas which looked quite nice. Also one gets to see where the Kings got on their boats. Also, at the water's edge there is a tiny beach area. There was some construction in the area which is a great sign. When we were in Athens a couple of years ago, the streets were in poor condition and much needed to be improved. It was much nicer to see that Lisbon is trying to keep up with repairs.
Spacious. A big square, a bit unpersonal. A lot of cement, but surrounded by beautiful buildings and some Nice cafés.

Royal Palace with The View. We can imagine going back in time to Descoveries Era when Portuguese founded The First World Empire with cities in 5 Continents! Terreiro do Paço was our Cape Canaveral with a difference we have an Historical World Class Monument and Square.

Nice square, but watch out for construction season. Nice view of the river on one side and the brightly colored ministry building on the other. There was a lot of construction going on when I visited, which did spoil the views somewhat, but construction must get done. This is also a jumping-off point for lots of tour buses, so expect quite a few to roll by. There were people selling various crafts and street performers near the Arch, but I enjoyed the river side a bit more. Oh, and yes, there were drug dealers here, too.

Between the river and the old part of the city. When you descend Av. Liberdade from Mq. Pombal statue, you reach Restauradores and Rossio, which then leads via several arteries to Terreiro do Paço. This is a historical area, a plaza or square which nowaydays has several ministeries and other locations of the sort. Cars are not allowed around it these days and public transport has limitations as well.Part of the touristic route throughout the old side of the city.

Probably the most important square in Lisboa. This is a real must see in Lisboa. The square is beautiful and the river views are amazing. You can relax, take a lot of photos of the river, 25 de Abril bridge, Cristo Rei, and then walk in the streets of Baixa (downtown), full with cafes, restaurants and shops.

lisbon´s ayuntamiento. this famous square was where all the ministries were in the past. they still bear the name of each ministry, you can find several exposition on each side, see the schedule, a good picture from the center to the arch of Rua Augusta, and also near the river. Some cruises port near by at Santa Apolónia. The view from next to the river the horse and st jorge castle is a must.
Very nice. A large yard with lots of history, try to know the history of this place, it´s very nice
Entry to Lisbon. It is a big square with some restaurants and cafes, and a place to relax by the river... It's a good place to be on a sunny afternoon =)

An amazing square. Praça do Comercio is known as the "welcoming square" of the city. Although that applied to the times people used to get Lisboa by the river Tagus, it keeps on being a magnificient  square, one of the biggest in Europe (180m x 200m)

Splendid 18th-century square on the great river. Lisbon has fortunately eliminated the car traffic and parking that used to mar the Praça do Comercio (Terreiro do Paço).  The square is a large space surrounded by an arcaded building in dark yellow, with a triumphal arch in the centre.  It's certainly a top sight in the most historic part of the city.  Highly recommended.

My favourite place. This place for sure is small, but the architecture, the small surrroundings & the neat places nearby surely deserves a small walk in the area. To all the places i've been in lisbon, i think this place has its own stamp, a "Lisboa Stamp". We really enjoyed to walk around, so do not miss it!
Spectacular. That is one of the best places in Lisbon without any hesitation. There is a great square and a lot of monuments and architecture. Highly recommend it!

It's Nice and All, But There's Not Much to It. Praça Do Comércio is a lovely square, although there's really not much to it. A large statue in the middle, a cafe or two in one corner and a lot of open space. It's a nice place to stretch your legs and breath in the salty sea air. At night, tiny floor lights are illuminated which give the whole square a pleasant shimmer.
Wonderful. Very nice place with wonderful view and good winetasting.

Lovely Square. Terreiro do Paço or Praça do Comércio is one of the biggest squares in the world. Surrounded by the buildings of the ministries it is an imposing place. In the center an equestrian statue of Dom José the king that rebuilt the square.All of this area was the Palace square until the XVIII century. In that period it was called Terreiro do Paço literally the Palace Square. However, in 1775 a huge quake shook the city and everything collapsed. The rulers decided to build a new big square in a neoclassical style that was supposed to be the center for commerce, hence, Square of Commerce its new name. However this never stick.The highlights of the square are besides the square the dock where the boats used to arrive with the collumns, the triumphant arch of the entrance of Rua augusta, Café Martinho da Arcada one of the oldest in the world and the Patio da Gale where expositions are held.

Picturesque but the smell of dope by the waterfront was a bit off-putting. Apparently it's known as a dealing area but a pleasant location all the same. You can be waiting quite a while to get across the road to the steps down to the river.

The door to Lisbon (from the sea/river). Praça do Comercio is a monumental place.This is where the old royal palace used to be before the big earthquake that destroyed Lisbon. This square is the perfect setting for arriving to Lisbon, as it must have been great to step off a ship into this great square.We strolled through the square, and then sat on the small wall facing the river, watching Lisbon and its citizen pass by. It's a square and it's monumental.
Praça do comercio. It's a really imponent place in the historic Lisbon , From the south side of the Tagus river you can see at night this open and lighted place. The correct name is Praça do Comércio

Check out the Christmas Tree. We were in Lisbon at Christmas, and on this square they have a Christams Tree. I believe it is the biggest Christmas Tree in Europe. However it's not real it's made out of metal, but it is worth goin to have a look at.
